choices.text: Normal photopic and scotopic responses on electroretinography (ERG)
Absent cone responses, preserved rod responses
Extinguished or severely reduced scotopic and photopic ERG responses
Increased b-wave amplitude with preserved a-wave on ERG

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with progressive night blindness and peripheral vision loss since adolescence. Fundoscopic examination findings is shown in the image. Which of the following electrophysiologic findings is most consistent with the pathology shown?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extinguished or severely reduced scotopic and photopic ERG responses

 

  • This fundus image is classic for Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP) — a hereditary retinal dystrophy characterized by degeneration of rod and cone photoreceptors. 
  • Early in the disease, rod (scotopic) responses diminish first, leading to night blindness (nyctalopia). 
  • Eventually, cone (photopic) responses are also lost, affecting central and color vision.
  • ERG in advanced RP shows:
    • Severely reduced or extinguished photopic and scotopic responses.
    • Loss of both a-wave and b-wave amplitudes due to widespread photoreceptor and inner retinal dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal photopic and scotopic responses on electroretinography (ERG): Incorrect. Normal ERG would rule out RP, especially when clear clinical signs and symptoms are present.

 

Option B. Absent cone responses, preserved rod responses: Incorrect. This pattern is seen in cone dystrophies, not RP (where rods are typically affected earlier).

 

Option D. Increased b-wave amplitude with preserved a-wave on ERG: Incorrect. This finding might suggest enhanced S-cone syndrome or electronegative ERG as in congenital stationary night blindness, not typical RP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Retinitis Pigmentosa is characterized by progressive loss of rods and cones, leading to extinguished ERG responses in advanced stages. 
  • Classic signs include bone spicule pigmentation, vessel attenuation, and optic disc pallor.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents with a palpable breast lump. Histopathological examination of the biopsy reveals tumor cells with signet ring morphology, mucin deposition, and a pattern of infiltration within fibrous stroma, as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Invasive lobular carcinoma

 

  • The hallmark histopathological features seen in the image and described in the case—signet ring cells, mucin deposition, and Indian file pattern (single rows of tumor cells infiltrating the stroma)—are characteristic of invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast.
  • This subtype originates from the terminal duct-lobular unit and is often bilateral and multicentric.
  • Loss of E-cadherin expression is a key molecular feature, leading to poor cohesion between cells and the classic single-file pattern.
  • Signet ring cells (cells with mucin pushing the nucleus to the periphery) are also commonly seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Invasive ductal carcinoma: This is the most common type of breast cancer and tends to form glandular or duct-like structures, not single-file patterns or signet ring cells.

 

Option C. Mucinous carcinoma: Although mucin production is a feature, this carcinoma shows clusters or islands of tumor cells floating in large pools of extracellular mucin, not an Indian file pattern.

 

Option D. Medullary carcinoma: Characterized by sheets of large anaplastic cells, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, and well-circumscribed borders, not mucin or signet ring cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast typically shows signet ring cells, mucin production, and the Indian file pattern on histology due to loss of E-cadherin, distinguishing it from other breast cancer subtypes.

questions.text: A baby presented with abdominal pain. On examination, a mass is palpated in the right lumbar region. A barium enema is done, and the image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intussusception 

 

  • The barium enema shows the classic "claw sign" (crescent filling defect), which is diagnostic of intussusception. 
  • This condition involves telescoping of one segment of the intestine into another, most commonly the ileocolic junction. 
  • It presents with sudden onset colicky pain, vomiting, "red currant jelly" stools, and a palpable sausage-shaped abdominal mass. 
  • Barium or air enema is both diagnostic and therapeutic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Volvulus: Volvulus typically presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. Imaging may show the "coffee bean" or "whirlpool" sign, not the claw sign.

 

Option C. Duodenal atresia: This presents in neonates with bilious vomiting and no passage of meconium. The hallmark X-ray finding is the "double bubble" sign, not seen here.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction: This is a broad term encompassing various causes. The patient presents with greenish vomiting. While intussusception is a type of obstruction, the claw sign specifically points to intussusception rather than general obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intussusception should be suspected in infants with episodic pain, vomiting, and red currant jelly stools, and is confirmed by the claw sign on contrast enema, which can also be therapeutic.

choices.text: Mortality is uniformly low and limited to children.
Disease affects only elderly or immunocompromised.
Mortality can range from 5% to 50%, and all age groups except breastfed infants may be affected.
It presents with inflammatory cellulitis and is due to fungal contamination.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is most accurate about epidemic dropsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mortality can range from 5% to 50%, and all age groups except breastfed infants may be affected.

 

  • Epidemic dropsy results from the consumption of mustard oil adulterated with Argemone oil, which contains the toxic alkaloid sanguinarine. It presents with:
    • Non-inflammatory bilateral pitting edema (typically of the legs)
    • Associated symptoms: diarrhea, dyspnea, cardiac failure, and rarely glaucoma
    • High mortality (5–50%) depending on the level of contamination and promptness of intervention
    • Affects all age groups except breastfed infants, who are protected due to dietary isolation from contaminated food

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mortality is uniformly low and limited to children: Incorrect. Mortality is not uniformly low and may be high in adults with severe cardiac involvement. Also, children are not the only affected group.

 

Option B. Disease affects only elderly or immunocompromised: Incorrect. The disease affects all age groups (except breastfed infants) and is not limited to the elderly or immunocompromised.

 

Option D. It presents with inflammatory cellulitis and is due to fungal contamination: Incorrect. The edema is non-inflammatory, and the etiology is toxic, not infectious or fungal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Epidemic dropsy is a toxicological public health emergency primarily caused by sanguinarine in adulterated mustard oil. 
  • It presents with non-inflammatory edema, affects all age groups except breastfed infants, and can have high mortality if not recognized and managed early.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman, gravida 2 para 1, presents to the obstetric clinic at 8 weeks gestation with complaints of persistent nausea and vomiting for the last 10 days. She has already tried dietary changes but symptoms have not improved. She is hemodynamically stable and her labs rule out other causes. She is diagnosed with hyperemesis gravidarum and requires pharmacological therapy. Which of the following medications is safest and most appropriate for controlling her symptoms at this stage of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Doxylamine

 

  • Use in pregnancy: First-line drug for hyperemesis gravidarum.
  • Often combined with: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6).
  • FDA classification: A (most reassuring category).
  • Evidence: Strong track record of safety and efficacy in early pregnancy.
  • First-line therapy, safe and effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metoclopramide:

 

  • Use in pregnancy: Considered second-line after doxylamine-pyridoxine combination fails.
  • FDA category: B (safe in pregnancy, but some risk of extrapyramidal symptoms with prolonged use).
  • Role: Dopamine antagonist, enhances gastric motility and has antiemetic properties.
  • Not first-line despite safety.
  • Safe, but not first-line. Used when doxylamine–pyridoxine fails.

 

Option C. Dronabinol:

 

  • Class: Cannabinoid receptor agonist.
  • Use: Chemotherapy-induced nausea.
  • Not approved in pregnancy – potential fetal neurodevelopmental effects.
  • FDA category: C (potential risks; not recommended).
  • Not safe – avoid in pregnancy.

 

Option D. Aprepitant:

 

  • Class: Neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist.
  • Use: Chemotherapy-induced or postoperative nausea.
  • Not studied extensively in pregnancy; safety data is lacking.
  • FDA category: Not established for pregnancy.
  • Not safe or recommended in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:



Doxylamine, often with pyridoxine, is the first line and safest medication for nausea and vomiting in pregnancy, especially in hyperemesis gravidarum.

questions.text: A public health team is investigating a case of zoonotic infection linked to unpasteurized milk consumption. They note that the pathogen involved is able to withstand 30 minutes of pasteurization at 63°C (Holder method). Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Coxiella burnetii

 

  • Organisms that can be transferred by unpasteurized milk are M. bovis, Brucella spp., C. burnetti.
  • 2 methods for pasteurization:
    • Holder method – 63°C for 30 mins (M.bovis and Brucella)
    • Flash method – 72°C for 20 secs and bring down to 18°C
  • Coxiella burnetii, the causative agent of Q fever, is known for its exceptional resistance to heat and is the most heat-resistant pathogen among non-spore-forming bacteria. 
  • It can survive standard batch pasteurization (63°C for 30 minutes), which is why pasteurization guidelines were revised in some regions to ensure its inactivation. 
  • The organism is typically found in livestock and can be transmitted through inhalation of aerosols or ingestion of unpasteurized dairy products.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium bovis: Though Mycobacterium bovis was historically associated with milk-borne transmission, standard pasteurization methods are effective in killing Mycobacteria.

 

Option B. Salmonella spp: These Gram-negative bacilli are heat-sensitive and are easily destroyed by pasteurization.

 

Option D. Bucella spp: They are known to cause acute Brucellosis by consumption of unpasteurized milk but is rapidly killed in the holder method of milk pasteurization. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxiella burnetii is a highly heat-resistant bacterium that can survive 30 minutes of standard batch pasteurization and is the causative agent of Q fever, often transmitted through unpasteurized dairy products or inhalation from animal waste.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man volunteers for a research study on the effects of fasting. After consuming only water for 48 hours, he is brought in for testing. He reports feeling slightly fatigued but is otherwise alert and responsive. Blood glucose is mildly decreased, ketone levels are elevated, and insulin levels are significantly suppressed. Attending endocrinologist explains that the body has shifted from using glucose to using fatty acids and ketone bodies for energy. Which of the following hormones is primarily responsible for stimulating hepatic gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis to maintain plasma glucose levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucagon

 

  • During fasting and starvation, glucagon secretion rises as insulin levels fall. Glucagon:
    • Stimulates glycogenolysis in the liver.
    • Activates gluconeogenesis from substrates like lactate, alanine, and glycerol.
  • Helps preserve blood glucose levels for the brain and red blood cells.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option B. Insulin: Insulin promotes glucose uptake and storage, which occurs in the fed state. During fasting, insulin secretion falls, allowing catabolic processes like gluconeogenesis to dominate.

 

Option C. Amylase: This is a digestive enzyme, not a hormone. It breaks down dietary starch in the gastrointestinal tract and has no role in glucose homeostasis during starvation.

 

Option D. Somatostatin: A regulatory hormone that inhibits both insulin and glucagon secretion but does not directly stimulate glucose production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glucagon is the dominant hormone during fasting.
  • It ensures blood glucose remains available for obligate glucose users like the brain and RBCs.
  • As fasting continues, the liver uses amino acids and glycerol for gluconeogenesis and produces ketone bodies from excess acetyl-CoA.

questions.text:
In which of the following scenarios would the Hardy-Weinberg law not be valid?

 

  1. A population undergoing high rates of non-random mating due to caste-based endogamy
  2. A large, randomly mating population with no selection or mutation
  3. A small, isolated tribal population with frequent inbreeding
  4. A population with high immigration of individuals from genetically diverse regions
  5. A dynamic population where certain genotypes have a survival advantage
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4 and 5 only

 

  • The Hardy-Weinberg law applies only when five strict assumptions are satisfied:
    • Large population size (to prevent genetic drift)
    • Random mating
    • No mutation
    • No migration (gene flow)
    • No natural selection

 

Correct statements:

 

Statement 1. A population undergoing high rates of non-random mating due to caste-based endogamy: 

 

  • Non-random mating (caste-based endogamy)
  • Violates the random mating assumption.
  • Leads to increased homozygosity and distortion of genotype frequencies.
  • Hardy-Weinberg is NOT valid

 

Statement 3. A small, isolated tribal population with frequent inbreeding:

 

  • Small, isolated tribal population with inbreeding
  • Violates large population size and random mating assumptions
  • Susceptible to genetic drift and increased homozygosity
  • Hardy-Weinberg is NOT valid

 

Statement 4. A population with high immigration of individuals from genetically diverse region:

 

  • High immigration from genetically diverse groups
  • Violates no migration (gene flow) assumption
  • Introduces new alleles, altering equilibrium
  • Hardy-Weinberg is NOT valid

 

Statement 5. A dynamic population where certain genotypes have a survival advantage:

 

  • Genotype-specific survival advantage (selection)
  • Violates no natural selection assumption
  • Alters allele frequencies over time
  • Hardy-Weinberg is NOT valid

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 2. Large, randomly mating population with no selection or mutation:

 

  • Meets all assumptions
  • Hardy-Weinberg is valid here
  • Should be excluded from correct options

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium provides a mathematical model to estimate allele and genotype frequencies. 
  • However, it becomes invalid if any of the following factors—mutation, selection, gene flow, non-random mating, or genetic drift—are present in the population.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with progressive cervical lymphadenopathy. He is found to be HIV-positive with a CD4 count of 42/mm³. Fungal culture of lymph node aspirate shows a characteristic colony as shown in the image. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Talaromyces marneffei

 

  • Talaromyces marneffei (formerly known as Penicillium marneffei) is a dimorphic fungus that is endemic to Southeast Asia. 
  • It causes disseminated infection in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with advanced HIV/AIDS. 
  • The mold form produces a velvety colony with a characteristic red diffusible pigment on the reverse, which is a diagnostic hallmark in culture. 
  • Infections commonly manifest as fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, skin lesions, and hepatosplenomegaly.
  • Bamboo rats are reservoirs for Talaromyces marneffei
  • On LPCB staining it will give broom stick appearance 
  • Poop → yeast cells 
  • Red Rat – Red pigment on SDA 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumocystis jirovecii: This fungus causes pneumonia in immunocompromised hosts but does not grow in culture and does not produce a red pigment. It is identified via GMS staining showing crushed ping pong ball appearance or PCR from respiratory samples.

 

Option B. Blastomyces dermatiditis: A dimorphic fungus found in North America. It grows as a mold in culture but does not produce a red pigment. It typically causes pulmonary and skin lesions showing broad based budding on histopathology samples. 

 

Option C. Cryptococcus neoformans: An encapsulated yeast, best visualized with India ink or mucicarmine stain. It causes meningitis in AIDS patients but does not form red pigment in culture and grows as mucoid white creamy colonies, not velvety.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Talaromyces marneffei causes disseminated fungal infection in immunocompromised patients and forms a velvety mold with red diffusible pigment in culture—a key diagnostic clue.

choices.text: Balloon intra-aortic counterpulsation and urgent surgery
Mitral valve repair electively after 2 weeks

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents 5 days after inferior wall MI with sudden dyspnea, hypotension, and a new systolic murmur at apex. CXR shows pulmonary edema. Echo reveals flail posterior mitral leaflet with severe MR. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Balloon intra-aortic counterpulsation and urgent surgery

 

  • Acute post-MI MR → papillary muscle rupture
  • Leads to acute heart failure and shock
  • Requires IABP for stabilization + urgent surgery
  • Medical therapy alone is inadequate

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start diuretics and IV nitrates: Temporizing, not definitive

 

Option C. ACE inhibitor and observe: Not effective in acute severe MR

 

Option D. Mitral valve repair electively after 2 weeks: Risks mortality

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary muscle rupture after MI mandates surgical correction; IABP stabilizes pre-op.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency room with confusion, vomiting, and shallow breathing after accidentally ingesting a chemical used to preserve plant seeds. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated lactate levels and metabolic acidosis. On further investigation, it is found that the chemical inhibits the flow of electrons at the cytochrome c oxidase step of the electron transport chain. Which of the following agents is the most likely cause of the child’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cyanide

 

  • Cyanide inhibits Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase), which is the final step of the ETC, where electrons are transferred to oxygen to form water. 
  • This leads to complete arrest of cellular respiration and buildup of lactate due to anaerobic metabolism — hence, metabolic acidosis.
  • When complex IV of electron transport chain is inhibited, NADH will not be utilized 
  • NADH will bind with pyruvate to form lactate so lactate level will increase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antimycin A: Inhibits Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain, which prevents the transfer of electrons from coenzyme Q to cytochrome c. While toxic, this does not block the final step of electron transfer to oxygen.

 

Option C. Rotenone: This is a Complex I inhibitor that blocks the transfer of electrons from NADH to ubiquinone (Q). Though also toxic, it does not cause such a dramatic halt to respiration as cyanide.

 

Option D. Carboxin: Inhibits Complex II (succinate dehydrogenase) It interferes with electron transfer from succinate to coenzyme Q. Less commonly used in clinical scenarios; its inhibition does not fully block oxygen utilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyanide poisoning inhibits cytochrome c oxidase (complex IV) of the mitochondrial electron transport chain, leading to blocked oxidative phosphorylation, lactic acidosis, and cellular hypoxia despite adequate oxygen availability.

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines is not involved in the Th1 (T-helper 1) immune response?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IL-4

 

  • The Th1 immune response is characterized by the activation of cell-mediated immunity, particularly against intracellular pathogens (e.g., viruses, some bacteria). 
  • The key cytokines involved in promoting and sustaining the Th1 pathway include:
    • IFN-γ (Interferon gamma): Secreted by Th1 cells; activates macrophages and promotes the Th1 lineage while inhibiting Th2.
    • IL-2: Promotes proliferation of T cells including cytotoxic T cells and NK cells.
    • IL-12: Produced by antigen-presenting cells; it drives naïve T cells toward a Th1 phenotype.
  • In contrast, IL-4 is the signature cytokine of the Th2 response. It is involved in:
    • Promoting class switching to IgE
    • Driving differentiation into Th2 cells
    • Suppressing Th1 responses

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IFN-γ: Central to Th1 activity, enhances macrophage microbicidal activity.

 

Option B. IL-2: A Th1-associated growth factor for T cells.

 

Option C. IL-12: Promotes Th1 differentiation and IFN-γ production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IL-4 is a Th2 cytokine and is not involved in Th1-mediated responses, which are instead characterized by cytokines like IFN-γ, IL-2, and IL-12.

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhibitor of the intestinal mucosal transporter NPC1L1, responsible for the absorption of dietary and biliary cholesterol?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ezetimibe

 

  • Ezetimibe is a cholesterol absorption inhibitor that specifically targets the NPC1L1 transporter in the intestinal mucosa. 
  • By inhibiting NPC1L1, ezetimibe reduces the absorption of dietary and biliary cholesterol from the small intestine, thereby lowering the total amount of cholesterol delivered to the liver. 
  • This mechanism makes ezetimibe an effective drug for lowering cholesterol levels, particularly when combined with statins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atorvastatin: Atorvastatin is a statin, which is a class of drugs used to lower cholesterol levels in the blood. Statins work by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase, an enzyme involved in the synthesis of cholesterol in the liver. While atorvastatin effectively lowers cholesterol, it does not inhibit the NPC1L1 transporter.

 

Option B. Fenofibrate: Fenofibrate is a fibrate, a class of drugs used to reduce triglycerides and increase high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol levels. Fibrates work by activating peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-alpha (PPAR-alpha) which affects lipid metabolism. Fenofibrate does not inhibit the NPC1L1 transporter.

 

Option C. Metformin: Metformin is an oral hypoglycemic agent used primarily in the management of type 2 diabetes. It works by reducing hepatic glucose production and improving insulin sensitivity. Metformin has no effect on cholesterol absorption and does not inhibit the NPC1L1 transporter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ezetimibe lowers LDL cholesterol by inhibiting the NPC1L1 transporter in the intestinal mucosa, thereby reducing absorption of dietary and biliary cholesterol.

choices.text: In vitro fertilization (IVF) and intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI)

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the fertility clinic with concerns about difficulty conceiving. Her history reveals irregular cycles, and after an evaluation, a significant decline in ovarian reserve is confirmed through hormone testing and ultrasound. What is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Donor egg

 

  • When a woman presents with a significant decline in ovarian reserve, indicated by elevated FSH levels, low AMH (anti-Müllerian hormone), or reduced antral follicle count, the best treatment option often involves the use of donor eggs. 
  • This is because women with significantly diminished ovarian reserve have lower-quality eggs, which may fail to fertilize or result in poor embryo quality, reducing the chances of successful pregnancy.
  • In such cases, donor egg IVF offers the highest success rates because it bypasses the issue of poor egg quality and directly provides high-quality eggs from a younger donor. 
  • IVF with intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) can be performed as part of this treatment to facilitate fertilization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gonadotropin ovulation induction: Gonadotropins can stimulate ovulation, but in women with significantly diminished ovarian reserve, the response to these medications is often suboptimal. The likelihood of obtaining viable eggs through gonadotropin stimulation in these women is low, and the success rates are poor compared to donor eggs.

 

Option B. In vitro fertilization (IVF) and intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI): IVF with ICSI may be used in some cases, especially in patients with male factor infertility or previous fertilization issues. However, in women with low ovarian reserve, the egg quality is often the limiting factor, making donor eggs a more successful option in such cases.

 

Option D. Clomid ovulation induction: Clomid is a first-line treatment for women with ovulatory dysfunction, but it is less effective in women with diminished ovarian reserve. Clomid works by stimulating the ovaries to produce eggs, but in women with reduced egg quantity and quality, the chances of success are much lower.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In women with significantly diminished ovarian reserve, donor egg IVF offers the best chance for successful pregnancy, bypassing the issue of poor egg quality and increasing the likelihood of a successful outcome.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy is/are incorrect? 

 

  1. It is most commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern involving MYH7 or MYBPC3 gene mutations.
  2. Histological examination reveals myocyte disarray and patchy interstitial fibrosis.
  3. The murmur intensity increases when the patient is in a squatting position.
  4. The condition often leads to exertional syncope or sudden cardiac death in young athletes.
  5. Asymmetric septal hypertrophy is the key structural abnormality that contributes to dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only statement 3 is incorrect

 

The clinical scenario and pathologic findings point to Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM). 

 

Statement 3. The murmur intensity increases when the patient is in a squatting position: Incorrect. The harsh systolic murmur in HCM increases with Valsalva or standing, which decreases preload and worsens the obstruction. In contrast, squatting increases preload, reducing the murmur’s intensity.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1. It is most commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern involving MYH7 or MYBPC3 gene mutations: Correct. HCM is an autosomal dominant disorder. The most common mutations involve β-myosin heavy chain (MYH7) or myosin-binding protein C (MYBPC3).

 

Statement 2. Histological examination reveals myocyte disarray and patchy interstitial fibrosis: Correct. Histology shows myocyte disarray (a hallmark finding) and interstitial fibrosis, contributing to arrhythmias.

 

 

Statement 4. The condition often leads to exertional syncope or sudden cardiac death in young athletes: Correct. HCM is a classic cause of sudden cardiac death (SCD) in young athletes, especially during or after exertion.

 

Statement 5. Asymmetric septal hypertrophy is the key structural abnormality that contributes to dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction: Correct. Asymmetric septal hypertrophy narrows the left ventricular outflow tract, especially during systole, leading to a dynamic obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM), murmur intensity increases with maneuvers that decrease preload (e.g., Valsalva, standing) and decreases with maneuvers that increase preload (e.g., squatting). 
  • Recognizing autosomal dominant inheritance, myocyte disarray, and sudden death risk in young athletes is essential for diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Enhances recovery of Gram-positive cocci in urine
Facilitates detection of non-lactose fermenters in stool samples
Suppresses the swarming growth of Proteus species
Specifically isolates enteric organisms causing urinary tract infections

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with dysuria and increased urinary frequency. A urine culture is ordered to identify the causative pathogen. The microbiology lab uses CLED (Cystine Lactose Electrolyte Deficient) agar instead of MacConkey agar. What is the primary reason for choosing this medium for urinary cultures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Suppresses the swarming growth of Proteus species

 

  • CLED agar is widely used in the diagnosis of urinary tract infections. 
  • Its electrolyte-deficient nature specifically inhibits the swarming motility of Proteus species, which can otherwise overgrow the plate and obscure other pathogens. 
  • It covers all the other organisms that might be important in urinary sample. To supress this swarming of the proteus, we have electrolyte deficient medium.
  • This makes it a preferred medium for urine cultures, as it ensures discrete colony growth, allowing easier identification and isolation of urinary pathogens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enhances recovery of Gram-positive cocci in urine: While CLED supports growth of both Gram-negative and some Gram-positive organisms, its main advantage over MacConkey is not selective recovery of Gram-positive cocci.

 

Option B. Facilitates detection of non-lactose fermenters in stool samples: This is a function of MacConkey agar, which differentiates lactose fermenters (LF) and non-lactose fermenters (NLF) using color change. CLED also indicates lactose fermentation but is not primarily used for stool pathogens.

 

Option D. Specifically isolates enteric organisms causing urinary tract infections: CLED is not specific to enteric organisms alone and supports a broad range of urinary pathogens. The key distinction is inhibiting Proteus swarming, not targeted isolation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CLED agar is preferred for urine cultures because it prevents the swarming of Proteus species, allowing accurate isolation and identification of urinary pathogens.

choices.text: SMAD4 is a tumor suppressor gene implicated in the TGF-β signaling pathway.
SMAD4 mutations are associated with juvenile polyposis syndrome and pancreatic carcinoma.
SMAD4 promotes angiogenesis and enhances tumor invasiveness.
SMAD4 exerts its effects primarily by inhibiting mitogenic signaling pathways.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the SMAD4 gene is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) SMAD4 promotes angiogenesis and enhances tumor invasiveness.

 

  • SMAD4 is not involved in promoting angiogenesis or enhancing tumor invasion. 
  • Instead, it acts as a tumor suppressor gene, limiting cell proliferation and preventing malignant transformation by mediating TGF-β signaling, which opposes growth and invasion in normal cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SMAD4 is a tumor suppressor gene implicated in the TGF-β signaling pathway: Correct. SMAD4 plays a central role in transducing anti-proliferative signals from TGF-β, crucial in maintaining cellular homeostasis and preventing oncogenesis.

 

Option B. SMAD4 mutations are associated with juvenile polyposis syndrome and pancreatic carcinoma: Correct. Loss-of-function mutations in SMAD4 have been implicated in both juvenile polyposis syndrome (a hereditary condition with increased polyp burden) and pancreatic and colorectal cancers.

 

Option D. SMAD4 exerts its effects primarily by inhibiting mitogenic signaling pathways: Correct. SMAD4 contributes to growth inhibition by acting downstream in the TGF-β pathway, effectively turning off cell cycle-promoting signals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • SMAD4 is a tumor suppressor gene involved in the TGF-β pathway. 
  • It inhibits mitogenic signaling and is mutated in various cancers like juvenile polyposis syndrome, pancreatic, and colorectal carcinoma. 
  • It does not promote angiogenesis or tumor invasion.

choices.text: Radical type 3 hysterectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy
Radical type 2 hysterectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman (P4L4) presents with post-coital bleeding. On examination, a 2 cm growth is observed on the cervix, which bleeds on touch. The vagina appears normal, and the parametrium is free. A biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix. What is the most appropriate management option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radical type 3 hysterectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy

 

  • This patient has been diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of cervical cancer, often caused by persistent infection with high-risk HPV types. 
  • The appropriate management for early-stage cervical cancer (stage IA2, IB1, or IIA1) involves surgical treatment.
  • For a 2 cm growth confined to the cervix (no extension into the vagina or parametrial involvement), the best approach is a radical type 3 hysterectomy, which involves removal of the uterus, cervix, the parametrial tissue, and the upper vagina along with a pelvic lymphadenectomy.
  • This surgery is appropriate in cases of early cervical cancer with no signs of advanced spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radical type 2 hysterectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy: A radical type 2 hysterectomy involves removing the uterus and cervix along with parametrial tissue, but it does not involve the removal of the upper vagina. This type of surgery is typically used in patients with less extensive disease, such as early-stage cervical cancer where the tumor has not involved the vaginal walls. However, this patient has a 2 cm cervical mass, which likely requires a type 3 hysterectomy.

 

Option C. Radical trachelectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy: A radical trachelectomy is a fertility-sparing surgery that removes the cervix but preserves the uterus, typically used for women with early-stage cervical cancer who wish to preserve fertility. This would not be the most appropriate treatment for a woman who has completed her family (P4L4) and is past childbearing age. Additionally, this surgery is generally recommended for younger women with smaller tumors (typically less than 2 cm) and not for this woman's clinical presentation.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy: Radiotherapy is a common treatment for cervical cancer, especially when the tumor is more advanced or when surgical treatment is not feasible due to comorbidities or other reasons. However, in this case, the tumor is localized with no parametrium involvement, making surgery the more appropriate treatment. Radiotherapy may be used as an adjunct after surgery, but it is not the first-line treatment in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For early-stage cervical cancer, radical type 3 hysterectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy is the gold standard treatment. 
  • It involves the removal of the uterus, cervix, upper vagina, and parametrial tissue and is appropriate for tumors like this 2 cm cervical growth that is confined to the cervix.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with newly diagnosed diffuse large B-cell lymphoma has bulky abdominal nodes and LDH >2× ULN. His creatinine is 1.8 mg/dL. Chemotherapy is to start tomorrow. What is the most appropriate prophylactic step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rasburicase

 

  • High risk of tumor lysis syndrome (TLS): Bulky tumor, high LDH, borderline renal function
  • Rasburicase preferred in high-risk TLS, as it rapidly degrades uric acid
  • Before starting chemotherapy, we need to start with prophylaxis (IV fluids + Rasburicase)
  • Allopurinol prevents formation but doesn't clear existing urate
  • Diuresis and dialysis are supportive/rescue, not prophylactic

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral allopurinol: Slower onset, for intermediate-risk or low uric acid

 

Option C. Forced alkaline diuresis: Risky, no proven benefit in TLS

 

Option D. Hemodialysis: For established TLS with severe uremia or electrolyte derangement

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rasburicase is the preferred prophylaxis in high-risk TLS before chemotherapy.

choices.text: Proton-pump inhibitor is taken with two antibiotics.
Treatment is prescribed for at least 7 days.
Treatment of Helicobacter pylori infection leads to vitamin B12 deficiency.
Patients requiring long-term NSAIDs should undergo Helicobacter pylori eradication therapy to reduce ulcer risk.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect with regards to Helicobacter pylori eradication in peptic ulcer disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Treatment of Helicobacter pylori infection leads to vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

  • This statement is incorrect. Treatment of Helicobacter pylori infection itself does not directly lead to vitamin B12 deficiency. 
  • However, chronic Helicobacter pylori infection can lead to atrophic gastritis, which may impair the absorption of vitamin B12 over time. 
  • Further PPI cause vitamin B12 deficiency when used for prolonged periods over many years. 
  • In treatment of H pylori, PPIs are indicated for one to two weeks only and this adverse effect is unlikely in such a short duration. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proton-pump inhibitor is taken with two antibiotics: This statement is correct. The standard treatment for Helicobacter pylori eradication involves a proton-pump inhibitor (PPI) combined with two antibiotics. The PPI reduces stomach acid production, enhancing the effectiveness of the antibiotics. Common antibiotic combinations include clarithromycin with amoxicillin or metronidazole.


Option B. Treatment is prescribed for at least 7 days: This statement is also correct. The duration of treatment for Helicobacter pylori eradication therapy is was 7 days earlier, although new guidelines recommend extending the treatment to 14 days to improve eradication rates.


Option D. Patients requiring long-term NSAIDs should undergo Helicobacter pylori eradication therapy to reduce ulcer risk: This statement is correct. Patients who require long-term nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are at increased risk of developing peptic ulcers. Eradicating Helicobacter pylori infection in these patients can significantly reduce the risk of ulcer development, as the bacteria contribute to mucosal damage and ulcer formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Helicobacter pylori eradication is achieved with a PPI and two antibiotics for at least 7 days (preferably 14). 
  • Treatment does not lead to vitamin B12 deficiency; instead, chronic infection may impair B12 absorption due to atrophic gastritis.

choices.text: 1 ASHA, 1 Anganwadi Worker, 1 Trained Dai

questions.text: In a maternal health outreach program, a PHC team plans to deploy community-based workers to achieve 100% antenatal care coverage in a rural district. For every 1000 population, which of the following set of personnel is most appropriately deployed as per norms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 ASHAs, 1 AWW, 1 Trained Dai

 

  • According to Indian public health norms for rural areas:
    • ASHA: 1 per 1000 population, but in high-need maternal programs, 2 per 1000 is recommended (especially under NRHM).
    • Anganwadi Worker (AWW): 1 per 400–800 → hence, 1 AWW per 1000 is acceptable.
    • Trained Dai: 1 per 1000 population in villages.
    • Health Assistant: Supervisory role, typically 1 per 30,000 in plains or 1 per 20,000 in hilly areas — not deployed per 1000.
  • Thus, Option B reflects the most accurate and norm-compliant combination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Norms & Population Coverage of Health Personnel in India

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient is undergoing Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) for chronic rhinosinusitis unresponsive to medical therapy. During the procedure, the surgeon uses the instrument shown in the image below. Which of the following instruments is most appropriately used for uncinectomy during FESS?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blakesley forceps

 

  • Blakesley forceps are specially designed instruments with a long shaft and a cup-like tip, used for precise removal of tissues during endoscopic nasal surgery. 
  • They are essential for performing uncinectomy—the removal of the uncinate process—during FESS, which helps in opening the ethmoidal infundibulum and accessing the maxillary sinus ostium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ballenger swivel knife: Used in septal surgeries, particularly for submucous resection (SMR), not endoscopic sinus work.

 

 

Option C. Killian nasal speculum: A nasal speculum used for anterior rhinoscopy, not suitable for endoscopic procedures.

 

 

Option D. Freer’s elevator: Used for elevating mucoperichondrium or mucoperiosteum, helpful in septoplasty—not specific for uncinectomy in FESS.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Blakesley forceps are a fundamental instrument in FESS used for removing the uncinate process, polyps, or other soft tissue structures under endoscopic guidance. 
  • Their angulated design enables precise maneuvering within the nasal cavity, essential for effective sinus surgery.

choices.text: Open surgical repair via transabdominal approach

questions.text: A 58-year-old male smoker is undergoing evaluation for persistent abdominal discomfort. Ultrasound reveals a 5.6 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He has normal renal function and no major comorbidities. CT angiography confirms the findings. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Open surgical repair via transabdominal approach

 

  • AAA >5.5 cm in men requires repair. 
  • Open repair is a better treatment option in young and fit patients. 
  • Endovascular aneurysmal repair (EVAR) is done in elderly and unfit patients 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endovascular aneurysmal coiling: Coiling is performed for intracranial aneurysms.

 

Option C and D. Surveillance with ultrasound every 6 months and Beta-blockers and statins only: Not appropriate at >5.5 cm in asymptomatic patients.

 

Educational Objective:
 

For asymptomatic infrarenal AAA >5.5 cm with favorable anatomy, EVAR is the preferred intervention due to lower perioperative risk.

choices.text: Obstructed hemivagina and ipsilateral renal anomaly (OHVIRA) syndrome

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with progressively worsening dysmenorrhea, which began after her menarche 9 months ago. Despite using oral analgesics and NSAIDs, she is unable to control her severe pain. Based on this presentation, which of the following congenital anomalies is most likely present?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obstructed hemivagina and ipsilateral renal anomaly (OHVIRA) syndrome

 

  • In this we have to think about obstructive anomaly that is endometriosis 
  • The patient presents with cyclic pain starting after menarche, worsening dysmenorrhea, and the inability to control the pain with typical analgesics. 
  • This suggests the possibility of congenital uterine or vaginal anomalies that obstruct menstrual flow, leading to painful accumulation of blood in the uterus or vagina (hematocolpos or hematometra).
  • Obstructed hemivagina and ipsilateral renal anomaly (OHVIRA) syndrome is a congenital abnormality where there is obstruction of one hemivagina (often associated with a transverse vaginal septum) and a concomitant ipsilateral renal anomaly (such as renal agenesis or hypoplasia). 
  • This syndrome typically manifests in adolescents with cyclic pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea due to the accumulation of menstrual blood in the obstructed hemivagina. 
  • The lack of proper drainage of menstrual flow leads to severe cramping pain and, in some cases, an inability to menstruate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mullerian agenesis: This condition, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome, involves absence of the uterus and upper two-thirds of the vagina, leading to primary amenorrhea. This does not explain painful menstruation as the patient would not be able to menstruate due to absent uterine anatomy.

 

Option B. Complete transverse vaginal septum: This condition involves the presence of a transverse vaginal septum, which can lead to cyclic pain due to obstruction of menstrual flow. However, it does not typically present with ipsilateral renal anomalies as in OHVIRA syndrome, and the presentation is not usually associated with severe dysmenorrhea alone but rather with the absence of menstruation or delayed menstruation.

 

Option D. Imperforate hymen: This is a common cause of primary amenorrhea due to vaginal obstruction. While it can lead to cyclic pelvic pain, it does not typically present with progressively worsening dysmenorrhea or renal anomalies. The pain is usually from accumulated menstrual blood in the vagina (hematocolpos), which is treated with surgical opening of the hymen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Obstructed hemivagina and ipsilateral renal anomaly (OHVIRA) syndrome presents with cyclic dysmenorrhea and painful menstrual accumulation due to obstructed vaginal flow. 
  • This condition is associated with renal anomalies, and it is important to consider in adolescent girls with severe menstrual pain despite the use of analgesics.

choices.text: Innervates the stylopharyngeus muscle to assist in swallowing
Provides taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue
Carries somatic sensory fibers from the pharynx and middle ear
May be damaged in head and neck surgery, leading to glossopharyngeal neuralgia

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function or clinical feature associated with the glossopharyngeal nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Provides taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue

 

The anterior two-thirds of the tongue receives taste sensation via the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve (CN VII), not the glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Innervates the stylopharyngeus muscle to assist in swallowing: True. The glossopharyngeal nerve provides motor innervation to the stylopharyngeus muscle, aiding in swallowing and elevating the pharynx.

 

Option C. Carries somatic sensory fibers from the pharynx and middle ear: True. It provides sensory fibers from the pharynx, posterior third of the tongue, middle ear, and visceral afferents from the carotid body and sinus.

 

Option D. May be damaged in head and neck surgery, leading to glossopharyngeal neuralgia: True. Glossopharyngeal neuralgia and nerve injury may occur during head and neck cancer treatment, surgery, or trauma, leading to pain and dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) is a mixed cranial nerve originating from the medulla. 
  • It provides motor, sensory, and special sensory innervation to structures in the oropharynx and posterior tongue. 
  • Injury results in dysphagia, reduced gag reflex, and loss of posterior taste sensation.

choices.text: Increased blood viscosity, and reduced renal blood flow
Increased plasma oncotic pressure reducing filtration fraction
Constriction of the efferent arteriole via angiotensin II
Increased renal sympathetic stimulation causing vasodilation of the afferent arteriole

questions.text: A 28-year-old male athlete is undergoing training at high altitude (4,000 meters) for a competitive event. After a week, he has polycythemia and an elevated hematocrit. However, his GFR is noted to be lower than baseline despite no signs of dehydration or hypotension. Which of the following is the most likely physiological mechanism responsible for the decreased GFR?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased blood viscosity, and reduced renal blood flow

 

  • At high altitude, at high altitudes, a decrease in GFR can be caused by hemoconcentration, increased blood viscosity, and reduced renal blood flow. 
  • Hypoxia and the resulting high altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE) and cerebral edema (HACE) can also contribute to GFR reduction. 
  • Because of hypoxia the EPO i.e. erythropoietin must be stimulated. It will go to bone marrow and stimulate the RBC production (polycythaemia) 
  • If we increase the blood viscosity, then blood flow will decrease. This will decrease the hypostatic pressure and because of that the GFR will decrease
  • ↓GFR/↓RBF is going to be filtration fraction
  • The kidney will maintain the filtration fraction at high altitude. 
  • Additionally, changes in renal metabolism and the body's response to altitude-induced changes in blood pressure and hormones can affect GFR.
  • Hypoxia causes increased ventilation and respiratory alkalosis. 
  • This leads to increased Na⁺ delivery to the macula densa due to enhanced distal tubular flow, stimulating tubuloglomerular feedback, which causes afferent arteriole constriction and a decrease in GFR to protect downstream nephron segments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased plasma oncotic pressure reducing filtration fraction: Plasma oncotic pressure would rise with dehydration, not in this well-perfused athlete. High altitude increases filtration fraction because of reduced RPF

 

Option C. Constriction of the efferent arteriole via angiotensin II: Efferent arteriolar constriction increases GFR, not decreases it.

 

Option D. Increased renal sympathetic stimulation causing vasodilation of the afferent arteriole: Renal sympathetic activity causes constriction, not dilation, of the afferent arteriole.

 

Educational Objective:


Increased distal Na⁺ delivery triggers tubuloglomerular feedback, leading to afferent arteriole constriction and a reduction in GFR to protect nephron integrity during states like high-altitude adaptation.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding acquired hemophilia are incorrect?

 

  1. Acquired hemophilia involves the formation of autoantibodies that inactivate factor VIII.
  2. Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is typically shortened due to increased bleeding tendency.
  3. A mixing study typically shows correction of the prolonged aPTT in this condition.
  4. The Bethesda assay is used to quantify inhibitors against factor VIII.
  5. The intrinsic coagulation pathway is impaired, leading to isolated aPTT prolongation.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 3

 

Statement 2. Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is typically shortened due to increased bleeding tendency: Incorrect. In acquired hemophilia, aPTT is prolonged, not shortened, because of impaired intrinsic pathway function due to factor VIII inhibition.

 

Statement 3. A mixing study typically shows correction of the prolonged aPTT in this condition: Incorrect. Mixing studies do NOT correct the prolonged aPTT in acquired hemophilia because the inhibitor remains active in the mixed plasma, inactivating the added factor VIII from normal plasma.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1. Acquired hemophilia involves the formation of autoantibodies that inactivate factor VIII: Correct. Acquired hemophilia is caused by autoantibodies directed against factor VIII, a key clotting factor in the intrinsic pathway. These antibodies neutralize its function, leading to bleeding diathesis.

 

Statement 4. The Bethesda assay is used to quantify inhibitors against factor VIII: Correct. The Bethesda assay is the confirmatory test that measures inhibitory titers against factor VIII, thereby confirming acquired hemophilia.

 

Statement 5. The intrinsic coagulation pathway is impaired, leading to isolated aPTT prolongation: Correct. Since factor VIII is part of the intrinsic pathway, its inhibition results in prolonged aPTT with normal PT, consistent with intrinsic pathway impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acquired hemophilia, autoantibodies against factor VIII lead to prolonged aPTT, failure to correct with mixing studies, and diagnosis is confirmed by the Bethesda assay.

choices.text: Decreased end-systolic pressure and increased stroke volume
Shift of the loop upward and to the right with increased end-diastolic volume
Increased end-systolic pressure with decreased end-diastolic volume
Downward shift of the loop with increased compliance

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with longstanding uncontrolled hypertension presents with exertional dyspnea. Echocardiogram shows concentric left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following changes would most likely be observed in his left ventricular pressure-volume loop?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased end-systolic pressure with decreased end-diastolic volume

 

  • There is hypertrophy that means the muscle has been hypertrophied 
  • Concentric hypertrophy decreases the luman area because the muscle has grown
  • If the luman is decreased the end systolic volume and end diastolic volume will also decrease
  • Increase in muscle mass increases the contractility which will increase the stroke volume     
  • Chronic hypertension causes increased afterload, requiring the left ventricle to generate more pressure to eject blood → increased end-systolic pressure.
  • Concentric hypertrophy leads to decreased LV compliance, resulting in lower end-diastolic volume. 
  • The PV loop shifts upward (more pressure) but narrows (less volume).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased end-systolic pressure and increased stroke volume: It should be increased systolic pressure. Seen in inotropic support (e.g. dobutamine), not hypertension.

 

Option B. Shift of the loop upward and to the right with increased end-diastolic volume: Upward shift of the loop will occur when there is increase in afterload. Right shift will occur when EDV is increased. Describes eccentric hypertrophy, not concentric.

 

Option D. Downward shift of the loop with increased compliance: Hypertrophy decreases, not increases, compliance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In chronic hypertension with concentric LV hypertrophy, pressure-volume loops show increased end-systolic pressure and decreased compliance, leading to smaller end-diastolic volumes and reduced stroke volume.

choices.text: CT angiography followed by percutaneous intervention

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with a pulsatile mass in the supraclavicular region of the neck. On physical examination, the mass is compressible and exhibits an expansile pulsation. He denies pain, fever, or trauma. What is the most appropriate next investigation to evaluate this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Doppler ultrasonography

 

  • In the setting of a pulsatile neck mass, it is essential to first rule out a vascular lesion such as a carotid artery aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation.
  • Doppler ultrasonography is the most appropriate initial, non-invasive, bedside investigation to assess blood flow, vascular anatomy, and pulsatility. 
  • It provides crucial information about the vascular nature of the lesion and helps avoid inappropriate procedures (e.g., biopsy) that could lead to life-threatening hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CT angiography followed by percutaneous intervention: This may be considered after initial Doppler USG confirms a vascular lesion and further anatomical delineation is needed. However, it is not the first-line test.

 

Option C. MR angiography of neck vessels: While it is useful and non-invasive, Doppler USG is more accessible, quicker, and serves as the preferred initial investigation for a pulsatile mass. MR angiography can follow if needed.

 

Option D. Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC): Absolutely contraindicated as an initial test in a pulsatile mass. If the lesion is vascular (e.g., aneurysm), needle biopsy can cause catastrophic bleeding. Only non-pulsatile, avascular masses should be considered for FNAC, and only after ruling out vascular involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with a pulsatile neck mass, the first investigation must rule out vascular origin. 
  • Doppler ultrasonography is the initial modality of choice because it is non-invasive, safe, and effective for evaluating vascular lesions before considering advanced imaging or intervention.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female presents with sudden-onset severe headache, photophobia, fever of 101°F, and altered sensorium. On examination, she has nuchal rigidity and papilledema. A lumbar puncture is performed, and Gram stain of the CSF is shown below. Based on the findings, which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria meningitidis

 

  • The Gram stain of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows numerous Gram-negative diplococci, which is characteristic of Neisseria meningitidis. 
  • This organism is a common cause of bacterial meningitis in young adults and adolescents. 
  • It spreads via respiratory droplets and rapidly invades the bloodstream and central nervous system, leading to meningitis and septicemia.
  • Neisseria appears as kidney-shaped diplococci and is oxidase-positive.
  • Patients with fever, headache, photophobia, nuchal rigidity, and papilledema alongside such CSF findings strongly suggest meningococcal meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Listeria monocytogenes: Typically affects neonates, elderly, or immunocompromised patients. On Gram stain, it appears as Gram-positive bacilli, not diplococci.

 

Option B. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Appears as Gram-positive lancet-shaped diplococci, and is a common cause of adult meningitis, but does not match the gram-negative diplococci morphology shown.

 

Option D. Haemophilus influenzae type B: Gram-negative coccobacilli, not diplococci. Was a common cause of pediatric meningitis before widespread vaccination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neisseria meningitidis presents as Gram-negative diplococci in CSF Gram stain and is a leading cause of bacterial meningitis in adolescents and young adults. 
  • Prompt diagnosis is critical due to rapid progression and potential for septicemia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old Rh-negative pregnant woman presents with a history of prior miscarriage. She is currently 28 weeks pregnant and is being monitored for Rh sensitization. Which of the following investigations is the most appropriate for monitoring the fetus in this situation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MCA Doppler peak systolic velocity

 

  • In an Rh-negative sensitized mother, fetal monitoring is essential to assess for hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN), which can occur due to maternal antibodies attacking fetal Rh-positive red blood cells. 
  • This condition can lead to fetal anemia, and in severe cases, hydrops fetalis.
  • If anemia is more than 1.5 mm then it is fetal anemia 
  • The Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) Doppler peak systolic velocity is the most reliable non-invasive method for assessing fetal anemia in Rh-sensitized pregnancies. 
  • Increased peak systolic velocity in the MCA is a marker of fetal anemia, as it reflects increased blood flow due to reduced oxygen-carrying capacity in anemic fetuses. 
  • This Doppler ultrasound technique is used to identify those fetuses who may require early intervention, such as intrauterine transfusion or early delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biophysical profile: A biophysical profile (BPP) combines ultrasound and fetal heart rate monitoring to assess fetal well-being and oxygenation. It is a useful tool in assessing fetal health but is not specific for detecting fetal anemia in Rh-sensitized pregnancies.

 

Option B. Fetal blood sampling: Fetal blood sampling (cordocentesis) is an invasive test used to directly measure fetal hemoglobin levels and assess for fetal anemia. While it can be useful in some cases, it is more invasive and generally not the first-line method for monitoring an Rh-sensitized fetus due to risks of procedure-related complications.

 

Option C. Amniospectometry: Amniospectrometry refers to the analysis of amniotic fluid for bilirubin levels, which can be used to assess the severity of fetal anemia in Rh-sensitized pregnancies. However, it has been largely replaced by more reliable methods such as MCA Doppler ultrasound and is less commonly used now due to its invasiveness and less accurate predictions compared to Doppler studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Rh-negative sensitized pregnancies, the MCA Doppler peak systolic velocity is the best non-invasive method for monitoring fetal anemia and assessing the need for intervention.

questions.text: A 40-year-old individual presents with slowly progressive skin lesions on the face and ears that have been present for several months. The patient denies any systemic symptoms. On physical examination, there are well-demarcated, scaly plaques on the ears and surrounding areas, with evidence of central depigmentation and perifollicular plugging. A classic Shuster's sign is also observed on clinical examination. Biopsy reveals hyperkeratosis, follicular plugging, and chronic inflammation involving the dermo-epidermal junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE)

 

  • Discoid Lupus Erythematosus is a chronic autoimmune condition limited to the skin. It is characterized by sharply demarcated, erythematous plaques with adherent scales, depigmentation, and scarring. 
  • The scalp, ears, and face are commonly affected. 
  • Shuster's sign (involvement of the ear with discoid lesions) is a hallmark finding supportive of this diagnosis. 
  • Histopathology findings such as follicular plugging and basement membrane inflammation further confirm DLE. 
  • The absence of systemic symptoms differentiates it from systemic lupus erythematosus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lupus Vulgaris: Lupus vulgaris, a cutaneous form of tuberculosis, presents as reddish-brown plaque lesions, often ulcerative, associated with granulomatous inflammation on biopsy. There is also presence of an annular block with active periphery and atrophic/scarred centre. The absence of tuberculous granulomas and other systemic signs makes lupus vulgaris unlikely in this scenario.

 

Option B. Acne Rosacea: Acne Rosacea is a chronic inflammatory condition affecting the central face, characterized by flushing, telangiectasia, and pustules. The scaly plaques and Shuster’s sign observed in this case do not align with the presentation of rosacea, which is typically devoid of scarring and follicular plugging.

 

Option C. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE): SLE often involves systemic manifestations such as fever, arthritis, renal disease, or serositis, accompanied by photosensitive rashes like the "butterfly" rash or other dermal involvement, and painless oral ulcers. The absence of systemic symptoms and the local plaque features with Shuster’s sign exclude SLE as the correct diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE) is a chronic autoimmune dermatosis characterized by sharply demarcated, scaly plaques with scarring and depigmentation, commonly affecting the face and ears. 
  • Shuster’s sign (ear involvement) is a diagnostic clinical finding unique to this condition.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the role of growth hormone (GH) and somatomedins is/are correct? 

 

  1. Growth hormone exerts most of its growth-promoting actions indirectly via somatomedins.
  2. Somatomedin C, also known as IGF-1, is the most biologically important somatomedin.
  3. The half-life of IGF-1 is short compared to GH, similar to that of unbound peptide hormones.
  4. Blood levels of IGF-1 do not correlate with GH levels due to their independent regulation.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only statements 1 and 2 are correct

 

Statement 1. Growth hormone exerts most of its growth-promoting actions indirectly via somatomedins: Correct. GH stimulates the liver to produce somatomedins, particularly IGF-1, which mediate most of GH’s growth effects.

 

Statement 2. Somatomedin C, also known as IGF-1, is the most biologically important somatomedin: Correct. Somatomedin C (IGF-1) is the most significant somatomedin responsible for skeletal and soft tissue growth.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 3. The half-life of IGF-1 is short compared to GH, similar to that of unbound peptide hormones: Incorrect. IGF-1 binds to carrier proteins in blood, giving it a long half-life (~20 hours) unlike typical peptide hormones.

 

Statement 4. Blood levels of IGF-1 do not correlate with GH levels due to their independent regulation: Incorrect. Blood levels of IGF-1 generally parallel GH levels, as GH stimulates IGF-1 production in the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth hormone stimulates the liver to produce somatomedins, mainly IGF-1 (Somatomedin C), which mediate the growth-promoting effects of GH; IGF-1 binds to carrier proteins and has a long half-life, with its blood levels reflecting GH activity.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents for evaluation after 18 months of unsuccessful attempts to conceive. Her cycles are regular, and serum hormone levels are within normal range. On further assessment, she reports chronic pelvic pain and severe dysmenorrhea. A recent laparoscopic evaluation confirmed the presence of pelvic endometriotic lesions. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her infertility?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tubal obstruction

 

  • Endometriosis is a common cause of infertility and is characterized by ectopic implantation of endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterine cavity. 
  • The most likely mechanism for infertility in women with endometriosis is tubal obstruction or distortion of the normal pelvic anatomy due to adhesions and inflammation caused by ectopic endometrial implants.
  • These anatomical distortions hinder the fimbrial capture of the ovum, impair sperm transport, and alter tubal motility, making fertilization unlikely. 
  • In more advanced stages, pelvic adhesions can physically block the fallopian tubes or immobilize the ovaries, significantly reducing the chance of natural conception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abnormalities of the endocervical mucus: Although cervical mucus plays a role in fertility by facilitating sperm transport, this is not the primary mechanism by which endometriosis leads to infertility. Cervical mucus defects are more commonly seen with cervical infections or hormonal imbalances.

 

Option B. Ovulatory dysfunction: Most women with endometriosis have normal ovulatory cycles. Ovulatory dysfunction is more typical in conditions like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) or hypothalamic amenorrhea. Endometriosis-related infertility is usually not due to anovulation.

 

Option C. Implantation defect: While endometriosis can affect endometrial receptivity and theoretically impair implantation, this is not the most likely or primary cause of infertility in affected women. The anatomical distortion of the reproductive tract remains the most significant contributor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely etiology of infertility in women with endometriosis is tubal obstruction due to adhesions or anatomical distortion from ectopic endometrial implants.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child is brought to the clinic due to a history of recurrent infections, easy bruising, and persistent lymphadenopathy. The child's parents report that the lymph nodes have been enlarged for several months and are not painful. Laboratory tests reveal anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated levels of double-negative T cells (CD3+, CD4-, CD8-) in the peripheral blood. The child has a history of autoimmune hemolytic anemia. A gene mutation analysis confirms a defect in the Fas receptor gene. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome (ALPS)

 

  • ALPS is a rare genetic disorder characterized by chronic lymphadenopathy, autoimmune cytopenias (such as anemia and thrombocytopenia), and an elevated level of double-negative T cells (CD3+, CD4-, CD8-). 
  • A key feature of ALPS is the mutation in the Fas receptor gene, which is crucial for regulating apoptosis (programmed cell death). 
  • The history of recurrent infections, easy bruising, persistent lymphadenopathy, and the specific laboratory findings in this case, including the Fas receptor gene mutation, strongly support a diagnosis of ALPS.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID): SCID is a severe immunodeficiency disorder characterized by a lack of functional T and B cells, leading to recurrent severe infections early in life. While SCID presents with recurrent infections, it typically does not feature persistent lymphadenopathy, autoimmune cytopenias, or elevated double-negative T cells as seen in ALPS.

 

Option B. Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome: Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome is an immunodeficiency characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia, and recurrent infections. While thrombocytopenia and recurrent infections are common features, Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome does not present with the specific findings of elevated double-negative T cells or Fas receptor gene mutations seen in ALPS.

 

Option D. Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD): CGD is an immunodeficiency disorder that results in recurrent bacterial and fungal infections due to a defect in phagocyte function. While it causes recurrent infections, CGD does not present with lymphadenopathy, autoimmune cytopenias, or the specific T cell abnormalities found in ALPS.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome (ALPS) is characterized by chronic lymphadenopathy, autoimmune cytopenias, and elevated levels of double-negative T cells. 
  • A mutation in the Fas receptor gene, which is involved in regulating apoptosis, is a hallmark of this disorder. 
  • The combination of these clinical and laboratory features are essential for diagnosing ALPS and helps in distinguishing it from other immunodeficiency disorders.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with generalized edema, proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. Renal biopsy shows diffuse loss of podocytes on histology. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Minimal change disease (MCD)

 

  • Minimal Change Disease (MCD) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.
  • It presents with proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and edema. 
  • Renal biopsy in MCD shows diffuse podocyte effacement on electron microscopy but appears normal on light microscopy. 
  • Corticosteroids are the treatment of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute glomerulonephritis: Incorrect. Acute glomerulonephritis presents with hematuria, hypertension, and RBC casts, not pure nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option C. Henoch-Schönlein purpura nephritis: Incorrect. Henoch-Schönlein purpura nephritis presents with hematuria and palpable purpura, not isolated nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option D. Alport syndrome: Incorrect. Alport syndrome presents with hematuria, sensorineural hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities, not nephrotic syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Minimal Change Disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, presenting with proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and diffuse podocyte effacement on electron microscopy. 
  • Steroid therapy is the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida in labor presents with repeated urges to pass urine and premature bearing down. On examination, there is infra-umbilical flattening, and the fetal heart is heard on the lateral side. What is the most likely presentation and position of the fetus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Occipito-posterior

 

  • The clinical scenario described is suggestive of an occipito-posterior (OP) presentation. 
  • In OP, the fetal occiput is directed towards the posterior part of the maternal pelvis, and the fetus is facing the mother's abdomen. 
  • This presentation often results in difficult labor due to the larger fetal diameter and impeded descent. 
  • The clinical features, such as infra-umbilical flattening (indicating fetal head engagement in the posterior pelvis) and the fetal heart sound heard laterally (suggesting the fetus is positioned sideways relative to the maternal pelvis), are consistent with occipito-posterior presentation.
  • Additionally, premature bearing down and the urge to pass urine are common in posterior presentations, as the fetal head can apply pressure to the maternal bladder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right dorso-anterior: This presentation involves the fetal back facing the mother's abdomen, but the fetal head is oriented anteriorly to the pelvis. This does not match the infra-umbilical flattening or the lateral fetal heart sounds typically associated with occipito-posterior presentations.

 

Option B. Brow: A brow presentation is a rare and abnormal fetal position where the fetal head is hyperextended, resulting in the brow (forehead) presenting first during labor. While this can cause difficulty during labor, it does not present with infra-umbilical flattening and the lateral positioning of fetal heart sounds typical of occipito-posterior presentations.

 

Option C. Knee: A knee presentation is an abnormal fetal presentation where the fetus presents with a flexed knee, but this is much less common and typically leads to a malposition or malpresentation. The clinical features in the question are more suggestive of occipito-posterior rather than a knee presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In occipito-posterior presentation, the fetal occiput is facing the mother's posterior pelvis, which can lead to prolonged or difficult labor. 
  • The classic features include infra-umbilical flattening, lateral fetal heart tones, and the urge to pass urine due to pressure on the bladder. 
  • This is an important consideration for obstetric management during labor.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with COPD and atrial fibrillation presents with acute dyspnea. He was admitted for an upper GI bleed a week ago and got discharged. He was on apixaban but discontinued in view of the upper GI bleed. SpO₂ is 88%, HR 110/min, BP 80/70 mmHg. CT pulmonary angiogram is shown below. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Catheter-directed thrombolysis

 

  • The patient is having PE 
  • PE with SBP < 90 = Massive PE
  • Systemic thrombolysis increases bleeding risk, in elderly & those with recent GI bleed. 
  • Catheter-directed thrombolysis = targeted + lower dose → safer option
  • Oral anticoagulants are not first-line in acute unstable/sick PE

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral Rivaroxaban: Not for immediate use in hemodynamic compromise.

 

Option B. IV unfractionated heparin and monitor: Insufficient in high clot burden with RV dysfunction.

 

Option C. Systemic thrombolysis: Higher bleeding risk; reserved for massive PE without risk factors or C/I. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Catheter-directed thrombolysis is optimal in patients with risk of bleeding where systemic thrombolysis is C/I or deemed risky.

questions.text: Which of the following is more characteristic of Crohn’s disease compared to ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) More risk of perianal fistulae

 

  • Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are both types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), but they have distinct characteristics and should not be considered the same. 
  • Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the mouth to the anus, and is known for causing "skip lesions," meaning areas of diseased tissue interspersed with healthy tissue.
  • Perianal fistulae: Crohn’s disease is more associated with perianal complications, including fistulae, abscesses, and fissures, due to the deeper transmural inflammation that characterizes the disease. This is in contrast to ulcerative colitis, which primarily involves the mucosa and submucosa and starts from the rectum, rarely involving perianal areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lesions are continuous: This statement is incorrect for Crohn’s disease. Continuous lesions are characteristic of ulcerative colitis. In Crohn’s disease, the inflammation is patchy, with skip lesions being typical.

 

Option C. Malignancy is more common: Malignancy is more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis, particularly colorectal cancer, due to the long-standing inflammation typically confined to the colon. Crohn’s disease has a lower risk of malignancy.

 

Option D. Often presents with hematochezia: Hematochezia, or the passage of fresh blood in the stool, is more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis. Crohn’s disease typically presents with non-bloody diarrhea, although some cases might involve blood, it is not as frequent as in ulcerative colitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crohn’s disease is characterized by a higher risk of perianal fistulae and skip lesions, in contrast to ulcerative colitis, which presents with continuous lesions and a higher risk of colorectal malignancy.

choices.text: A person with borderline personality disorder who exhibits emotional dysregulation but can still reason through a decision is not compos mentis
A person with OCD who compulsively checks locks but understands the broader implications of their actions is compos mentis
A person diagnosed with dissociative identity disorder can never be considered compos mentis because they have multiple, distinct identities

questions.text: Which of the following statements about "compos mentis" and mental illness is correct in the context of decision-making capacity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A person with OCD who compulsively checks locks but understands the broader implications of their actions is compos mentis.

 

  • “Compos mentis” is a legal term meaning “a person of sound mind,” often used to determine whether an individual has decision-making capacity in the context of consent, contracts, and legal responsibility.
  • It implies that the person:
    • Understands information relevant to a decision,
    • Appreciates consequences,
    • Can reason logically, and
    • Can communicate a choice.
  • In obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), patients may engage in repetitive compulsions but usually retain insight into the irrational nature of these behaviors. As long as they understand their actions and consequences, they are compos mentis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A person with borderline personality disorder who exhibits emotional dysregulation but can still reason through a decision is not compos mentis: Incorrect. Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) may involve emotional dysregulation and impulsivity but does not inherently impair decision-making capacity.
