If the person can reason and understand decisions, they remain compos mentis.

 

Option C. A person diagnosed with dissociative identity disorder can never be considered compos mentis because they have multiple, distinct identities: Incorrect. Dissociative Identity Disorder (DID) does not universally preclude compos mentis status. During episodes where a dominant identity retains insight and cognitive function, the person can still make informed decisions. Blanket assumptions are inaccurate.

 

Option D. Both B and C: Since statement C is incorrect, this answer is also incorrect

 

Educational Objective:

 

A diagnosis of mental illness does not automatically imply incompetency. Compos mentis refers to the capacity to understand, reason, appreciate, and communicate decisions—regardless of psychiatric diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines requires frequent modification due to ongoing changes in the target organism's surface antigens?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Influenza

 

  • The influenza virus is known for undergoing antigenic variation, specifically antigenic drift and occasionally antigenic shift. 
  • These changes occur in the virus's hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) surface proteins. 
  • As a result, immunity from previous infections or vaccinations may not provide protection against new circulating strains.
  • Due to this rapid and frequent evolution, the influenza vaccine composition must be updated annually to match the most prevalent strains predicted to circulate in the upcoming flu season. 
  • This makes influenza unique among routine vaccines in requiring such regular strain adjustments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polio: Polio vaccines (both inactivated polio vaccine [IPV] and oral polio vaccine [OPV]) are directed against stable viral serotypes. The poliovirus does not undergo frequent antigenic changes, so strain updates are not regularly needed.

 

Option B. Typhoid: The typhoid vaccine targets Salmonella typhi, which is relatively antigenically stable. Though newer conjugate formulations exist for improved immunogenicity, strain replacement or drift is not a major concern requiring annual change.

 

Option D. Diphtheria: The diphtheria toxoid vaccine targets the exotoxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae and not the bacteria itself. Since the toxoid is highly conserved, strain evolution is not a factor, and vaccine composition remains unchanged over time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Influenza virus frequently undergoes antigenic variation (drift/shift), necessitating annual reformulation of the influenza vaccine to match circulating strains.

questions.text: Which of the following branches of the right coronary artery is involved in forming the annulus of Vieussens?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right conus artery

 

  • The right conus artery is typically the first branch of the right coronary artery (RCA).
  • It forms a collateral anastomotic ring with the left conus branch of the left coronary artery around the pulmonary trunk.
  • This arterial circle is called the annulus of Vieussens and is important for collateral circulation in coronary artery disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right marginal artery: Supplies the right ventricular wall; not involved in annulus formation.

 

Option C. Posterior interventricular branch: Runs in posterior interventricular sulcus; contributes to posterior septal blood supply.

 

Option D. SA nodal artery: Supplies the sinoatrial node; arises from RCA in ~60% of people.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The annulus of Vieussens is an arterial ring formed by the conus branches of the right and left coronary arteries around the pulmonary trunk.
  • The right conus artery, a branch of the right coronary artery, plays a key role in this anastomotic loop and may provide collateral circulation in cases of proximal coronary obstruction.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with dry eyes, arthritis, and recurrent miscarriages. Lab: positive lupus anticoagulant and anticardiolipin antibody. What is the most appropriate treatment to prevent further pregnancy loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heparin with low-dose aspirin

 

  • Classic antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS): recurrent pregnancy loss + positive LA/ACL.
  • Anticoagulation is essential for preventing thrombosis/miscarriage.
  • Heparin (LMWH) + aspirin is standard in pregnant women with APS.
  • Steroids are not needed unless SLE is active.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low-dose steroids: Steroids are for active autoimmune disease—not for APS alone.

 

Option B. Warfarin: Warfarin is contraindicated in pregnancy.

 

Option D. Hydroxychloroquine: HCQ is not the primary treatment for APS-related pregnancy loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant women with antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, heparin plus low-dose aspirin is the standard preventive therapy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with persistent nasal congestion and thick post-nasal discharge. He underwent a Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) 6 years ago due to chronic rhinosinusitis. During the prior surgery, uncinectomy and maxillary ostium enlargement were performed. He has recently experienced a recurrence of symptoms, and diagnostic nasal endoscopy (DNE) reveals mucosal edema and occluded sinus ostia. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repeat surgery

 

  • This patient has signs of recurrent chronic sinusitis with blocked sinus ostia and mucosal edema despite prior surgical intervention. 
  • The obstructed drainage pathway observed on diagnostic nasal endoscopy confirms a mechanical problem. 
  • Hence, the most effective next step is repeat surgery to re-establish sinus drainage and ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macrolides for 4 months: These may offer anti-inflammatory benefits but are not sufficient when mechanical blockage is present.

 

Option C. Steroid irrigation and antihistamines: Beneficial for inflammation but ineffective if the sinus ostia are physically blocked.

 

Option D. Biological therapy: Reserved for severe nasal polyp–associated chronic rhinosinusitis, which is not described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with chronic sinusitis and anatomically blocked sinus ostia—especially after previous surgical intervention—repeat surgery is the preferred management to re-establish adequate drainage and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: A 35-year-old African American woman presents with a persistent dry cough and fatigue. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. A biopsy of mediastinal lymph nodes demonstrates non-caseating granulomas. Laboratory findings show elevated serum ACE levels. Which of the following cytokines plays a primary role in the formation of granulomas observed in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha)

 

  • The clinical scenario—featuring non-caseating granulomas, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, elevated ACE, and a demographic predisposition—strongly suggests sarcoidosis.
  • Tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) is the primary cytokine responsible for granuloma formation in sarcoidosis.
  • Activated macrophages release TNF-α, which is crucial in maintaining the granulomatous structure by recruiting and activating additional immune cells. 
  • The persistent presence of antigenic stimuli results in chronic inflammation, in which TNF-α plays a central role.
  • Biologics such as infliximab, a TNF-α inhibitor, have been employed in refractory sarcoidosis, further emphasizing TNF-α's role in disease pathogenesis.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interleukin-6 (IL-6): IL-6 is a pro-inflammatory cytokine involved in acute phase reactions and B-cell activation. While elevated in various inflammatory states, it is not primarily responsible for granuloma formation in sarcoidosis.

 

Option B. Interleukin-1 (IL-1): IL-1 contributes to systemic inflammation and fever. It may be present during granulomatous inflammation, but it does not play a direct or central role in maintaining granulomas in sarcoidosis.

 

Option D. Interleukin-12 (IL-12): IL-12 promotes Th1 differentiation and interferon-gamma production. While it may indirectly support granuloma formation, TNF-α is the principal mediator sustaining the granulomatous architecture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) is the central cytokine involved in the formation and maintenance of non-caseating granulomas in sarcoidosis.

choices.text: Class II MHC is mainly found on dendritic cells, macrophages, and B lymphocytes
Class II MHC engages helper T cells via peptide display
Class II MHC loads peptides through the endosomal processing route
Class II MHC primarily displays cytosolic proteins for immune recognition

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the immunological presentation mechanism is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Class II MHC primarily displays cytosolic proteins for immune recognition

 

  • This is false and hence the correct answer. Cytosolic (endogenous) proteins are processed via the proteasome and presented by MHC Class I, not MHC Class II.
  • Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) Class II molecules are responsible for presenting extracellular (exogenous) peptide antigens to CD4+ T helper cells. 
  • These peptides are derived from material ingested via endocytosis or phagocytosis and processed within endosomes or lysosomes—this defines the endocytic (or exogenous) pathway.
  • They are expressed on professional antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as dendritic cells, B cells, and macrophages. 
  • The correct function of MHC class II is vital for activation of CD4+ T cells, which coordinate immune responses, including cytokine release and B-cell activation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Class II MHC is mainly found on dendritic cells, macrophages, and B lymphocytes: This is true. These cells are professional APCs and constitutively express Class II MHC molecules necessary for initiating helper T cell responses.

 

Option B. Class II MHC engages helper T cells via peptide display: This is correct. CD4+ T cells interact with antigenic peptides displayed by MHC class II on the surface of APCs.

 

Option C. Class II MHC loads peptides through the endosomal processing route: This is accurate. MHC II presents antigens derived from extracellular proteins that are processed in the endocytic compartment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MHC Class II molecules present peptides derived from extracellular proteins via the endocytic pathway to CD4+ T cells and are expressed on antigen-presenting cells.

choices.text: It inhibits peripheral decarboxylation of levodopa
Selegiline prolongs dopamine action by inhibiting its breakdown
It enhances dopamine synthesis in the substantia nigra

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with Parkinson's disease experiences "wearing-off" phenomena despite optimized levodopa/carbidopa therapy. Selegiline is added to his regimen. Which of the following best describes the rationale for this addition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Selegiline prolongs dopamine action by inhibiting its breakdown

 

  • Selegiline is a selective MAO-B inhibitor at therapeutic doses. MAO-B is the primary enzyme responsible for the degradation of dopamine in the brain. 
  • By inhibiting this enzyme, selegiline increases the availability and prolongs the half-life of dopamine, enhancing and sustaining the dopaminergic effect of levodopa in the central nervous system. 
  • This is particularly helpful in managing "wearing-off" episodes in Parkinson’s disease, where the effectiveness of levodopa shortens over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selegiline directly stimulates dopamine receptors: Incorrect. Selegiline is not a dopamine agonist. Agents such as pramipexole and ropinirole directly stimulate dopamine receptors, but selegiline acts indirectly by reducing dopamine catabolism.

 

Option B. It inhibits peripheral decarboxylation of levodopa: Incorrect. This action is specific to carbidopa, which inhibits DOPA decarboxylase peripherally to reduce levodopa degradation before reaching the brain. Selegiline does not have this mechanism.

 

Option D. It enhances dopamine synthesis in the substantia nigra: Incorrect. Selegiline does not increase dopamine synthesis. Instead, it prevents its breakdown in the brain. Dopamine synthesis is regulated by tyrosine hydroxylase, not influenced by MAO-B inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selegiline is a selective MAO-B inhibitor used as adjunct therapy in Parkinson’s disease to prolong central dopamine activity by inhibiting its enzymatic breakdown, especially useful for managing "wearing-off" phenomena in patients on levodopa/carbidopa.

choices.text: Surgical intervention, including bile duct repair or reconstruction

questions.text: A 47-year-old male patient underwent emergency laparoscopic cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis. Within a few days postoperatively, he developed progressive right upper quadrant abdominal pain and jaundice. Laboratory tests show elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels. An imaging is performed as follows. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ERCP

 

  • The scenario and image (MRCP) shows filling defect in distal CBD, suggestive of a slipped CBD stone.
  • Sometimes during cholecystectomy, while handling the gall bladder, the stone slips into the CBD. It is a known complication. 
  • Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with stone removal is the preferred first-line intervention.
  • If ERCP is not possible, then surgical removal of the CBD stone is preferred. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observation and supportive care: This is inappropriate for post-cholecystectomy CBD stone.

 

Option C. Surgical intervention, including bile duct repair or reconstruction: Surgical intervention (e.g. CBD exploration) is generally reserved for large CBD stones not amenable to endoscopic therapy.

 

Option D. Pigtail drain: These have no role in CBD stone management and may worsen outcomes due to immunosuppression and risk of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CBD stones following laparoscopic cholecystectomy are best managed initially with ERCP and removal.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman undergoes a normal vaginal delivery but develops excessive uterine bleeding that does not respond adequately to uterotonics. A balloon device is inserted transvaginally into the uterine cavity to manage the ongoing postpartum hemorrhage. What is the typical volume of fluid used to inflate this device to achieve hemostasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 500 ml

 

  • In cases of atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) that are unresponsive to uterotonics, mechanical tamponade using an intrauterine balloon catheter (e.g., Bakri balloon) is a common intervention. 
  • The balloon is inflated with sterile saline or water to provide pressure against the uterine walls and tamponade bleeding vessels.
  • The typical volume instilled is 300 to 500 ml, which is sufficient to achieve adequate tamponade effect while minimizing risk of uterine injury. 
  • The fluid is introduced gradually under careful monitoring.
  • We can also use condom catheter or Sengstaken-Blakemore tube but the amount of fluid remains the same

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 100 ml: Although sometimes used as an initial inflation step, 100 ml is usually inadequate to stop significant hemorrhage and often needs to be increased up to 500 ml.

 

Option B. 1000 ml: This volume is excessive and may cause uterine rupture or trauma. It exceeds the safe inflation limit of the Bakri balloon and similar devices.

 

Option D. 50 ml: Such a low volume is insufficient for tamponade, and not clinically effective in controlling postpartum bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of postpartum hemorrhage, intrauterine balloon tamponade (e.g., Bakri balloon) is inflated with up to 500 ml of sterile fluid to achieve effective compression of the uterine walls and control bleeding.

questions.text: A 4-week-old child was brought to the emergency department with recurrent episodes of non-bilious vomiting. He was dehydrated. What should be corrected before performing surgical treatment as shown in this baby?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypokalemia

 

  • The child presents with recurrent non-bilious vomiting, which is a classic sign of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS). 
  • IHPS is a condition in infants causing severe vomiting due to the thickening of the pylorus muscle, leading to obstruction.
  • Patients with IHPS often develop a specific electrolyte imbalance characterized by hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. 
  • Before performing surgical treatment (such as a pyloromyotomy, often referenced in this context as the Ramstedt procedure), it is crucial to correct the electrolyte imbalance to stabilize the patient. 
  • The primary focus is on correcting hypokalemia because potassium is essential for normal cellular function and cardiac rhythm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: This condition involves high potassium levels, which is not typically seen in patients with IHPS. Instead, these patients usually have low potassium levels due to vomiting.

 

Option C. Hyponatremia: While hyponatremia (low sodium levels) can occur, it is generally not as significant or immediately life-threatening as hypokalemia in the context of IHPS.

 

Option D. Hypernatremia: High sodium levels are not characteristic of IHPS. The vomiting associated with IHPS more commonly leads to losses of electrolytes like potassium and chloride, not an increase in sodium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) is often associated with hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. 
  • Correction of hypokalemia is essential before surgical intervention.

questions.text: A newborn presents with weakness in the hand and forearm following a difficult breech delivery. Examination reveals deformity as shown below. There is also associated Horner's syndrome with ptosis and miosis. Which part of the brachial plexus is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lower trunk (C8-T1)

 

  • The clinical features in this neonate are characteristic of Klumpke’s palsy, a brachial plexus injury affecting the lower trunk (C8-T1). This occurs due to excessive arm abduction, such as in breech delivery with arm hyperextension or a fall where one grabs an object to prevent falling.
  • Key features:
    • Paralysis of intrinsic hand muscles (lumbricals, interossei, thenar, hypothenar muscles)
    • "Claw hand" deformity – Hyperextension at MCP joints, flexion at IP joints
    • Weakness in wrist and finger flexors
    • Associated Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis) – Due to damage to sympathetic fibers traveling with T1

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper trunk (C5-C6): Injury results in Erb-Duchenne palsy seen in shoulder dystocia during delivery. Features include "waiter's tip" deformity (adducted, internally rotated arm with extended elbow).

 

Option B. Middle trunk (C7): Rarely injured in isolation, may contribute to weakness in elbow extension and wrist flexion.

 

Option D. Posterior cord: Injury affects radial nerve, leading to wrist drop due to paralysis of extensor muscles of the forearm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Klumpke’s palsy (C8-T1 injury) occurs due to excessive arm abduction and presents with claw hand deformity and possible Horner’s syndrome due to T1 involvement.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male boxer presents with wrist pain after falling onto an outstretched hand during training. Examination reveals tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox. The physician is concerned about a fracture of the underlying bone. Which of the following bones is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Scaphoid

 

  • The anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression located on the lateral wrist.
  • Scaphoid fractures are the most common carpal bone fractures and occur due to falls onto an outstretched hand (FOOSH injury).
  • Classic finding: Tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox
  • Complication: Risk of avascular necrosis due to retrograde blood supply from the radial artery

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lunate: More commonly associated with perilunate dislocations rather than fractures.

 

Option B. Capitate: Less commonly fractured; usually involved in high-energy trauma.

 

Option D. Hamate: Typically fractured due to direct trauma (e.g., from a baseball bat or golf club).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scaphoid fractures should always be suspected in patients with wrist trauma and tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox. 
  • Due to its retrograde blood supply, scaphoid fractures carry a high risk of avascular necrosis, necessitating early diagnosis and immobilization.

 

 

 

Boundaries of Anatomical Snuffbox

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with SLE (class IV lupus nephritis) previously treated with mycophenolate now presents with hematuria, proteinuria (3.8 g/day), and S.Cr of 4.1 mg/dl (previous was 1.4). Anti-dsDNA is high and complement levels are low. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Switch to cyclophosphamide

 

  • Biochemical relapse + rising creatinine = renal flare
  • If prior MMF fails → switch to cyclophosphamide
  • Dual induction with steroids + cyclophosphamide indicated
  • Rituximab is reserved for resistant cases or intolerance

     

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulse IV methylprednisolone only: Not sufficient to induce remission

 

Option C. Continue mycophenolate at same dose: Already failed in this patient

 

Option D. Add rituximab immediately: Second-line after failure of CYC and MMF

 

Educational Objective:

 

In proliferative lupus nephritis flare after MMF failure, cyclophosphamide is the next induction option.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin

questions.text: A 63-year-old male, who received a kidney transplant 2 years ago and has been on chronic immunosuppressive therapy, presents with multiple hyperkeratotic lesions on sun-exposed areas of the skin. A biopsy of one lesion confirms malignancy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin

 

  • Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin is the most common malignancy seen in post-transplant patients due to chronic immunosuppression, particularly in sun-exposed areas, matching the presentation described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD): PTLD refers to a range of lymphoid proliferations that can occur following transplantation due to immunosuppression. However, it does not present with hyperkeratotic skin lesions.

 

Option C. Leukemia: Leukemia can occur in the post-transplant setting but would not present with localized skin lesions, but with pancytopenia and splenomegaly.

 

Option D. Kaposi’s sarcoma: Kaposi’s sarcoma can occur in transplant patients but typically presents as violaceous plaques or nodules and is less common than squamous cell carcinoma in these patients.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The most common malignancy seen post-transplant in patients on immunosuppressive therapy is squamous cell carcinoma of the skin, often occurring on sun-exposed areas.

questions.text: Which of the following toxic plant exposures can be confused with Datura based on seed appearance but does not cause anticholinergic symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Capsicum annuum

 

  • The seeds of Datura are dark brown, reniform (kidney-shaped), and can resemble the seeds of Capsicum annuum (chilli pepper). 
  • This resemblance may lead to accidental ingestion, especially by children or uninformed individuals.
  • However, the active principles differ:
    • Datura: Contains anticholinergic alkaloids (atropine, scopolamine, hyoscyamine) → anticholinergic toxidrome.

 

 

  • Capsicum annuum: Contains capsaicin, which is a local irritant but does not cause anticholinergic symptoms. It leads to burning sensations, increased secretions, and GI irritation if ingested in large amounts, but not CNS or autonomic blockade.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ricinus communis: Castor bean plant – seeds contain ricin, a potent toxalbumin that inhibits protein synthesis, causing multiorgan failure. Not anticholinergic but extremely toxic.

 

 

Option B. Abrus precatorius: Rosary pea – contains abrin, another toxalbumin similar to ricin, leading to GI symptoms, liver and kidney damage, and multiorgan failure. Again, not anticholinergic, but seeds are shiny and red with black spots (visually distinct from Datura).

 

 

Option D. Atropa belladonna: This plant is a true anticholinergic agent, containing atropine and scopolamine. It causes identical symptoms to Datura (dryness, delirium, mydriasis, urinary retention).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Datura seeds may resemble Capsicum seeds, but only Datura contains anticholinergic alkaloids. 
  • Capsicum annuum (chilli) is not toxic in the same way and does not cause anticholinergic symptoms. Always distinguish plants by both morphology and toxicological profile.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with severe ARDS is intubated on volume control. FiO₂ is 0.9, PEEP 16 cm, TV 6 mL/kg. PaO₂ remains 54 mmHg. Plateau pressure is 32 cm H₂O. What is the next best management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Initiate prone ventilation

 

  • Prone positioning improves V/Q match, recruits posterior alveoli. 
  • Indications: Proning is indicated when the PaO2/FiO2 ratio is <150 on a ventilator with FiO2 ≥ 0.6 and PEEP ≥ 5 cm H2O, despite optimized ventilatory settings.
  • It should be done for atleast 16 hrs/day and it has shown to improve oxygenation
  • Plateau pressure already high → increasing TV is unsafe
  • Pressure support not suitable for ARDS

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase tidal volume to 8 mL/kg: Increases barotrauma risk

 

Option B. Decrease PEEP: Would worsen oxygenation

 

Option D. Switch to pressure support mode: For weaning, not ARDS

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prone ventilation is next step in severe ARDS with refractory hypoxemia despite optimal PEEP.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a firm, enlarging midline neck mass over the past few months. The swelling moves up on deglutition. Her serum calcitonin levels are elevated. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medullary thyroid cancer

 

  • Goitre with elevated serum calcitonin is likely to be a Medullary thyroid cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Papillary thyroid cancer: Papillary and follicular thyroid cancers can present with neck mass but they show elevated serum Thyroglobulin.

 

Option B. Thyroglossal duct cyst: Do not show elevated Calcitonin. The neck mass can move up with deglutition but it also moves up with tongue protrusion. 

 

Option D. CA esophagus: Does not present with neck mass

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MTC is derived from parafollicular C cells and shows elevated serum calcitonin and CEA levels. 
  • Radioactive iodine is ineffective in MTC, as C cells do not take up iodine

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with prolonged fever, weight loss, and splenomegaly. A bone marrow aspirate is obtained and stained, revealing intracellular organisms within macrophages, as shown in the image. Which of the following vectors is responsible for transmitting the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sandfly

 

  • The image shows Leishmania donovani amastigotes (also called LD bodies) within macrophages, characteristic of visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar). 
  • These are intracellular, oval organisms with a nucleus and kinetoplast.
  • Transmission occurs via the female Phlebotomus sandfly, which inoculates the promastigote form into the human host. 
  • Once inside macrophages, the organism transforms into the amastigote form and multiplies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ixodes tick: Transmits Borrelia burgdorferi (Lyme disease), Babesia, and Anaplasma, not Leishmania.

 

Option B. Tsetse fly: Vector for Trypanosoma brucei, which causes African sleeping sickness, not visceral leishmaniasis.

 

Option D. Anopheles mosquito: Transmits Plasmodium species causing malaria, not Leishmania.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visceral leishmaniasis is caused by Leishmania donovani, transmitted by the sandfly, and diagnosed by identifying amastigotes in macrophages on tissue biopsy or aspirate.

questions.text: A neonate is diagnosed with congenital aganglionic megacolon, caused by absence of ganglion cells in the enteric nervous system. These ganglion cells normally arise from which of the following embryological structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neural crest cells

 

  • The enteric plexus (both Auerbach's and Meissner's) is derived from neural crest cells. 
  • These cells migrate along the gastrointestinal tract during development to form the enteric nervous system (ENS).
  • Failure of this migration, especially into the distal colon, results in aganglionic segments, as seen in Hirschsprung disease and Achalasia cardia.
  • This failure occurs due to the lack of hyaluronic acid during embryonic life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neural tube: Gives rise to the central nervous system (brain, spinal cord) and CNS glial cells (e.g., oligodendrocytes).

 

Option B. Notochord: Forms the nucleus pulposus of intervertebral discs and signals neural tube development but does not give rise to ganglia.

 

Option D. Surface ectoderm: Gives rise to epidermis and associated structures like hair, nails, and lens of the eye, not neural elements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The enteric nervous system is derived from neural crest cells. 
  • These cells migrate into the developing gut wall and form the enteric ganglia. 
  • Disruption in this migration can lead to congenital disorders like Hirschsprung disease, highlighting the clinical relevance of embryonic neural crest derivatives.

questions.text: 34-year-old man with pleural TB, confirmed by pleural fluid analysis, was started on anti-tuberculous therapy (ATT) 4 weeks ago. He now presents with fever, increased pleural effusion, and new chest pain. Imaging shows worsening pleural thickening and a new pleural nodule. Pleural fluid cultures remain sterile. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paradoxical reaction to ATT

 

  • Worsening symptoms (fever, increased pleural effusion, chest pain) and imaging findings (pleural thickening, new nodule) after 4 weeks of ATT in an immunocompetent patient suggest a paradoxical reaction.
  • Paradoxical reaction is a transient worsening of TB symptoms or lesions during treatment, due to an exaggerated immune response to dying mycobacteria, often seen in extrapulmonary TB like pleural TB.
  • Sterile cultures rule out active infection progression, supporting an inflammatory rather than infectious cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drug-resistant TB: Unlikely with sterile cultures; resistance typically shows persistent or worsening infection with positive cultures.

 

Option C. Pleural malignancy: Possible but less likely without risk factors (e.g., smoking, weight loss); timeline aligns better with a treatment reaction.

 

Option D. Superinfection with bacterial empyema: Would show purulent fluid and positive bacterial cultures, not sterile fluid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Paradoxical reactions in TB can mimic treatment failure, often occurring 2–12 weeks after starting ATT.
  • Sterile cultures and timing help differentiate from drug resistance or superinfection.
  • Management typically involves continuing ATT and adding anti-inflammatory therapy (e.g., steroids) if severe.

questions.text:
Concerning the clinical use of corticosteroids, which statements are correct?

 

  1. Inhaled corticosteroids are considered safe during pregnancy.
  2. Ciclesonide has minimum chances of causing oropharyngeal candidiasis due to its lung-specific activation.
  3. Beclomethasone alone can be used as first-line drug in acute asthma attacks.
  4. Depot steroids like triamcinolone can lead to proximal muscle weakness.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Only 1, 2 and 4



Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1. Inhaled corticosteroids are considered safe during pregnancy: These are considered safe, especially budesonide. They do not cross the placenta significantly when inhaled and do not produce systemic effects in therapeutic doses.


Statement 2. Ciclesonide has minimum chances of causing oropharyngeal candidiasis due to its lung-specific activation: Ciclesonide is a soft steroid—an inactive prodrug that is activated in the lungs. It has minimal chances of causing oropharyngeal candidiasis because the deposited steroid at these places is inactive. 


Statement 4. Depot steroids like triamcinolone can lead to proximal muscle weakness: Depot IM triamcinolone is long-acting and used in chronic inflammatory diseases but is known to cause proximal myopathy, especially in elderly or cachectic patients.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 3. Beclomethasone alone can be used as first-line drug in acute asthma attacks: Beclomethasone is an inhaled corticosteroid, but it is not used alone for acute asthma attacks because it lacks rapid bronchodilatory effects. Beta-2 agonists (e.g., formoterol) are first-line in acute settings. Beclomethasone is given in combination with these agents

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ciclesonide is a prodrug inhaled corticosteroid activated in the lungs, minimizing systemic toxicity, especially beneficial in elderly and hepatic-impaired patients. 
  • Inhaled corticosteroids are generally safe during pregnancy. 
  • Depot steroids like triamcinolone can cause proximal muscle weakness. Inhaled corticosteroids are not used alone for acute asthma attacks.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant G3P2L2 woman presents at 36 weeks of gestation. Ultrasound reveals that the fetus is in an oblique lie. The amniotic fluid is adequate, the placenta is normal, and there are no gross anomalies. She has had two previous normal vaginal deliveries. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) External cephalic version

 

  • The most appropriate management for a fetus in an oblique lie at 36 weeks of gestation is External cephalic version (ECV). 
  • In an oblique lie, the fetus is not in an ideal position for delivery (cephalic presentation), but it can still be manipulated to a cephalic position through ECV. 
  • This procedure involves applying external pressure on the mother's abdomen to turn the fetus to a head-down position. 
  • It is usually performed after 36 weeks, when the fetus has reached enough maturity for delivery, and there are no contraindications to the procedure.
  • ECV is safe and effective for turning a fetus, especially in cases like this one where the maternal pelvis is normal and there are no other contraindications such as uterine abnormalities or fetal distress. 
  • It increases the likelihood of a successful vaginal delivery and reduces the need for a cesarean section.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cesarean section: Cesarean section is generally not indicated for an oblique lie unless the fetus cannot be repositioned, or there are other complications such as fetal distress or non-reassuring fetal heart tones. A cesarean is usually reserved for cases where the fetus is not in a favorable position or if labor is progressing poorly. In this patient, external cephalic version should be attempted first.

 

Option C. Expectant management: Expectant management may be an option, but it is not the most appropriate approach in the case of an oblique lie. Waiting without intervention increases the risk of the fetus remaining in an abnormal position, which could complicate labor and delivery. This patient should be offered an attempt at external cephalic version.

 

Option D. Induction of labor: Induction of labor is not indicated for a fetus in an oblique lie because the fetus is not in the proper position for delivery. Induction should not be attempted until the fetus is in a favorable presentation (such as cephalic) to prevent complications such as cord prolapse or obstructed labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best management for a fetus in an oblique lie at 36 weeks is external cephalic version (ECV), which attempts to turn the fetus to a cephalic presentation for vaginal delivery.

questions.text: Atropine is contraindicated in the treatment of which of the following mushroom poisonings due to potential exacerbation of symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amanita muscaria

 

  • Amanita muscaria (fly agaric) contains ibotenic acid (a glutamate analog) and muscimol (a GABA-A agonist), which act primarily on the central nervous system.
  • Symptoms include confusion, seizures, hallucinations, CNS depression, and delirium.
  • Amanita muscaria causes delayed mushroom poisoning with symptoms similar to anti-cholinergic drugs.
  • Atropine is contraindicated in Amanita muscaria poisoning because it can worsen CNS symptoms, including delirium, agitation, and seizures due to central anticholinergic toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inocybe species: Contains muscarine, a potent muscarinic agonist, causing cholinergic excess (SLUDGE symptoms: salivation, lacrimation, urination, diarrhea, GI cramps, emesis).
Atropine is the treatment of choice as it antagonizes muscarinic receptors.
 

Option C. Clitocybe dealbata: Another muscarine-containing mushroom, with a similar presentation and management as Inocybe.
Atropine is indicated.
 

Option D. Galerina marginata: Contains amatoxins, which inhibit RNA polymerase II, leading to delayed hepatotoxicity.
Atropine is not helpful, but it is not contraindicated either. Management includes supportive care, activated charcoal, and silibinin or thiotic acid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Atropine is effective for mushroom poisoning caused by muscarinic agonists like Inocybe and Clitocybe species. 
  • However, it is contraindicated in CNS-active mushroom toxins such as Amanita muscaria, which may lead to worsened neurological symptoms.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents with a gradually enlarging, non-tender mass in the anterior neck. A fine-needle aspiration of the lesion reveals papillary formations with optically clear ground-glass nuclei and longitudinal nuclear grooves. Immunohistochemistry is positive for thyroglobulin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Papillary thyroid carcinoma

 

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is the most common thyroid malignancy and typically presents as a painless neck mass. Classic cytological features on fine-needle aspiration include:
    • Papillary architecture
    • Ground-glass (“Orphan Annie eye”) nuclei
    • Nuclear grooves
    • Intranuclear pseudoinclusions (occasionally seen)
    • Positive thyroglobulin immunostaining, confirming origin from thyroid follicular cells
  • These findings are diagnostic of PTC.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma: Typically presents in older individuals with rapidly enlarging neck mass and compressive symptoms. Cytology shows pleomorphic giant cells, not papillary structures or nuclear grooves, and thyroglobulin is usually negative.

 

Option B. Hurthle cell neoplasm: A subtype of follicular thyroid neoplasm composed of eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm-rich Hurthle cells. It lacks the nuclear features seen in PTC and may or may not express thyroglobulin, depending on differentiation.

 

Option D. Medullary thyroid carcinoma: Arises from parafollicular C cells and secretes calcitonin, not thyroglobulin. Histology shows amyloid stroma and polygonal/spindle-shaped cells, not papillary formations or ground-glass nuclei.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma is identified by papillary architecture, ground-glass nuclei, and nuclear grooves on cytology. 
  • Positive thyroglobulin staining confirms its follicular epithelial origin and distinguishes it from other thyroid neoplasms such as medullary carcinoma.

choices.text: Insight and reality testing are relatively intact
It includes transient psychotic symptoms that last at least once per week for 1 month
It is a formal diagnostic category in ICD-11
It may progress to full-blown psychosis in some individuals

questions.text: All of the following are true about Attenuated Psychosis Syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is a formal diagnostic category in ICD-11

 

  • False. ICD-11 does not recognize APS as a formal diagnostic category. While DSM-5 includes it in Section III (conditions for further study), it remains non-diagnostic in both systems for routine clinical use.
  • Attenuated Psychosis Syndrome (APS) refers to a clinical condition characterized by subthreshold or early symptoms of psychosis, with intact reality testing and insight, but with the potential to progress to a full psychotic disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insight and reality testing are relatively intact:True. Individuals with APS usually retain partial insight and do not exhibit grossly impaired reality testing, unlike full psychosis.

 

Option B. It includes transient psychotic symptoms that last at least once per week for 1 month: True. The DSM-5 criteria for APS (section III) specify mild psychotic symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations) occurring at least once per week for the past month.

 

Option D. It may progress to full-blown psychosis in some individuals: True. APS is considered a risk syndrome — studies show that 20–35% of such individuals may convert to full psychosis within a few years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Attenuated Psychosis Syndrome (APS) is characterized by subthreshold psychotic symptoms with retained insight and intact reality testing. 
  • It includes transient symptoms occurring at least once per week for over a month and may progress to full psychosis in some individuals. 
  • APS is not a formal diagnosis in ICD-11. Early recognition allows close monitoring and preventive strategies.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with AKI from rhabdomyolysis has pH 7.08, HCO₃⁻ 11, PaCO₂ 28 mmHg, serum K⁺ 6.7 mEq/L. Despite IV calcium, IV bicarbonate and insulin-dextrose, K⁺ remains high and pH worsens. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemodialysis
 

  • Severe metabolic acidosis with hyperkalemia not responding to medical therapy
  • Rhabdomyolysis = persistent potassium release
  • Dialysis indicated for refractory acidosis and K⁺ >6.5 despite therapy
  • Calcium is only membrane-stabilizer, not definitive
  • Diuretics and resin too slow
  • Indications for haemodialysis – AEIOU
    • Acidosis
    • Electrolyte imbalance 
    • Intoxication
    • Overload
    • Uremia. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Loop diuretics: May be ineffective in AKI

 

Option B. Sodium polystyrene sulfonate: Delayed action, unreliable in emergency

 

Option D. Repeat IV Calcium Gluconate: Unlikely to be effective since already given

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dialysis is essential in life-threatening acidosis and hyperkalemia unresponsive to medical therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with HIV develops central obesity, dorsocervical fat pad, and insulin resistance after several months of antiretroviral therapy. Which of the following drugs is least likely to cause this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atazanavir

 

  • Most protease inhibitors (PIs) are associated with lipodystrophy syndrome, which includes fat redistribution, insulin resistance, and dyslipidemia.
  • Atazanavir is unique among PIs because it is not associated with lipodystrophy or significant lipid disturbances, making it a preferred agent in patients at risk of metabolic complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lopinavir: Strongly associated with dyslipidemia and insulin resistance, especially when boosted with ritonavir.

 

Option B. Indinavir: Known to cause lipodystrophy and also causes nephrolithiasis and asymptomatic hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Option D. Saquinavir: Though considered metabolically safer than some PIs, it still carries a risk of lipid abnormalities and is not preferred over atazanavir for metabolic tolerance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atazanavir is a protease inhibitor with a lower risk of lipodystrophy, dyslipidemia, and insulin resistance compared to other PIs, making it a favorable option in HIV patients with metabolic concerns.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman undergoes an abdominal CT scan as part of the evaluation for vague right upper quadrant pain. She has no history of hepatitis, cirrhosis, or oral contraceptive use. The imaging is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH)

 

  • Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is a benign hepatic lesion most commonly seen in young women. 
  • On contrast-enhanced CT imaging, it typically appears as:
    • A well-circumscribed lesion
    • Often hypervascular in the arterial phase
    • Characterized by a central stellate scar that enhances on delayed contrast phases
  • FNH is often asymptomatic, discovered incidentally, and has no malignant potential. It is not associated with oral contraceptive use (unlike hepatic adenoma), and biopsy is generally avoided unless imaging is inconclusive.
  • On performing a Tc99 sulfur colloid scan, FNH shows a hotspot due to the presence of kupffer cells. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatic adenoma: Also a benign lesion often found in women, especially those using oral contraceptives. It does not have a central scar and can hemorrhage or transform into HCC.

 

Option C. Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC): Typically arises in a background of cirrhosis, shows arterial enhancement with rapid washout in the portal venous phase. Rarely shows a central scar.

 

Option D. Hemangioma: The most common benign liver tumor, shows peripheral nodular enhancement with progressive centripetal fill-in on contrast imaging—not a central scar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Focal nodular hyperplasia is a benign hepatic lesion characterized by a central scar with delayed enhancement on imaging. 
  • It is important to differentiate it from other hepatic masses to avoid unnecessary intervention.

choices.text: Start mexiletine and discontinue ICD therapy

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with ischemic cardiomyopathy and ICD placement presents with 4 ICD shocks over 12 hours. ECG shows sinus rhythm, K⁺ 4.2, Mg²⁺ 2.0. Device interrogation confirms recurrent VT episodes, each terminated by shock. BP 110/70 mmHg. What is the best next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ICD reprogramming and beta-blocker initiation

 

  • Multiple (≥3) VT episodes in 24 hours = electrical storm
  • Initial management = Beta-blocker (e.g., propranolol or metoprolol) and ICD reprogramming (to raise detection threshold or delay shocks)
  • Lidocaine/amiodarone if unstable
  • Ablation = second line after stabilization

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV lidocaine and amiodarone: Not first step in stable patient

 

Option C. Urgent catheter ablation: Done for recurrence despite medical therapy

 

Option D. Start mexiletine and discontinue ICD therapy: Contraindicated; life-saving shocks occurring

 

Educational Objective:

 

Electrical storm requires ICD reprogramming and beta-blockers as first-line in stable patients.

questions.text: A 36-year-old physically active woman underwent a laparoscopic transabdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) mesh repair for a left-sided inguinal hernia. Her early postoperative course was uneventful, and the surgical wounds healed well.  Examination revealed a well-healed surgical site with no signs of infection, fluid collection, or mesh displacement on imaging. Which of the following is the most common complication following inguinal hernia repair?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chronic pain

 

  • Chronic pain is the most common complication after inguinal hernia repair, affecting up to 30% of patients, especially younger individuals or those with higher physical activity. 
  • It is often due to nerve entrapment, mesh-related inflammation, or scar formation. 
  • Pain can be neuropathic and may require pharmacological management (e.g. NSAIDs, gabapentinoids), nerve blocks, and physiotherapy. 
  • This pain persists for > 3 months. 
  • Rarely, mesh removal or nerve resection may be needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wound infection: Incorrect. Wound infections can occur but are relatively uncommon in clean elective surgeries like laparoscopic TAPP, especially when prophylactic antibiotics are used.

 

Option B. Seroma formation: Incorrect. Seromas are fluid collections that may occur early postoperatively but are usually transient and resolve with observation or needle aspiration.

 

Option C. Hematoma: Incorrect. Hematomas are less common with laparoscopic approaches and are typically managed conservatively or by drainage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic post-herniorrhaphy pain is the most frequent long-term complication of inguinal hernia repair, often related to nerve involvement or mesh-related issues, and may require a multidisciplinary approach for management.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has short stature, webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, cryptorchidism, and pulmonary valve stenosis. Karyotype is 46,XY. Intelligence is mildly affected. Which gene mutation is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PTPN11 gene

 

  • Most common gene mutated in Noonan syndrome (autosomal dominant).
  • Key features: Short stature, webbed neck, pulmonary stenosis, cryptorchidism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SHOX gene mutation: Incorrect. Seen in Turner syndrome and Léri-Weill dyschondrosteosis, not Noonan.

 

Option B. FMR1 gene: Incorrect. Seen in Fragile X syndrome – features intellectual disability, long face, macroorchidism, autism traits.

 

Option D. TSC1 gene: Incorrect. Tuberous sclerosis complex - Ash leaf spots, seizures, cortical tubers – different presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Noonan syndrome is a phenotypic mimic of Turner syndrome in males with a distinct genetic etiology — PTPN11 mutation.

questions.text: A newborn is evaluated for recurrent respiratory tract infections. Laboratory analysis shows a deficiency in the immunoglobulin class that is primarily responsible for mucosal immunity. The image below illustrates the structure of the deficient antibody. Based on the structural features, which class of immunoglobulin is most likely shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IgA

 

  • The image demonstrates a dimeric antibody structure with a J chain (joining chain) and a secretory component, which are classic features of secretory IgA (sIgA). 
  • IgA is the principal immunoglobulin involved in mucosal immunity and is found in secretions such as saliva, tears, colostrum, and mucosal surfaces of the gastrointestinal and respiratory tracts. 
  • The secretory component, derived from the polymeric immunoglobulin receptor (pIgR), protects the IgA dimer from enzymatic degradation in secretions, making it essential for defending mucosal surfaces.
  • IgA can be of two type – dimeric and monomeric. Monomeric present as single antibody. Dimeric happens in secretory phase i.e when it is trying to provide mucosal immunity 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgE: IgE is a monomer that plays a role in allergic reactions and parasite defense by binding to Fc receptors on mast cells and basophils. It does not contain a J chain or secretory component.

 

Option B. IgG: IgG is the most abundant immunoglobulin in serum, and it crosses the placenta. It exists as a monomer and lacks both the J chain and secretory component.

 

Option D. IgM: IgM is a pentamer in its secreted form and contains a J chain, but it lacks the secretory component found in IgA. It is the first antibody produced in the primary immune response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretory IgA is a dimer linked by a J chain and a secretory component, enabling it to function effectively at mucosal surfaces where it resists enzymatic degradation and provides localized immunity.

questions.text: A patient from Southeast Asia presents with chronic limb swelling and lymphatic dysfunction. Peripheral blood smear demonstrates sheathed microfilariae with two distinct nuclei at the tail tip. Which of the following organisms is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brugia malayi

 

  • Brugia malayi is a filarial nematode that causes lymphatic filariasis, particularly in Southeast Asia. 
  • The microfilariae of B. malayi are sheathed and are distinguished microscopically by the presence of two discrete nuclei at the tail tip, which is a key diagnostic feature. 
  • 4 – 5 nuclei in the tail region and two widely spaced nuclei in tail up 
  • The infection leads to lymphatic obstruction, resulting in chronic lymphedema and elephantiasis, similar to Wuchereria bancrofti but with distinct geographic and morphological characteristics.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Onchocerca volvulus: Causes River blindness and dermatitis; its microfilariae are unsheathed, and they reside in skin snips, not in peripheral blood.

 

Option B. Wuchereria bancrofti: Also causes lymphatic filariasis and has sheathed microfilariae but lacks terminal nuclei at the tail tip—this is how it is distinguished from Brugia malayi.

 

Option D. Loa loa: Causes Calabar swellings and subconjunctival migration, and its microfilariae are sheathed with continuous nuclei till the tail tip.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brugia malayi is identified by sheathed microfilariae with two distinct nuclei at the tail tip, a key feature distinguishing it from other filarial parasites.

questions.text: A randomized controlled trial evaluates a new antihypertensive drug. Systolic blood pressure (SBP) was measured in 625 patients after 4 weeks of therapy. The mean SBP was 132 mmHg, and the standard deviation was 12 mmHg. What is the 95% confidence interval for the population mean systolic blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 131 to 133 mmHg

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When estimating the population mean from a sample, the 95% confidence interval is calculated as:

 

 

  • Larger sample sizes yield narrower confidence intervals, increasing precision.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with complaints of being excessively concerned with a minor nose deformity, seeking repeated cosmetic consultations despite normal findings. She is preoccupied and distressed. What is the best pharmacological management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fluoxetine

 

  • This patient’s symptoms are characteristic of Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD) — a psychiatric condition where a person is excessively preoccupied with perceived flaws in appearance, often minor or non-existent to others. 
  • She is distressed and seeking repeated cosmetic procedures despite reassurances.
  • First-line pharmacological treatment for BDD includes Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs), with fluoxetine being a commonly used and effective option. 
  • SSRIs help reduce obsessive thoughts and compulsive behaviors associated with BDD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Olanzapine: An atypical antipsychotic, not first-line for BDD. It may be considered adjunctively, but not as monotherapy.

 

Option B. Clomipramine: A tricyclic antidepressant with strong serotonergic action; effective for OCD but less preferred than SSRIs due to side-effect profile.

 

Option D. Buspirone: Used for generalized anxiety disorder, not effective for obsessive or body image preoccupations like those seen in BDD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, is the pharmacological treatment of choice for Body Dysmorphic Disorder, reducing obsessive preoccupations and distress over imagined or exaggerated defects.

questions.text: Which of the following Dural venous sinuses receives the great cerebral vein of Galen as its tributary?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

  • The venous sinus marked with 'B' in the given image is the straight sinus. 
  • The great cerebral vein of Galen drains into the straight sinus.

 

 

  • The great cerebral vein of Galen drains deep cerebral structures and empties into the straight sinus, which then flows into the confluence of sinuses. 
  • Thrombosis of the straight sinus can lead to intracranial hypertension, venous infarcts, and deep brain swelling due to impaired venous drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior sagittal sinus: This sinus runs along the midline and receives blood from superficial cortical veins. Thrombosis typically presents with seizures and parasagittal cortical infarcts rather than deep cerebral swelling.

 

Option C. Transverse sinus: Drains blood from the confluence of sinuses into the sigmoid sinus. Thrombosis results in mastoid region pain and increased intracranial pressure but does not directly receive the vein of Galen.

 

Option D. Cavernous sinus: This sinus receives drainage from the face and orbit via the ophthalmic veins. Thrombosis leads to cranial nerve palsies (CN III, IV, V1, V2, VI) and proptosis, but it does not receive the great cerebral vein of Galen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The great cerebral vein of Galen drains into the straight sinus, which is a key venous structure in deep cerebral circulation. 
  • Thrombosis of the straight sinus can lead to deep cerebral venous congestion and increased intracranial pressure.

questions.text: Identify the investigation from the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hysterosalpingography

 

  • This is an image of a Hysterosalpingogram (HSG)
  • An HSG is used to
    • Delineate uterine anomalies.
    • Endometrial cavity lesions like polyps, adhesions
    • Tubal patency in infertility
  • Anomaly shown here is unicornuate uterus 
     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysteroscopy: Incorrect. Hysteroscopy is a direct visual examination of the uterine cavity using an endoscope. It is not a radiographic study and does not use contrast or fluoroscopy.

 

 

Option B. Saline infusion sonography: Incorrect. This ultrasound-based technique uses sterile saline infusion into the uterine cavity to assess endometrial pathology and uterine contour. It is not an X-ray image and does not appear as the image shown.

 

 

Option D. Transvaginal ultrasonography: Incorrect. Transvaginal ultrasound uses sound waves to create images of pelvic organs. It is commonly used in early pregnancy and gynecological evaluations but does not involve contrast media or fluoroscopy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a fluoroscopic radiographic procedure used to evaluate the shape of the uterine cavity and the patency of the fallopian tubes by injecting contrast media. 
  • It is commonly performed in the workup of female infertility and recurrent pregnancy loss.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child weighing 12 kg is brought to the emergency department with a history of diarrhea and vomiting for the past two days. The child is irritable, thirsty, and shows a delayed skin turgor recoil of less than 2 seconds. Capillary refill is slightly prolonged, and the child’s heart rate is slightly increased. Calculate the total amount of Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) that should be given to this child.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 900 mL

 

For mild to moderate dehydration as per Plan B guidelines, the recommended ORS dosage is 75 mL/kg. Since the child weighs 12 kg:

 

  • ORS required = 75 mL/kg × 12 kg = 900 mL

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • For mild to moderate dehydration as per Plan B guidelines, the recommended ORS dosage is 75 mL/kg.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with persistent fever, weight loss, and a new diastolic murmur is suspected to have infective endocarditis. Blood cultures after 72 hours are negative. TTE shows vegetation on the aortic valve. Patient denies exposure to antibiotics prior to hospitalization. What is the best next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Order Brucella and Coxiella serology
 

  • Culture-negative endocarditis: suspect fastidious organisms (Coxiella, Bartonella, Brucella)
  • Serologies help identify these
  • Empiric treatment can follow but diagnosis is critical
  • Surgery not first step unless heart failure/abscess

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Empiric ceftriaxone + gentamicin: For streptococci; incomplete empiric therapy

 

Option B. Start vancomycin + ceftriaxone + doxycycline: Should follow focused diagnostic workup

 

Option D. Schedule valve replacement surgery: Only if refractory symptoms or valve dysfunction

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serologic testing for fastidious organisms is crucial in culture-negative endocarditis.

questions.text: A clinician is evaluating a diagnostic test for its ability to confidently exclude a disease when the test result is negative. Which of the following test characteristics best reflects the likelihood that a negative result truly indicates absence of disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Negative Predictive Value

 

  • Negative Predictive Value (NPV) is the proportion of individuals with a negative test result who are truly disease-free.
  • It is the diagnostic power of the screening test to correctly exclude the disease.
  • It directly answers the clinical question:

"If a patient tests negative, what is the chance they truly do not have the disease?"

  • NPV is especially important when a clinician wants to exclude a diagnosis based on a negative test result.
  • NPV is calculated as:

 

 

Key Point:

 

  • NPV is highly influenced by disease prevalence:
    • In low-prevalence populations, NPV is higher (more likely a negative result is truly negative).
    • In high-prevalence settings, NPV is lower.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensitivity: Gives the usefulness of the screening tests. It measures the proportion of actual positives correctly identified (true positives). High sensitivity is useful to rule out disease when the test is negative (SnNOut), but it does not directly measure the predictive value of a negative test result in a real population.

 

Option B. Specificity: Refers to the ability of the test to correctly identify true negatives. High specificity means fewer false positives, and it is more helpful when interpreting positive results, especially in the SpPIn principle (specificity, positive test rules in disease). It is not the same as NPV.

 

Option C. Positive Predictive Value (PPV): It is the diagnostic power of a screening test. It represents the probability that a positive test result indicates actual disease. Like NPV, it also depends on prevalence, but PPV is relevant to positive results, not exclusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Negative Predictive Value (NPV) quantifies the probability that a negative test result truly indicates absence of disease.
  • It is a key metric for clinicians relying on negative test results to rule out disease, especially in low-prevalence settings.

choices.text: Administer tocolytics and deliver at 37 weeks
Administer antihypertensives, magnesium sulfate, and proceed with delivery
Give steroid cover and delay delivery until steroid cover is complete

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman at 35 weeks and 5 days gestation presents to the labor and delivery unit with severe epigastric pain, headache, and blurred vision. Her blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg. She is having regular contractions, and on examination, her cervix is 3 cm dilated with intact membranes. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer antihypertensives, magnesium sulfate, and proceed with delivery

 

  • This patient presents with symptoms consistent with severe preeclampsia, including severe hypertension (170/110 mmHg), epigastric pain, headache, and blurred vision—all of which are signs of end-organ damage. 
  • In the late preterm period (between 34 and 37 weeks), the management of severe preeclampsia includes the administration of antihypertensive therapy, magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis, and delivery.
  • Given the patient is already experiencing contractions and her cervix is 3 cm dilated, delivery is the most appropriate next step to prevent further maternal and fetal complications, including eclampsia and placental abruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer tocolytics and deliver at 37 weeks: Tocolytics are used to suppress preterm labor and delay delivery, but this patient has severe preeclampsia with concerning symptoms indicating maternal and fetal risk. There is no indication for tocolysis, as immediate delivery is needed for the health of both the mother and fetus.

 

Option B. Conservative management and continue observation: Given the severity of her symptoms (e.g., high blood pressure, headache, blurred vision, and epigastric pain), observation alone is not sufficient. Severe preeclampsia requires active management to prevent progression to eclampsia, placental abruption, or fetal distress.

 

Option D. Give steroid cover and delay delivery until steroid cover is complete: Steroid therapy is typically given for fetal lung maturity in cases of preterm labor; however, this patient has severe preeclampsia, and immediate delivery is the best course of action rather than delaying delivery for steroids. The risks of severe preeclampsia outweigh the benefits of waiting for steroid cover to be completed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Severe preeclampsia at 35 weeks gestation requires delivery and immediate management, including antihypertensives, magnesium sulfate for seizure prevention, and close monitoring. 
  • Tocolytics and delaying delivery are not appropriate in cases of severe preeclampsia with maternal and fetal risks.

questions.text: During a drug trial, a novel antagonist is observed to reduce the maximum response of an agonist without significantly altering its EC50. Which of the following best describes the type of pharmacologic interaction and the corresponding dose-response curve?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Noncompetitive antagonism; curve C

 

  • In the dose-response graph:
    • Curve A represents the agonist alone (full efficacy and normal potency).
    • Curve B represents the agonist in the presence of a competitive antagonist, which causes a rightward shift (↓ potency) but the same maximum effect (no change in efficacy).
    • Curve C represents the agonist in the presence of a noncompetitive antagonist, which causes a decrease in the maximal effect (↓ efficacy) while the EC50 (potency) remains relatively unchanged.
  • In this case, the novel antagonist is reducing the maximum effect without shifting the curve significantly to the right → this is classic for noncompetitive antagonism, often due to irreversible receptor binding or allosteric inhibition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Partial agonism; curve B: Incorrect. Partial agonists produce submaximal response even at full receptor occupancy, but their curves typically lie below full agonists without necessarily mimicking the effect of a competitive antagonist (which shifts the curve rightward).

 

Option C. Receptor downregulation; curve A: Incorrect. Curve A is the reference (agonist alone), not an altered state. Receptor downregulation would reduce efficacy and mimic noncompetitive antagonism, but that’s not shown by curve A.

 

Option D. Competitive antagonism; curve B: Incorrect. Competitive antagonism increases EC50 (right shift) without reducing maximum efficacy — opposite of what’s described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Noncompetitive antagonists bind irreversibly or allosterically to receptors, reducing the efficacy of agonists without changing the EC50 significantly. 
  • In contrast, competitive antagonists shift the dose-response curve rightward (↓ potency) but preserve maximal efficacy.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male is brought to the Emergency Room by friends due to drowsiness, slurred speech, and ataxia after attending a party. His vital signs are stable, and pupils are normal. Suspecting benzodiazepine overdose, the emergency physician administers flumazenil, a benzodiazepine antagonist. Soon after, the patient becomes agitated and develops generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Which of the following substances was the patient most likely taking?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Barbiturate

 

  • Barbiturates (e.g., phenobarbital) do not act at the benzodiazepine site on GABA-A receptors.
  • Flumazenil has no antagonistic effect on barbiturates, but if given mistakenly, it can unmask underlying proconvulsant activity or precipitate withdrawal seizures if patient was chronically using sedatives.
  • Flumazenil is contraindicated in suspected barbiturate or mixed overdoses for this reason.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diazepam:

 

  • A long-acting benzodiazepine that acts on GABA-A receptors.
  • Flumazenil is a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine binding site and would reverse its effects.
  • Seizures after flumazenil administration are uncommon if the patient had only taken diazepam.
  • Incorrect – seizures unlikely if only diazepam was involved.

 

Option B. Alprazolam:

 

  • A short-acting benzodiazepine.
  • Flumazenil can reverse its sedation.

 

Option D. Zaleplon:

 

  • A non-benzodiazepine hypnotic ("Z-drug") acting on benzodiazepine-1 (BZ1) subunit of GABA-A.
  • Flumazenil does work as an antidote to Z-drug overdose.
  • Seizures are not a typical reaction to flumazenil unless chronic use or mixed ingestion exists.
  • Incorrect – unlikely to cause seizures after flumazenil.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

Flumazenil is contraindicated in patients with unknown sedative overdose or chronic sedative use because it can precipitate withdrawal seizures, especially in barbiturate or mixed drug ingestion.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy that has persisted for two months. A lymph node biopsy is given below. Immunohistochemical staining is positive for CD15 and CD30. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nodular sclerosis Hodgkin lymphoma

 

  • The most likely diagnosis is nodular sclerosis Hodgkin lymphoma (NSHL), based on both clinical and pathological features provided in the question.
  • Patient profile: A 23-year-old woman with painless cervical lymphadenopathy fits the demographic and presentation of NSHL, which is the most frequent type of Hodgkin Disease (HD) and occurs more commonly in women than in men.
  • Histopathology image: The image reveals numerous large cells with clear pericellular spaces, consistent with lacunar type Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells, which are a defining feature of nodular sclerosis HD.
  • Lymph node features: Although not explicitly described in this variation of the question, the diagnosis is tied to earlier knowledge that NSHL is characterised by bands of collagen dividing the lymph node into nodules.
  • Immunophenotyping: The Reed-Sternberg cells in classical HL subtypes, including nodular sclerosis, typically express CD15 and CD30, which is explicitly stated in the question.
  • All these findings (young woman, painless lymphadenopathy, characteristic RS cells with lacunar features, and CD15/CD30 positivity) together confirm the diagnosis of nodular sclerosis Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma: This subtype is not the most frequent type of HD and typically presents with popcorn cells (lymphocytic and histiocytic or L&H cells), not lacunar RS cells. It also does not stain positive for CD15 and CD30, but instead expresses CD20. The biopsy and immunophenotype in this case do not support this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Mixed cellularity Hodgkin lymphoma: While mixed cellularity HL does show classic RS cells, it lacks lacunar RS cells and does not show bands of collagen dividing the lymph node into nodules. It is also more common in men, and typically presents in older individuals or those with HIV. Thus, the patient's demographic, cell type on biopsy, and immunostains are more in line with NSHL.

 

Option D. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL): DLBCL is a non-Hodgkin lymphoma and not a subtype of HD. It does not feature RS cells, particularly lacunar-type RS cells. Its immunophenotype is typically CD20+, not CD15/CD30+. The presence of RS cells with a halo and the patient’s clinical picture argue strongly against this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nodular sclerosis is the most frequent type of Hodgkin Disease, occurs more commonly in women, and is characterized by lacunar-type Reed-Sternberg cells with pericellular halo and CD15/CD30 positivity.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with recurrent gout and a history of uric acid nephrolithiasis is being considered for urate-lowering therapy. Which of the following agents is contraindicated in this patient despite being mechanistically logical for urate lowering?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Probenecid

 

  • Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that increases renal excretion of uric acid by inhibiting the URAT1 transporter in the proximal tubule. 
  • While this mechanism seems useful in lowering serum uric acid, it also raises urinary uric acid concentration, which increases the risk of stone formation—especially uric acid nephrolithiasis. 
  • Thus, probenecid is contraindicated in patients with a history of uric acid stones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Febuxostat: A non-purine xanthine oxidase inhibitor that reduces uric acid synthesis. It does not increase uric acid excretion, making it safe in nephrolithiasis.

 

Option B. Allopurinol: A purine analog that also inhibits xanthine oxidase. It reduces uric acid production and is commonly used in patients with hyperuricemia, even with nephrolithiasis (though caution is required in renal impairment).

 

Option D. Pegloticase: A recombinant uricase enzyme that converts uric acid into allantoin, a water-soluble compound easily excreted. It does not increase uric acid excretion directly and is generally reserved for refractory cases but is not contraindicated in nephrolithiasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Probenecid is contraindicated in patients with uric acid nephrolithiasis because it increases urinary uric acid levels, raising the risk of further stone formation. 
  • In such patients, xanthine oxidase inhibitors (e.g., allopurinol, febuxostat) are preferred for long-term urate-lowering therapy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents with gradually worsening pain and stiffness in both hands over the last 8 months. She reports morning stiffness lasting over an hour and difficulty performing fine motor tasks. On examination, her metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints are swollen and show ulnar deviation. What is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rheumatoid arthritis

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune inflammatory disease that primarily affects the synovial joints.
  • Key Features:
    • Morning stiffness > 1 hour → classic for RA
    • Symmetrical joint involvement → typical in RA
    • MCP swelling and ulnar deviation → hallmark signs of advanced RA
    • Fine motor difficulty → due to joint destruction and deformity
  • RA often progresses to:
    • Ulnar deviation (fingers drift towards the ulnar side)
    • Swan neck and boutonnière deformities

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoarthritis:

 

  • Osteoarthritis (OA) is a degenerative joint disease due to wear and tear of cartilage.
  • OA typically affects weight-bearing joints (knees, hips, spine)
  • In the hand, OA usually involves DIP (Heberden’s nodes) and PIP (Bouchard’s nodes) joints — not MCP
  • Morning stiffness is brief (usually <30 minutes)
  • OA is not associated with ulnar deviation

 

Option C. Psoriatic arthritis:

 

  • Psoriatic arthritis (PsA) is an inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis.
  • PsA may involve DIP joints and cause dactylitis ("sausage digits"), and pencil-in-cup appearance.
  • Can be asymmetric
  • Often associated with skin and nail changes (pitting, onycholysis)
  • Ulnar deviation is less common than in RA
  • The case lacks any history or signs of psoriasis

 

Option D. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE):

 

  • SLE is a multisystem autoimmune disease, and it can cause non-erosive arthritis.
  • It causes resorption of the bone. 
  • While SLE can cause joint pain, joint deformities like ulnar deviation (Jaccoud arthropathy) are rare and non-destructive
  • SLE arthritis is typically migratory and less severe
  • No mention of systemic features (rash, renal, hematologic, photosensitivity, etc.) which are common in SLE
  • Morning stiffness and symmetrical small joint arthritis are more characteristic of RA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rheumatoid arthritis causes symmetric MCP joint inflammation, prolonged morning stiffness, and ulnar deviation, distinguishing it from osteoarthritis, psoriatic arthritis, and SLE.

questions.text: The patient who had previously suffered a fracture in his right leg, visited the doctor for a follow-up appointment during which the cast was removed for evaluation. The doctor observed that the area had become malleable but was not movable, leading to reapplication of the cast. Based on this assessment, what is the stage of fracture healing?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Soft callus

 

  • This is the second stage of fracture healing (after inflammation).
  • Occurs approximately 3-4 weeks after the fracture.
  • The body forms a fibrocartilaginous callus made of collagen and cartilage.
  • The callus is soft and pliable, offering partial stability but not full mechanical strength.
  • On physical exam, the area may feel malleable and not fully rigid, consistent with what the doctor observed.
  • Callus is not fully calcified yet.
  • Fracture ends are starting to connect, but movement is restricted.
  • Re-casting is often needed to allow continued healing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Re-modelling:

 

  • Final stage of fracture healing.
  • Occurs months to years after injury.
  • Woven bone is replaced by lamellar bone and normal bone structure is restored.
  • The bone regains its original shape and strength.
  • In this stage, the bone is fully solid, not malleable.
  • There would be no need for re-casting.

 

Option C. Hard Callus:

 

  • This is the third stage (after soft callus).
  • Occurs around 3–6 weeks post-injury.
  • The fibrocartilaginous callus is replaced by woven bone, making the fracture site hard and stable.
  • X-rays will show visible bony bridging.
  • The bone would feel firm, not malleable.
  • Typically, cast removal may be permanent in this stage.

 

Option D. Inflammation:

 

  • Initial stage occurs immediately after the fracture (first few days).
  • Involves bleeding, hematoma, and inflammatory response.
  • No callus has formed yet.
  • At this point (likely weeks after injury), inflammation would have resolved.
