  • There would be no malleable tissue yet—just swelling or pain.

 

Educational Objective:

  • To identify the soft callus stage of fracture healing, characterized by a malleable yet partially stable callus, typically occurring 3-4 weeks after injury and requiring continued immobilization for proper bone healing.
  • Stages of fracture healing:
    • Hematoma: Fracture mobility is present
    • Callus (soft callus): The fragment is movable but not displacable
    • Consolidation (hard callus): Bone is united
    • Remodelling
  • Between the stage of hematoma and callus, there is a stage of granulation tissue, where neovascularization occurs.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements correctly differentiates a symposium from a workshop? 

 

  1. Symposium involves structured individual presentations with minimal interaction during the session.
  2. Workshops focus on passive learning, while symposiums prioritize hands-on problem solving.
  3. Symposium is ideal for integrated teaching; workshops are better for skill-building.
  4. In workshops, participants may divide into sub-groups and formulate a plan of action.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3 and 4 only

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1. Symposium involves structured individual presentations with minimal interaction during the session: True. A symposium typically consists of structured presentations by multiple speakers, often with no interaction during sessions.

 

Statement 3. Symposium is ideal for integrated teaching; workshops are better for skill-building: True. Symposia are ideal for sharing various facets of a topic (integrated teaching), whereas workshops foster skill acquisition via practical application.

 

Statement 4. In workshops, participants may divide into sub-groups and formulate a plan of action: True. A hallmark of workshops is group division, often into subgroups tasked with real problem-solving and generating actionable outputs.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. Workshops focus on passive learning, while symposiums prioritize hands-on problem solving: False. This is inverted. Workshops emphasize active, hands-on learning. Symposiums are more didactic and passive in nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Symposium is suitable for consolidated expert viewpoints without interaction; Workshop enables skill-building through active participation and group collaboration. 
  • Avoid confusing passive versus active learning roles between the two.

choices.text: It can be seen on the dorsal and volar aspect of wrist

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Less chances of recurrence

 

  • A ganglion cyst is a non-cancerous, fluid-filled swelling typically found near joints or tendons, commonly around the wrist. 
  • It is a high pressure swelling that comes as a fluid out of the Scapho-lunate area.
  • It contains mucinous (gelatinous) fluid and often appears suddenly.
  • It can appear in either the dorsal or the volar region of the wrist. 
  • Ganglion cysts are known to recur frequently, even after treatment.
  • Recurrence Rates:
    • After aspiration: Up to 50% recurrence.
    • After surgical excision: 10–20% recurrence, depending on technique.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transillumination positive: 

 

  • A ganglion cyst is filled with clear fluid, so it allows light to pass through. 
  • When a light is shined against the cyst, it will glow, which is a positive transillumination test. 
  • This helps distinguish it from solid tumors or lipomas, which do not transilluminate.

 

Option C. It can be surgically excised: 

 

  • When conservative treatments (like observation or aspiration) fail, or if the cyst is painful or limits funlimit’s surgical excision is a definitive treatment. 
  • Complete removal includes removal of the cyst and its stalk (connection to the joint capsule) to reduce recurrence risk.

 

Option D. It can be seen on the dorsal and volar aspect of wrist:

 

  • Dorsal aspect: Most common site especially over the scapholunate ligament
  • Volar aspect: Less common, but clinically important due to proximity to radial artery.
  • They can also appear in the foot, knee, or near tendon sheaths.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To recognize ganglion cysts by their typical location, positive transillumination, high recurrence rate, and available treatment options including surgical excision.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a history of prolonged vomiting over the past 3 days. She complains of fatigue, muscle cramps, and light headedness. Vital signs reveal mild tachypnea. Arterial blood gas analysis shows a pH of 7.8, PaCO₂ of 50 mmHg, and HCO₃⁻ of 30 mEq/L. What is the most likely acid-base disturbance?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation

 

  • The elevated pH (alkalemia) indicates an alkalotic state. 
  • The increased HCO₃⁻ points toward a primary metabolic alkalosis, likely due to loss of gastric acid from vomiting. 
  • The elevated PaCO₂ suggests that the body is attempting to compensate via hypoventilation, a typical respiratory compensation for metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with inability to close his right eye and drooping of the corner of his mouth following a viral upper respiratory tract infection. On examination, he is unable to raise his eyebrows, close his eyes tightly, or puff out his cheeks on the right side. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Facial nerve (VII)

 

  • The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for motor innervation to the muscles of facial expression. 
  • Bell's palsy, a common idiopathic facial nerve palsy, is associated with viral infections (e.g., herpes simplex virus) and presents as:
    • Unilateral facial weakness affecting the entire half of the face
    • Inability to close the eye, raise the eyebrow, or puff the cheek
    • Drooping of the mouth on the affected side
    • Loss of taste in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue (via chorda tympani)
  • The five branches of the facial nerve include:
    1. Temporal – Frontalis, orbicularis oculi
    2. Zygomatic – Orbicularis oculi
    3. Buccal – Upper lip, nose, buccinator
    4. Marginal mandibular – Lower lip muscles
    5. Cervical – Platysma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mandibular nerve (V3): Supplies muscles of mastication; does not control facial expression.

 

Option C. Hypoglossal nerve (XII): Controls tongue movements, not facial muscles.

 

Option D. Trigeminal nerve (V): Provides sensation to the face but does not cause motor paralysis of facial muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Facial nerve (VII) palsy, such as Bell's palsy, causes unilateral facial muscle paralysis, including inability to close the eye, raise the eyebrow, or smile symmetrically. 
  • It affects both upper and lower facial muscles, distinguishing it from central lesions (e.g., stroke), which spare the forehead.

questions.text: Which of the following glucose lowering agent can be given as an injectable drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Liraglutide

 

  • Liraglutide is a glucose-lowering agent that belongs to the glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist class. 
  • It is available as an injectable drug (given subcutaneously) and is used to enhance insulin secretion, suppress glucagon release, and slow gastric emptying, thus lowering blood glucose levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is an oral glucose-lowering agent belonging to the thiazolidinedione class. It improves insulin sensitivity but is not available as an injectable formulation.

 

Option B. Metformin: Metformin is an oral glucose-lowering agent that belongs to the biguanide class. It is the first-line treatment for type 2 diabetes but is not available in injectable form.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is an oral glucose-lowering agent that belongs to the dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor class. It is used to increase insulin secretion and decrease glucagon levels but is not available as an injectable drug.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Liraglutide is a GLP-1 receptor agonist used for type 2 diabetes that is administered via subcutaneous injection.
  • It is distinct from oral agents like metformin, pioglitazone, and sitagliptin in both mechanism and route of delivery.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with progressive shortness of breath and chronic productive cough. He complains of exertional dyspnea that has worsened over the past year. Pulmonary function testing is performed, and his flow-volume loop (in blue color) is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the flow-volume pattern and clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

 

  • Black graph is the normal graph and blue colour graph i.e patient’s graph is shifted towards the left. 
  • If it is right shift, then it is RLD and if it is left shift it will be OLD.
  • In this graph there is slight scooping which is emphysematous change
  • We can see that FVC is decreased and FEV1 is also decreased. But if numerator is going to decrease more then we will require more time 
  • Numerator has decreased more than the denominator so the ratio will decrease  
  • The flow-volume loop shows a "scooped-out" or concave expiratory limb, characteristic of obstructive lung disease. 
  • Combined with the patient's age, smoking history, and chronic productive cough, COPD is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis: Would show a restrictive pattern with a narrow, tall loop, not a scooped expiratory limb. The graph will shift towards the right hand side.


Option C. Myasthenia gravis: Can affect respiratory muscles but typically causes a restrictive pattern with low volumes, not obstructive scooping. The graph will shift inward but it will not shift towards the left side.

 

Option D. Interstitial lung disease: Also shows a restrictive loop, not the obstructive pattern seen here. The graph will shift towards the right hand side.

 

Educational Objective:
 

A scooped-out expiratory limb on flow-volume loop suggests obstructive lung disease such as COPD, particularly in smokers with chronic dyspnea and cough.

questions.text: A hospitalized patient with a bloodstream infection is started on empiric antibiotic therapy. The microbiology lab is requested to perform antibiotic susceptibility testing to guide further treatment. Which of the following methods is based on the disc diffusion technique to determine antimicrobial sensitivity?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kirby-Bauer method

 

  • The Kirby-Bauer method is a disc diffusion technique used to determine antibiotic susceptibility of bacteria. 
  • In this method, antibiotic-impregnated discs are placed on Mueller-Hinton agar that has been inoculated with a standardized concentration of the test organism. 
  • After incubation, zones of inhibition are measured to determine if the organism is susceptible, intermediate, or resistant to the antibiotics tested.
  • This method is widely used due to its simplicity, reproducibility, and cost-effectiveness, particularly in resource-limited settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Broth dilution method: This is a quantitative method that determines the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) by using serial dilutions of antibiotics in liquid media. It is not a disc diffusion method.

 

Option B. E test:  It is called as Epsilometre test. This is a Diffusion and dilution method. It has graded MIC concentrations on a paper strip that starts to diffuse into the media once placed on it giving us the MIC of the drug.

 

 

Option D. Agar dilution method: This is another quantitative MIC-based test in which bacteria are grown on agar plates with known antibiotic concentrations. It is not based on disc diffusion, but on bacterial growth directly on drug-containing media.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Kirby-Bauer method is a disc diffusion technique used to assess antibiotic susceptibility, characterized by the use of antibiotic discs on agar and measurement of zones of inhibition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman presents to the emergency department at 32 weeks of gestation with complaints of abdominal pain and reduced fetal movements for the past 24 hours. She has a history of preterm vaginal delivery due to pre-eclampsia in a previous pregnancy, but her current pregnancy has been uncomplicated. On examination, the uterus is found to be tense and tender to palpation, reaching up to the xiphisternum. The fetal parts are not well felt, and the fetal heart rate is undetectable on auscultation. Her blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and her pulse rate is 120 bpm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abruptio placentae

 

  • The most likely diagnosis is Abruptio placentae. This condition occurs when the placenta prematurely detaches from the uterine wall before delivery, typically presenting with symptoms of abdominal pain, tenderness, and reduced fetal movements. 
  • The tense uterus and the absence of fetal heart sounds are hallmark signs. The increased pulse rate in this patient also suggests maternal distress due to hemorrhage. 
  • Abruptio placentae can cause fetal distress and is a medical emergency.
  • In this patient, the history of previous pre-eclampsia and preterm labor are significant risk factors for this condition. Prompt diagnosis and intervention are crucial to manage this serious complication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uterine rupture: While uterine rupture can present with severe abdominal pain, tenderness, and fetal heart rate abnormalities, it usually occurs with a previous cesarean section or uterine surgery. This patient does not have such a history, and uterine rupture typically presents with acute, severe pain and signs of shock. The absence of shock (BP 120/80 mmHg) makes uterine rupture less likely.

 

Option C. Preterm labor pains: Preterm labor often presents with contractions and a change in the cervix (cervical dilation and effacement). However, this patient does not demonstrate significant uterine contractions on examination, and there is no mention of cervical changes. The tenderness and absence of fetal heart sounds point towards a more serious condition like abruptio placentae, not just preterm labor.

 

Option D. Polyhydramnios: Polyhydramnios refers to an excessive amount of amniotic fluid, which could cause abdominal discomfort. However, it would not explain the tense, tender uterus or the absent fetal heart sounds in this case. Polyhydramnios typically does not cause a decrease in fetal movements or fetal distress unless another underlying condition exists.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary condition associated with abdominal pain, uterine tenderness, and absent fetal heart sounds in a pregnant woman at 32 weeks gestation, especially with a history of preterm labor, is abruptio placentae.

questions.text: Identify the image shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ovarian torsion

 

  • Laparoscopic image shows a congested, dusky, and enlarged ovary, often with a visible twisted pedicle.
  • We can see a black necrotic mass in this image. It is an ovary which is undergoing torsion
  • It results from rotation of the ovary on its ligamentous supports, compromising venous outflow first, then arterial inflow.
  • Clinical signs include acute pelvic pain, vomiting, and adnexal mass.
  • It is a gynecological emergency needing prompt surgical intervention to salvage the ovary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometriotic (chocolate) cyst of ovary:

 

  • Also called an endometrioma, it contains old, altered blood, giving a thick, dark brown (“chocolate”) appearance.
  • Typically bilateral and adherent to pelvic structures.
  • Chronic pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea are common; the appearance is more cystic and not associated with torsion.

 

Option B. Dermoid cyst (mature teratoma):

 

  • A benign germ cell tumor containing ectodermal derivatives (hair, fat, teeth).
  • On imaging, shows a heterogeneous appearance with echogenic components (due to fat/hair).
  • Laparoscopically, appears as a solid-cystic mass, but not congested or dusky.
  • Can cause torsion but does not itself appear like the dusky, twisted ovary shown here.

 

Option C. Hemorrhagic ovarian cyst:

 

  • Results from bleeding into a functional cyst (e.g., corpus luteum).
  • On laparoscopy, it appears cystic with fresh or clotted blood, but the ovary retains a normal surface color.
  • No twisting or vascular compromise is typically seen unless complicated by torsion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ovarian torsion is an acute surgical emergency typically affecting women of reproductive age. Clinical features include sudden-onset lower abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. 
  • Diagnosis is often confirmed by ultrasound with Doppler showing decreased ovarian perfusion. 
  • Laparoscopy may reveal a twisted, enlarged ovary, and prompt detorsion or oophorectomy is required to preserve ovarian function and prevent necrosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with osteoarthritis presents with worsening joint stiffness and decreased mobility in her knees. Intra-articular injection of a viscous substance is administered to improve joint lubrication and reduce symptoms. This compound is composed of N-acetylglucosamine and glucuronic acid. What is the most likely substance administered?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyaluronic acid

 

  • Hyaluronic acid (hyaluronan) is a non-sulfated glycosaminoglycan (GAG) composed of repeating disaccharide units of N-acetylglucosamine and glucuronic acid. 
  • No sulphate is present.
  • It plays a critical role in joint lubrication, wound healing, tissue hydration, synovial fluid 
  • In the context of osteoarthritis, intra-articular hyaluronic acid injections help restore the viscoelastic properties of synovial fluid, reducing joint pain and improving mobility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratan sulfate: A sulfated GAG found in cartilage and the cornea; composed of galactose and N-acetylglucosamine, not glucuronic acid. No uromic acid.

 

Option B. Heparan sulfate: A sulfated GAG involved in cell signaling and anticoagulation; made up of glucosamine and iduronic or glucuronic acid but not used for joint lubrication. It is responsible for charge selectiveness GBM

 

Option C. Chondroitin sulfate: Another cartilage-associated GAG, composed of N-acetylgalactosamine and glucuronic acid, but does not have the same high viscoelastic properties as hyaluronic acid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyaluronic acid is a glycosaminoglycan composed of N-acetylglucosamine and glucuronic acid, widely used for its viscoelastic and lubricating properties in conditions like osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with chronic kidney disease stage 4 is started on a β-blocker for stable angina. One week later, he presents with dizziness, bradycardia, and fatigue. Vitals reveal a heart rate of 48/min and blood pressure of 88/60 mmHg. ECG shows sinus bradycardia. Lab results show no electrolyte imbalance. Which of the following β-blockers is most likely responsible for this exaggerated action in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atenolol

 

  • Atenolol is a lipid-insoluble β-blocker that is primarily excreted by the kidneys. 
  • In patients with renal impairment, atenolol accumulates due to reduced clearance, potentially leading to adverse effects like bradycardia, hypotension, and fatigue.
  • Due to its long half-life and poor hepatic metabolism, dose adjustment or avoidance is necessary in CKD patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metoprolol: Lipophilic and primarily metabolized by the liver, hence safer in renal failure. Not the most likely cause here.

 

Option B. Propranolol: Also, liver-metabolized and lipid-soluble. Less likely to accumulate in renal failure.

 

Option D. Esmolol: Ultra-short acting β-blocker metabolized by RBC esterases. Used in critical care settings; not used for chronic angina therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lipid-insoluble β-blockers (e.g., atenolol, nadolol) are renally excreted and can accumulate in renal failure, causing bradycardia and hypotension. 
  • Dose adjustment or alternative agents should be considered in patients with CKD.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with CML on imatinib for 3 years presents with WBC 180,000/mm³, fatigue, and splenomegaly. No fever or neurological symptoms. Blasts <5%, basophils 15%. BCR-ABL1 PCR shows no MMR (ratio 1.2%), and ABL mutation analysis reveals T315I. Next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Switch to ponatinib

 

  • CML with rising WBC (180,000/mm³), no MMR, and T315I mutation indicates imatinib resistance.
  • T315I mutation resists most TKIs except ponatinib, a third-generation TKI, making it the best choice.
  • Patient is in chronic phase (blasts <5%); ponatinib can regain control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Add hydroxyurea, continue imatinib: Imatinib fails against T315I; hydroxyurea only lowers WBC temporarily.

 

Option C. Leukapheresis and second-line TKI: No leukostasis; second-line TKIs (e.g., dasatinib) fail against T315I.

 

Option D. Stem cell transplant workup: Too early in chronic phase; try ponatinib first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

T315I mutation in CML needs ponatinib to overcome resistance.

choices.text: Damage to lateral spinothalamic tract decussating in the medulla
Involvement of dorsal column medial lemniscus pathway, which decussates at the level of spinal entry
Disruption of the dorsal columns that ascend ipsilaterally and decussate in the medulla
Injury to anterior horn cells responsible for lower motor neuron innervation

questions.text: A 29-year-old male suffers a spinal cord injury in a road traffic accident. He develops loss of proprioception, vibration sense, and fine touch below the level of the lesion, with preserved pain and temperature sensation. Based on this clinical profile, which of the following best explains the underlying neurophysiological basis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Disruption of the dorsal columns that ascend ipsilaterally and decussate in the medulla

 

  • The dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway carries fine touch, proprioception, and vibration sense. 
  • These fibers ascend ipsilaterally in the spinal cord and decussate in the medulla. 
  • Damage to this pathway results in ipsilateral loss of the above sensations below the lesion.


Other Options:
 

Option A. Damage to lateral spinothalamic tract decussating in the medulla: Incorrect. The lateral spinothalamic tract carries pain and temperature, and decussates in the spinal cord, not the medulla.

 

Option B. Involvement of dorsal column medial lemniscus pathway, which decussates at the level of spinal entry: Incorrect. The dorsal column pathway does not decussate at the level of spinal entry. It remains ipsilateral in the spinal cord until reaching the medulla.

 

Option D. Injury to anterior horn cells responsible for lower motor neuron innervation: Incorrect. Anterior horn cell injury causes lower motor neuron symptoms (e.g., flaccid paralysis), not sensory deficits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dorsal column-medial lemniscus system transmits proprioception, vibration, and fine touch; it ascends ipsilaterally in the spinal cord and decussates in the medulla, so a spinal cord lesion can lead to ipsilateral loss of these sensations below the level of injury.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding suture materials are true? 

 

  1. Polypropylene is a non-absorbable, monofilament suture preferred for vascular anastomosis.
  2. Polydioxanone (PDS) is absorbed within 180-210 days.
  3. Polyglactin is non-absorbable.
  4. Polypropylene causes minimal tissue reaction and does not weaken when exposed to tissue enzymes
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Statements 1, 2 and 4 are correct

 

Correct statements:

 

Statement 1. Polypropylene is a non-absorbable, monofilament suture preferred for vascular anastomosis: True. Polypropylene (Prolene) is a non-absorbable, monofilament suture preferred in vascular surgery due to its biological inertness, high tensile strength, and minimal tissue reactivity.

 

Statement 2. Polydioxanone (PDS) is absorbed within 180-210 days: True. PDS retains approximately 50% tensile strength at 4 weeks and is absorbed within 180–210 days.

 

Statement 4. Polypropylene causes minimal tissue reaction and does not weaken when exposed to tissue enzymes: True. Polypropylene is inert, non-adhering, and not degraded by tissue enzymes, making it ideal for permanent fixtures in vascular repair.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 3. Polyglactin is non-absorbable: False. Polyglactin (Vicryl) is an absorbable suture. It gets absorbed by 60–90 days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polypropylene is the suture of choice for vascular anastomosis due to its non-absorbable nature, biological inertness, and high tensile strength with minimal tissue reactivity.

questions.text: A pulmonologist in Delhi advises patients with moderate asthma to remain indoors when the NAQI enters a range where breathing discomfort becomes evident in people with pre-existing cardiopulmonary conditions. Which NAQI category most closely correlates with this warning?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 101–200 (Moderate)

 

  • The National Air Quality Index (NAQI) classifies air quality into six color-coded categories ranging from "Good" to "Severe", based on levels of key pollutants like PM10, PM2.5, NO₂, SO₂, CO, O₃, NH₃, and Pb.
  • The "Moderate" category (101–200) specifically notes that breathing discomfort may occur in sensitive individuals, particularly those with pre-existing respiratory or cardiovascular conditions, such as asthma, COPD, or ischemic heart disease.
  • Therefore, C) 101–200 (Moderate) is the correct range for this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following terms with their correct definitions:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A–2, B–3, C–1, D–4

 

Each term in the match-the-following question describes a specific cellular process involving the interaction, internalization, or clearance of one cell by another. Here's how they align:

 

A-2. Entosis → Active internalization of a living cell into another cell: Entosis refers to a unique process where a live cell actively invades another cell, resulting in a "cell-in-cell" structure. The internalized cell can survive, die, or be released. This is distinct from phagocytosis as it involves live cell internalization and is implicated in cancer and cell competition.

 

B-3. Emperipolesis → Passage of a live cell through another cell without destruction: Emperipolesis is a non-destructive, transient process, commonly seen in conditions like Rosai-Dorfman disease. It is characterized by the passage of a viable cell (usually a lymphocyte) through the cytoplasm of another (usually a megakaryocyte or histiocyte) without damaging either cell.

 

C-1. Efferocytosis → Clearance of dying cells by phagocytosis: Efferocytosis is a phagocytic mechanism specifically for clearing apoptotic (dying) cells by professional phagocytes like macrophages. It is essential for maintaining tissue homeostasis and preventing inflammation due to necrotic debris.

 

D-4. Enclysis → Entrapment of live CD4+ T cells by hepatocytes: Enclysis is a recently described process where hepatocytes engulf live CD4+ T cells into their cytoplasm, which can lead to immune regulation. This is especially important in liver immunology and reflects a unique interaction between liver cells and the immune system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Entosis → live cell internalization
  • Emperipolesis → non-destructive cell passage
  • Efferocytosis → phagocytosis of dying cells
  • Enclysis → T cell capture by hepatocytes

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about the Shrivastava Committee (1975) are correct?

 

  1. It recommended creating a cadre of para-professional and semi-professional health workers recruited from within the community.
  2. It proposed the introduction of the Rural Medical Officer (RMO) cadre under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM).
  3. It laid the foundation for the Village Health Guide Scheme and the Health Assistant posts.
  4. It recommended the Reorientation of Medical Education (ROME) scheme and suggested the establishment of a Medical and Health Education Commission.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3 and 4 only

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1. It recommended creating a cadre of para-professional and semi-professional health workers recruited from within the community: Correct. The Shrivastava Committee recommended creating bands of para-professional and semi-professional health workers who would be recruited from within the community to address the rural health manpower gap. This was a pivotal concept to decentralize care and build local health capacity.

 

Statement 3. It laid the foundation for the Village Health Guide Scheme and the Health Assistant posts: Correct. The committee recommended the creation of two key community-level human resource cadres—Village Health Guides and Health Assistants—to strengthen the delivery of primary healthcare services at the grassroots level.

 

Statement 4. It recommended the Reorientation of Medical Education (ROME) scheme and suggested the establishment of a Medical and Health Education Commission: Correct. The committee proposed the Reorientation of Medical Education (ROME) scheme to align medical training with community needs. It also recommended the establishment of a Medical and Health Education Commission to integrate health and medical education planning.

 

Incorrect Statement: 

 

Statement 2. It proposed the introduction of the Rural Medical Officer (RMO) cadre under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM): Incorrect. The Rural Medical Officer (RMO) cadre was not a recommendation of the Shrivastava Committee. RMOs were introduced much later (2005) as part of state-level innovations and under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) launched in 2005, which came decades after the Shrivastava Committee report of 1975.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Shrivastava Committee (1975) was a pivotal milestone in Indian public health planning. 
  • It aimed to decentralize health manpower, strengthen community-based care, and reform medical education through the ROME scheme and creation of Village Health Guides and Health Assistants.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman with seropositive RA has failed methotrexate, HCQ, Sulfasalazine and adalimumab. She still has swollen joints and elevated ESR. What is the best next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Switch to tocilizumab

 

  • Anti-TNF failure → switch to biologic with a different mechanism
  • Tocilizumab = IL-6 inhibitor
  • Adding more csDMARDs when the patient is already on triple therapy + anti TNF is suboptimal
  • IL-6 / CD-20 or JAK inhibitors are preferred options after anti-TNF failure

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase the dose of hydroxychloroquine: Risk of Maculopathy and increasing doses are likely to be ineffective.

 

Option C. Continue adalimumab and add leflunomide: Combination may help but insufficient in anti-TNF failure

 

Option D. Start IVIG: Not used in RA unless overlap with myositis or severe infection

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-TNF failure in RA requires switching to non-TNF biologic (IL-6, JAK inhibitor).

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of alcohol use is brought to the emergency department by his family after being found confused and in distress. He had a recent episode of binge drinking. On examination, his BP is 72/48 mmHg, HR is 120/min, RR is 28/min, and SpO₂ is 88% on room air. He complains of severe epigastric pain radiating to the back. Serum amylase, lipase, and BUN levels are markedly elevated. A CT scan of the abdomen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Severe acute pancreatitis

 

  • Severe acute pancreatitis is characterized by persistent organ failure lasting more than 48 hours. In this case, the patient has multi-organ dysfunction: renal impairment (elevated creatinine), respiratory compromise (hypoxia), and hypotension. 
  • The CT scan shows non-enhancing areas of the pancreas, indicating necrosis. 
  • These findings fulfil the criteria for severe acute pancreatitis per the Modified Atlanta Classification. 
  • His BISAP score (raised BUN, impaired GCS, SIRS, age > 60 years) is at least 4/5.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver abscess: Presents with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and liver imaging abnormalities. The CT here shows pancreatic involvement, not liver pathology.

 

Option B. Acute pancreatitis: Though likely initially, the presence of persistent organ failure and necrosis shifts the diagnosis to severe acute pancreatitis.

 

Option C. Acute pyelonephritis: Typically presents with flank pain, fever, and urinary symptoms. Renal imaging would show renal enlargement or wedge-shaped hypodensities, not pancreatic necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Severe acute pancreatitis is diagnosed when acute pancreatitis is accompanied by persistent (>48 hours) organ failure, and imaging often reveals pancreatic necrosis or non-enhancing areas on contrast-enhanced CT.

questions.text: Identify the type of fibres (marked in green) in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Projection 

 

  • The green-highlighted structures in the image represent the internal capsule, which is a key bundle of projection fibers. 
  • These fibers connect the cerebral cortex with subcortical structures, including the brainstem and spinal cord.
  • The internal capsule is located between the thalamus and caudate nucleus medially and the lentiform nucleus laterally, and it contains ascending (sensory) and descending (motor) tracts such as:
    • Corticospinal tract (motor)
    • Corticobulbar tract
    • Thalamocortical fibers (sensory)

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Projection fibers such as those forming the internal capsule link the cerebral cortex to subcortical structures, brainstem, and spinal cord, facilitating both motor output and sensory input.

choices.text: Pooling of fluorescein into epithelial microcystic edema
Tear break-up time artifact in a dry eye
Positive Seidel sign suggesting globe rupture
Fluorescein clumping due to infectious keratitis

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with eye pain, photophobia, and blurred vision following blunt trauma with a metallic object. Exam reveals a peaked pupil and subconjunctival hemorrhage. Fluorescein dye is applied, and the cornea is examined under cobalt blue light as shown below. Which of the following is the most accurate interpretation of this image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Positive Seidel sign suggesting globe rupture

 

  • The image shows a vertical, sharply demarcated clear stream within the fluorescein dye, which is the hallmark of a positive Seidel test. 
  • Fluorescein dye is applied and because the aqueous is leaking the fluorescein dye flows with the aqueous 
  • Seidel test is leak test which can be done after a trauma or after a surgery (to check for wound integrity)
  • This finding indicates leakage of aqueous humor through a full-thickness defect in the cornea or sclera. 
  • The fluorescein dye is diluted by the aqueous humor, appearing as a clear path in the dye under cobalt blue light. 
  • This is diagnostic of globe rupture, a vision-threatening emergency.
  • Fluorescein dye is also used for:
    • To check for epithelial defect (post trauma, corneal ulcer)
    • Fundus fluorescein angiography
    • For checking IOP (applanation tonometry)
    • Jone’s dye test

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pooling of fluorescein into epithelial microcystic edema: Would show diffuse green fluorescence without a clear streaming pattern. This occurs in corneal edema or abrasions but not in full-thickness perforation.

 

Option B. Tear break-up time artifact in a dry eye: In dry eye, tear film breaks down and creates patchy dark spots, not a flowing clear stream like in Seidel positivity.

 

Option D. Fluorescein clumping due to infectious keratitis: In microbial keratitis, fluorescein accumulates in epithelial defects, creating intense bright green patches, not dilutional streams.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A positive Seidel test is the most specific sign of a full-thickness corneal or scleral perforation. 
  • It presents as a clear stream within fluorescein dye, caused by leaking aqueous humor. 
  • Immediate ophthalmologic referral and globe protection are essential to preserve vision.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with frequent lower respiratory tract infections, hypocalcemia-induced tetany, and facial dysmorphism. On examination, he has low-set ears, micrognathia, and a fish-like mouth. Chest X-ray reveals absent thymic shadow. Genetic testing confirms a 22q11.2 microdeletion. Which of the following features is least likely to be seen in this syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperphosphatemia due to renal tubular defect

 

  • The child has DiGeorge Syndrome (22q11.2 deletion).
  • Classical features include: (Mnemonic: CATCH22) 
    • C: Cardiac defects (especially conotruncal like TOF, truncus arteriosus)
    • A: Abnormal facies
    • T: Thymic aplasia and T-cell deficiency
    • C: Cleft palate
    • H: Hypocalcemia (due to hypoparathyroidism)
  • Learning disabilities are common.
  • So least likely to happen is Hyperphosphatemia due to renal tubular defect

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Renal tubular defects causing hyperphosphatemia is not a feature of DiGeorge; in fact, hypocalcemia is prominent due to low PTH.

questions.text: A clinical trial evaluates the average reduction in systolic blood pressure among 150 hypertensive patients following 12 weeks of therapy. To assess how well the sample mean represents the true average reduction in the entire hypertensive population, which of the following statistical measures should be used?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Standard error

 

  • The standard error (SE) quantifies the variability of a sample mean as an estimate of the population mean. 
  • It reflects how much the sample mean is expected to fluctuate due to random sampling error. 
  • A smaller SE indicates more precise estimation of the population parameter. 
  • In contrast, the range and standard deviation measure variability within the sample, but do not directly assess precision of the sample mean as a population estimate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Geometric mean: Useful for log-transformed or skewed data (e.g., microbial counts), not for assessing sampling precision.

 

Option B. Range: Reflects the spread between highest and lowest values in a dataset but gives no insight into how well the mean represents the population.

 

Option C. Deviation: Generic term often refers to deviation from mean; not a specific measure of sampling error.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The standard error is a critical concept in inferential statistics. 
  • It is used to construct confidence intervals and perform hypothesis tests, helping estimate the precision of sample-derived statistics.

choices.text: Reduced afferent input from carotid sinus via cranial nerve IX
Loss of inhibitory output to the vasoconstrictor area from the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius
Excessive stimulation of the vagal efferents causing resting tachycardia
Unopposed parasympathetic stimulation due to vagal nucleus hyperactivity

questions.text: A 66-year-old man with a history of aortic arch atherosclerosis is found to have wide blood pressure fluctuations and resting tachycardia. MRI shows infarction involving the dorsomedial medulla. Which of the following most likely explains the patient's dysregulation of blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loss of inhibitory output to the vasoconstrictor area from the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius

 

  • The Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS) integrates baroreceptor input from CN IX (carotid sinus) and CN X (aortic arch). 
  • Peripheral baroreceptors are present in the carotid sinus and aortic arch. They will carry the blood pressure that means the changes that they will sense (action potential) towards the medulla with IX and X nerve and they will go towards the medullary centre i.e Nucleus Tractus Solitarius which is present at dorso medial medulla.
  • In medullary infarction, particularly dorsomedial medulla, damage to the NTS impairs its ability to inhibit the vasoconstrictor area, leading to loss of vasodilation and labile hypertension with tachycardia, as seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduced afferent input from carotid sinus via CN IX: Would be seen in glossopharyngeal nerve lesions, not in NTS infarction.

 

Option C. Excessive stimulation of the vagal efferents causing resting tachycardia: Would cause bradycardia, not tachycardia. Efferent will reduce because the processing will be hampered.

 

Option D. Unopposed parasympathetic stimulation due to vagal nucleus hyperactivity: Again, would result in bradycardia and hypotension, opposite of what is seen here. It will go under sympathetic stimulation because sympathetic centres like CVLM and RVLM will act as vasomotor centres.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Nucleus Tractus Solitarius plays a central role in baroreceptor reflexes by inhibiting vasoconstrictor centers and stimulating vagal output; damage to this nucleus impairs blood pressure regulation, leading to tachycardia and hypertension.

questions.text: A teenager was brought into the casualty following a fall during a football match, with complaints of amnesia, confusion, and headache, but no loss of consciousness. His GCS was 14/15. The CT scan of his brain showed no abnormality. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Concussion

 

  • A concussion is a mild traumatic brain injury that can occur with or without loss of consciousness. 
  • Key features include confusion, amnesia, and other cognitive disturbances. 
  • It is commonly seen in sports-related injuries and does not typically show up on a CT scan. 
  • The patient’s symptoms and the fact that the CT scan showed no abnormalities make this the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diffuse Axonal Injury: Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is a severe form of brain injury that occurs with intense rotational forces, often seen in high-velocity car accidents or severe falls. It can cause microscopic brain lesions that may not be evident on a CT scan but are more often associated with a lower GCS score and loss of consciousness.

 

Option C. Lucid interval: It is seen in EDH. EDH typically presents with a lucid interval followed by a decline in consciousness and is usually associated with a fracture of the temporal bone. This condition often shows a lens-shaped bleed on a CT scan, which was not present in this case.

 

Option D. Subdural Hemorrhage: A subdural hemorrhage is a collection of blood between the dura and the brain tissue. It usually results from tearing of bridging veins and presents with a fluctuating level of consciousness and focal neurological signs. Like extradural hemorrhages, subdural hemorrhages are usually visible on a CT scan.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Concussion is a clinical diagnosis characterized by symptoms such as headache, confusion, and amnesia following head trauma, often without imaging abnormalities. 
  • It is important to note that loss of consciousness is not required for the diagnosis of concussion.

questions.text: A 38-year-old primigravida is informed that her risk of having a baby with Down syndrome is significantly high due to her age. She asks for a screening test with a high detection rate for Down syndrome. Which of the following tests would you recommend?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cell-free DNA

 

  • The best screening test for Down syndrome with the highest detection rate in this patient is Cell-free DNA. 
  • This test analyzes fetal DNA circulating in the maternal blood and has a very high detection rate for trisomy 21 (Down syndrome). 
  • It is non-invasive, with a very low false-positive rate, making it an excellent choice for high-risk pregnancies.
  • Cell-free DNA testing is highly accurate and can be done as early as the 10th week of pregnancy. 
  • It is considered more accurate than other screening methods, such as the combined test, which relies on maternal serum markers and ultrasound findings, and provides a lower detection rate for trisomy 21.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amniocentesis: Amniocentesis is a diagnostic test, not a screening test. While it provides definitive information regarding chromosomal abnormalities, including Down syndrome, it carries a small risk of miscarriage. It is typically offered when a screening test (like cell-free DNA or the combined test) has indicated an increased risk, or in cases where more invasive testing is warranted.

 

Option C. Combined test: The combined test, which includes a first-trimester ultrasound and maternal blood markers, is a screening test for Down syndrome. It is accurate but has a lower detection rate compared to cell-free DNA testing, particularly in older women, making it less ideal for this patient who is at high risk.

 

Option D. Chorionic villous sampling (CVS): Like amniocentesis, CVS is a diagnostic test that involves taking a sample of tissue from the placenta to analyze fetal DNA. While it provides definitive results, it also carries a risk of miscarriage and is usually reserved for situations where a diagnostic test is needed, such as when a screening test has shown a high risk or when the patient is known to have a higher risk of chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cell-free DNA testing is the screening test with the highest detection rate for Down syndrome in high-risk pregnancies and is considered the most accurate non-invasive option.

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman is in active labor. During the pelvic examination, it is noted that the anterior parietal bone of the fetus is descending first into the pelvis during engagement. Which of the following terms describes this positioning of the fetal head?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nagele’s asynclitism

 

  • When the anterior parietal bone descends first it is called as anterior asynclitism or Nagele’s asynclitism
  • Nagele’s asynclitism is a specific term referring to a fetal head position in which the anterior parietal bone of the fetus leads into the pelvis during labor, while the posterior parietal bone is tilted backward. 
  • This creates an asymmetrical engagement of the fetal head and is often seen in the vertex presentation. 
  • Although this positioning can complicate the descent and delivery, it is typically noted during the clinical examination and can influence management decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Synclitism: Synclitism refers to the ideal fetal head positioning where both the anterior and posterior parietal bones descend equally into the pelvis. This is the most favorable and normal alignment for vaginal delivery, not the case here, where one parietal bone is descending first.

 

Option C. Asymmetrical synclitism: This refers to a mild form of asynclitism, where one parietal bone enters the pelvis slightly more than the other. It is a form of uneven descent, but not exactly what is described in this scenario, where the anterior parietal bone leads.

 

Option D. Litzmann’s asynclitism: Litzmann’s asynclitism describes a situation where one of the parietal bones is anteriorly displaced while the other is posteriorly displaced, causing significant obstruction to the normal descent. This is not the situation here, where only the anterior parietal bone is descending.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nagele’s asynclitism refers to a type of fetal head position in which the anterior parietal bone leads into the pelvis, while the posterior parietal bone is displaced. 
  • This can lead to difficulty in labor progression and should be recognized during examination.

choices.text: Treating hypertension in a pregnant woman
Managing withdrawal symptoms in a heroin-dependent patient
Increasing blood pressure in a patient with septic shock
Treating ADHD as adjunctive therapy in a pediatric patient

questions.text: Which of the following clinical scenarios is least appropriate for α₂-agonist therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increasing blood pressure in a patient with septic shock

 

  • α₂-agonists (such as clonidine, methyldopa, dexmedetomidine, guanfacine) primarily act centrally by stimulating presynaptic α₂ receptors, which inhibit sympathetic outflow, resulting in decreased norepinephrine release and reduced blood pressure.
  • In septic shock, the goal is to increase systemic vascular resistance and perfusion pressure, typically using α₁ agonists (e.g., norepinephrine).
  • Using α₂ agonists here would further suppress sympathetic tone, potentially worsening hypotension, tissue hypoperfusion, and mortality risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treating hypertension in a pregnant woman: Appropriate. Methyldopa is a centrally acting α₂ agonist and is considered safe during pregnancy, making it a preferred first-line antihypertensive in this context.

 

Option B. Managing withdrawal symptoms in a heroin-dependent patient: Appropriate. Clonidine can alleviate autonomic symptoms (e.g., sweating, agitation, anxiety, tachycardia) during opioid withdrawal.

 

Option D. Treating ADHD as adjunctive therapy in a pediatric patient: Appropriate. Guanfacine and clonidine are approved as non-stimulant options in the treatment of ADHD, especially useful in children with comorbid tics or insomnia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • α₂-agonists reduce sympathetic tone and are useful in managing hypertension, ADHD, and withdrawal syndromes.
  • However, they are contraindicated in hypotensive states like septic shock, where increasing vascular tone is required.

questions.text:
Match the following tests with the parasitic diseases they help diagnose: 

 

Tests:

 

  1. Casoni test
  2. Montenegro test
  3. Frenkel test
  4. Fairley test

 

Diseases:

 

  1. Kala azar
  2. Schistosomiasis
  3. Toxoplasmosis
  4. Hydatid disease
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A–4, B–1, C–3, D–2

 

A–4. Casoni test → Hydatid disease: Intradermal hypersensitivity test using hydatid fluid.

 

B–1. Montenegro test → Kala azar (Leishmaniasis): Delayed hypersensitivity skin test with killed Leishmania.

 

C–3. Frenkel test → Toxoplasmosis: Serological test for antibodies to Toxoplasma gondii.

 

D–2. Fairley test → Schistosomiasis: Diagnostic test based on antigen exposure from Schistosoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Casoni test → Hydatid disease

Montenegro test → Kala azar

Frenkel test → Toxoplasmosis

Fairley test → Schistosomiasis

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of lower abdominal discomfort and the presence of a lower abdominal mass. Upon examination, her uterus is uniformly enlarged, and there is no tenderness in the adnexa. An MRI reveals a myometrial cyst. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenomyosis

 

  • The patient presents with lower abdominal discomfort, a uniformly enlarged uterus, and a myometrial cyst seen on MRI. 
  • These features are most consistent with adenomyosis.
  • Adenomyosis occurs when endometrial tissue grows within the myometrium (muscle layer of the uterus). 
  • This causes the uterus to become enlarged and boggy, and MRI often reveals myometrial cysts or areas of low signal intensity, which are typical findings of adenomyosis. 
  • It is often associated with painful menstruation (dysmenorrhea) and heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia), although it can also be asymptomatic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leiomyoma: Leiomyomas (fibroids) are common benign tumors of the uterus, often presenting with localized mass formation, typically well-circumscribed. Although fibroids can cause an enlarged uterus, they usually present with a firm, non-boggy consistency, unlike adenomyosis. Fibroids do not typically present with myometrial cysts.

 

Option B. Endometrial hyperplasia: Endometrial hyperplasia involves the thickening of the endometrial lining and can be associated with abnormal uterine bleeding. However, it would not cause a uniformly enlarged uterus or myometrial cysts as seen in adenomyosis.

 

Option D. Endometriosis: Endometriosis occurs when endometrial tissue is found outside the uterus, typically in the pelvic cavity (e.g., ovaries, fallopian tubes). It does not typically cause a uniformly enlarged uterus or myometrial cysts. The presence of adnexal masses or ovarian cysts (such as chocolate cysts) would be more suggestive of endometriosis, which this patient does not have.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with lower abdominal discomfort, a uniformly enlarged uterus, and myometrial cysts on MRI, adenomyosis is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old medical student is brought to the emergency department after collapsing during a late-night college party. His friends report that he had been exercising intensely throughout the day for an upcoming sports event and skipped dinner. At the party, he consumed a large amount of alcohol on an empty stomach. On examination, the patient is confused and diaphoretic, with a blood glucose level of 38 mg/dL. Laboratory analysis shows increased lactate levels consistent with metabolic acidosis. Which of the following metabolic pathways is most likely inhibited by alcohol metabolism, leading to this patient’s hypoglycemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gluconeogenesis

 

  • Alcohol metabolism increases the NADH/NAD⁺ ratio, particularly in the liver. 
  • This altered redox state inhibits key steps in gluconeogenesis, especially the conversion of lactate to pyruvate and malate to oxaloacetate. 
  • As a result, glucose production is impaired during fasting or exercise, predisposing to hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycogenolysis: This pathway is not directly inhibited by alcohol. In fact, during early fasting or stress, glycogenolysis provides glucose. However, liver glycogen stores are depleted after 12–18 hours of fasting or intense exercise, at which point gluconeogenesis becomes essential.

 

Option C. Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) Shunt: This pathway (also called the pentose phosphate pathway) mainly generates NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate, and is not directly involved in maintaining blood glucose or affected by alcohol.

 

Option D. Ketone Body Formation: Ketogenesis is typically upregulated during prolonged fasting or carbohydrate deprivation. Alcohol metabolism does not acutely inhibit ketogenesis, though it can affect the redox state of the liver and promote ketoacidosis in some scenarios.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcohol metabolism increases the NADH/NAD⁺ ratio, which inhibits gluconeogenesis, especially in the setting of fasting or depleted glycogen stores, resulting in hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 18 weeks of gestation presents for a routine antenatal checkup. During the abdominal examination, the uterine size corresponds to 16 weeks of gestation. Ultrasound reveals oligohydramnios. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Renal agenesis

 

  • Oligohydramnios, which refers to low amniotic fluid, can occur for several reasons, one of the most common being renal agenesis. 
  • Renal agenesis is a congenital anomaly where one or both kidneys fail to develop, resulting in reduced urine output by the fetus. 
  • Since fetal urine production is the primary source of amniotic fluid after the first trimester, the absence of kidneys leads to a significant reduction in amniotic fluid volume, resulting in oligohydramnios.
  • When oligohydramnios is detected along with a smaller-than-expected uterus for gestational age (in this case, 18 weeks with a uterine size corresponding to 16 weeks), renal agenesis should be strongly considered, as this condition affects fluid production, leading to inadequate amniotic fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anencephaly: Anencephaly is a neural tube defect in which the brain and skull do not develop properly. While it is associated with certain prenatal findings, it does not typically cause oligohydramnios. It causes polyhydramnios. Fetal urine production can still occur in cases of anencephaly, making renal agenesis a more likely cause of oligohydramnios in this scenario.

 

Option C. Barter syndrome: Barter syndrome is a rare renal tubular disorder that causes electrolyte imbalances and affects fluid regulation in the fetus. While it can lead to oligohydramnios, it is typically seen in later gestation and usually presents with more prominent signs of electrolyte imbalance. This would not typically be diagnosed at 18 weeks with just oligohydramnios.

 

Option D. Fetal anemia: Fetal anemia can indeed cause oligohydramnios, but this would typically be accompanied by signs of hypoxia or hydrops fetalis (fluid buildup in fetal tissues), which is not indicated here. The uterine size discrepancy and absence of other signs of fetal distress make renal agenesis a more likely cause in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal agenesis is the most common cause of oligohydramnios in early pregnancy due to a lack of fetal urine production, which significantly reduces the amount of amniotic fluid.

choices.text: A woman ovulates and conceives during two separate cycles, with one fertilization occurring after intercourse with a different partner in the second cycle
A woman ovulates once but is fertilized twice by sperm from the same partner during a prolonged sexual encounter
A woman has two eggs released from the same ovulatory cycle and both are fertilized by sperms from two different partners
A woman has two fertilized eggs from the same ovulation cycle, from two different partners, but one implantation is delayed compared to the other

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios would be most likely to result in heteropaternal superfetation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A woman ovulates and conceives during two separate cycles, with one fertilization occurring after intercourse with a different partner in the second cycle

 

  • Superfetation refers to two separate ovulations and two conceptions from different menstrual cycles occurring during an ongoing pregnancy.
  • When the sperm come from two different fathers, it is termed heteropaternal superfetation.
  • Though extremely rare in humans, this phenomenon is possible when:
    • Ovulation occurs during an already ongoing pregnancy (typically prevented by hormonal feedback).
    • A second fertilization and implantation occur, usually involving a different sexual partner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. A woman ovulates once but is fertilized twice by sperm from the same partner during a prolonged sexual encounter: Incorrect. This is twinning from a single ovulatory cycle with monopaternal fertilization. It is not superfetation nor heteropaternal, because the sperm are from the same partner.

 

Option C. A woman has two eggs released from the same ovulatory cycle and both are fertilized by sperms from two different partners: Incorrect. This describes heteropaternal superfecundation, not superfetation. Superfecundation occurs when two ova from the same cycle are fertilized by sperm from different partners.

 

Option D. A woman has two fertilized eggs from the same ovulation cycle, from two different partners, but one implantation is delayed compared to the other: Incorrect. This again fits heteropaternal superfecundation, not superfetation. Implantation delay does not change the ovulatory origin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The definition of heteropaternal superfetation:
    • Superfetation: Two conceptions from Two consecutive ovulatory cycles
    • Heteropaternal: Two different fathers.

choices.text: Cannot be calculated without population size

Among 30 close, unvaccinated contacts of the index case, 27 developed a paroxysmal cough within 14 days of exposure. What is the secondary attack rate (SAR) for this outbreak?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 90%

 

  • Secondary Attack Rate (SAR) is used in outbreak investigations to estimate the infectivity of a disease among susceptible contacts after exposure to a primary case. SAR is calculated by the formula:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secondary Attack Rate (SAR) is used to measure the spread of infectious diseases in defined settings (e.g., households, schools, communities) among susceptible individuals. 
  • It is especially relevant in diseases with person-to-person transmission, like pertussis, measles, chickenpox, etc.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman presents with a chronic nonproductive cough, wheezing, and recent episodes of hemoptysis. A CT scan of the chest shows a centrally located mass obstructing the left main bronchus. Bronchoscopic biopsy is given below. Immunohistochemistry is positive for CD56, chromogranin, and synaptophysin. What is the most likely cell of origin for this tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kulchitsky cell

 

  • The described tumor represents a typical carcinoid tumor of the lung, a type of neuroendocrine tumor. 
  • These tumors are centrally located, may present with airway obstruction (wheezing, cough), and can be associated with hemoptysis. 
  • The presence of neuroendocrine markers—CD56, chromogranin, and synaptophysin—confirms neuroendocrine differentiation. 
  • The cell of origin is the Kulchitsky cell, a neuroendocrine cell found in the bronchial epithelium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basal cell: Basal cells are epithelial progenitor cells and can be involved in squamous cell carcinoma, but they do not express neuroendocrine markers.

 

Option B. Goblet cell: These are mucus-secreting epithelial cells and are not the source of neuroendocrine tumors. Goblet cell carcinoids are primarily found in the appendix, not the lung.

 

Option D. Clara cell: Also known as club cells, these non-ciliated bronchiolar epithelial cells are involved in xenobiotic metabolism and surfactant-like secretion. They are not neuroendocrine cells and do not give rise to carcinoid tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulmonary carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine neoplasms that stain positive for chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56, and originate from Kulchitsky cells—neuroendocrine cells of the bronchial mucosa.

questions.text: Which of the following is required for the enzymatic activity of propionyl-CoA carboxylase?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biotin and ATP

 

  • Propionyl-CoA carboxylase is an important enzyme in the propionate metabolism pathway, specifically involved in the conversion of propionyl-CoA to methylmalonyl-CoA. 
  • This reaction requires biotin as a cofactor and ATP as an energy source. 
  • Biotin functions as a coenzyme in carboxylation reactions, where it facilitates the attachment of a carboxyl group to propionyl-CoA. 
  • The ATP is needed to provide the energy for this carboxylation process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12 and Folic acid: While vitamin B12 and folic acid are critical in methylmalonyl-CoA metabolism and homocysteine metabolism, they are not involved in the propionyl-CoA carboxylase reaction.

 

Option C. NAD+ and Coenzyme A: These are important for oxidative reactions and acyl group transfer, respectively, but are not required for the biotin-dependent carboxylation of propionyl-CoA.

 

Option D. Thiamine and Lipoic acid: Thiamine is involved in pyruvate decarboxylation, and lipoic acid is involved in pyruvate dehydrogenase and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase reactions, not in the propionyl-CoA carboxylase pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propionyl-CoA carboxylase requires biotin as a cofactor and ATP for its carboxylation reaction, which is essential in the metabolism of propionate.

choices.text: Selection bias due to exclusion criteria
Lead-time bias due to early enrollment
Observer bias due to unblinded investigators
Attrition bias due to poor follow-up

questions.text: An RCT on a new antihypertensive agent excludes patients with previous cardiac events. At the end of the study, the drug appears to have minimal cardiovascular protective benefit. Which bias likely explains the underestimation of efficacy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Selection bias due to exclusion criteria

 

  • Selection bias occurs when the study population is not representative of the target population, leading to distorted associations between exposure and outcome. 
  • In this case, by excluding high-risk individuals (those with prior cardiac events), the investigators have selected a lower-risk cohort, reducing the number of cardiovascular events overall. 
  • This makes it harder to detect a true protective effect of the drug, especially since the population at greatest benefit has been excluded. 
  • Therefore, the observed minimal benefit is an underestimate of the actual efficacy in real-world, higher-risk populations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lead-time bias due to early enrollment: Incorrect. Lead-time bias is typically associated with screening interventions where early diagnosis appears to prolong survival, even if the natural course of the disease is unchanged. It does not apply here, as the trial involves treatment efficacy, not screening.

 

Option C. Observer bias due to unblinded investigators: Incorrect. Observer bias occurs when the outcome assessment is influenced by the knowledge of group assignment. In a well-designed RCT, blinding minimizes this. Moreover, cardiovascular endpoints (e.g., MI, stroke) are usually objective and less prone to subjective interpretation.

 

Option D. Attrition bias due to poor follow-up: Incorrect. Attrition bias refers to differential loss to follow-up between groups, which can skew results. There is no mention of loss to follow-up here; the key issue is the exclusion of high-risk participants at baseline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When high-risk individuals are excluded from a clinical trial, the remaining low-risk sample may fail to demonstrate a true treatment benefit. 
  • This is a classic form of selection bias, leading to underestimation of efficacy, particularly in preventive or cardioprotective interventions.

choices.text: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever, diffuse body aches, and a widespread erythematous rash. He recently underwent nasal packing for a nosebleed (epistaxis) two days ago. On examination, he is febrile and hypotensive, and his rash is noted to involve the trunk and extremities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxic Shock Syndrome

 

  • Toxic Shock Syndrome (TSS) is an acute, life-threatening illness caused by toxin-producing strains of Staphylococcus aureus (or rarely Streptococcus pyogenes). 
  • It classically presents with high-grade fever, hypotension, diffuse erythematous macular rash (often resembling sunburn), and multisystem involvement. 
  • Risk factors include nasal packing, tampon use, or surgical wounds, which can serve as a nidus for bacterial toxin release. 
  • The association with nasal packing and the acute systemic signs in this patient strongly suggest TSS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scarlet fever: Caused by Group A Streptococcus pyogenes, presents with fever, sandpaper-like rash, strawberry tongue, and pharyngitis, but is not associated with nasal packing and does not typically cause hypotension or systemic shock.

 

Option C. Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS): Usually occurs in infants or young children and is caused by exfoliative toxin-producing S. aureus. It presents with painful skin desquamation, but without hypotension and multi-organ failure.

 

Option D. DRESS (Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms): A delayed hypersensitivity drug reaction that includes rash, fever, eosinophilia, and organ dysfunction. However, it occurs days to weeks after starting a drug—not within 2 days of a local procedure—and is not associated with nasal packing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toxic Shock Syndrome should be suspected in patients presenting with fever, hypotension, rash, and recent history of nasal packing or surgical procedures, due to toxin-producing Staphylococcus aureus infection.

questions.text:
Which of the following accurately describe characteristics of the Service Approach in health education?

 

  1. It is a supply-side approach with provision of health services irrespective of population’s felt needs.
  2. It builds long-term community empowerment and sustained behavioral change.
  3. It includes mobile vaccination vans sent to underserved regions without prior awareness campaigns.
  4. It relies heavily on punitive enforcement mechanisms.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 3 only

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1. It is a supply-side approach with provision of health services irrespective of population’s felt needs: Correct. The service approach emphasizes provision of services, often without engaging with the community’s felt needs or demand. It is supply-driven and sometimes passive in nature, assuming that availability will translate into uptake.

 

Statement 3. It includes mobile vaccination vans sent to underserved regions without prior awareness campaigns: Correct. Deploying mobile vaccination vans without prior IEC (Information, Education, and Communication) or community involvement is a classic example of the service approach. While such services may fill gaps, their effectiveness can be limited due to poor community uptake.

 

Incorrect Statements: 

 

Statement 2. It builds long-term community empowerment and sustained behavioral change: Incorrect. Long-term community empowerment and sustained behavior change are hallmarks of the health education approach, not the service approach. The latter lacks the participatory and educational elements needed to change beliefs and behaviors over time.

 

Statement 4. It relies heavily on punitive enforcement mechanisms: Incorrect. Punitive enforcement is a feature of the regulatory approach, where laws or mandates (e.g., fines for not wearing seatbelts or spitting in public) are used. It is not part of the service model, which lacks coercive components.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The service approach in health education is characterized by passive, supply-driven delivery of healthcare services. 
  • While useful in filling immediate gaps, it often lacks the participatory and educational components needed for sustainable health behavior change.

questions.text:
Identify the incorrect statements regarding Sugammadex:
 

  1. It is ineffective against succinylcholine-induced muscle relaxation.
  2. It reverses neuromuscular blockade by enzymatic degradation of rocuronium.
  3. Sugammadex can reverse the effects of vecuronium to some extent.
  4. Sugammadex produces autonomic instability similar to neostigmine.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only 2 and 4

 

Incorrect Statements:
 

Statement 2. It reverses neuromuscular blockade by enzymatic degradation of rocuronium: Incorrect. Sugammadex does not enzymatically degrade rocuronium. Instead, it works via encapsulation — forming tight water-soluble complexes that render the drug inactive and prevent receptor interaction.

 

Statement 4. Sugammadex produces autonomic instability similar to neostigmine: Incorrect. Sugammadex does not cause autonomic instability (like bradycardia or GI disturbances), which are typical with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors such as neostigmine. This is one of its major advantages.

 

Correct Statements:
 

Statement 1. It is ineffective against succinylcholine-induced muscle relaxation: Correct. Sugammadex is ineffective against depolarizing neuromuscular blockers like succinylcholine and also against benzylisoquinolines like atracurium. It only works on aminosteroid non-depolarizing blockers.

 

Statement 3. Sugammadex can reverse the effects of vecuronium to some extent: Correct. Suggamadex is most effective against rocuronium and vecuronium. Some efficacy has been demonstrated against pancuronium, another aminosteroid, though it’s less commonly used to reverse the action of this agent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sugammadex reverses aminosteroid-induced neuromuscular blockade (especially rocuronium and vecuronium) by encapsulating the drug molecule, not enzymatic degradation. 
  • It is ineffective against succinylcholine and benzylisoquinolines, and unlike neostigmine, does not produce autonomic side effects.

choices.text: Start nimodipine and do CT Angiography

questions.text: A 32-year-old male develops acute severe headache after lifting a 50kg bar in the gym. He is conscious but complains of severe headache and photophobia. NCCT brain is shown. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start nimodipine and do CT Angiography

 

  • Hyperdensity (blood) in sulci/gyri = subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • Next step is to do CT Angiography for localizing the aneurysm. If NCCT is negative and the clinical presentation is typical – do LP to rule out xanthochromia. 
  • Nimodipine prevents vasospasm. 
  • Surgical/vascular interventions follow aneurysm localization. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate surgical clipping: Can be done after localizing the aneurysm by angiography. 

 

Option C External ventricular drain placement: Needed only if hydrocephalus or ICP elevation

 

Option D. Repeat NCCT within 24 hours: Not needed as the initial NCCT is diagnostic. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

SAH is treated initially with nimodipine. CT angiography is important to localize aneurysm.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve are correct?

 

  1. A rightward shift of the curve indicates decreased affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, promoting oxygen unloading in tissues.
  2. Increased 2,3-DPG levels shift the dissociation curve to the left, enhancing oxygen binding.
  3. Stored blood (banked blood) may show a left shift due to decreased levels of 2,3-DPG.
  4. Hypothermia causes a right shift in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Statements 1 and 3 are correct

 

Statement 1. A rightward shift of the curve indicates decreased affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, promoting oxygen unloading in tissues: Correct. Right shift = decreased oxygen affinity = promotes unloading at tissues. Caused by ↑PCO₂, ↑temperature, ↓pH, ↑2,3-DPG.

 

Statement 3. Stored blood (banked blood) may show a left shift due to decreased levels of 2,3-DPG: Correct. Banked blood has reduced 2,3-DPG, causing a left shift, meaning reduced oxygen delivery to tissues.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2. Increased 2,3-DPG levels shift the dissociation curve to the left, enhancing oxygen binding: Incorrect. Increased 2,3-DPG causes a right shift, not a left shift. It facilitates oxygen release.

 

Statement 4. Hypothermia causes a right shift in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve: Incorrect. Hypothermia decreases temperature, causing a left shift, not a right shift.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve shifts right with factors like ↑PCO₂, ↓pH, ↑temperature, and ↑2,3-DPG, enhancing oxygen delivery to tissues; whereas a left shift (↓PCO₂, ↑pH, ↓temperature, ↓2,3-DPG) increases oxygen affinity and impairs tissue oxygenation.

choices.text: Constitutional delay of growth and puberty

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with short stature, delayed puberty, and a high-pitched voice, as shown in the image. On examination, he has small testes and lacks secondary sexual characteristics. His bone age is delayed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Constitutional delay of growth and puberty

 

  • Constitutional delay of growth and puberty is a common cause of delayed puberty, particularly in boys. 
  • This condition is often characterized by a temporary delay in physical development and pubertal progression. 
  • Boys with this condition typically have a delayed bone age, and although they are shorter and show delayed pubertal signs compared to their peers, they eventually undergo normal growth spurts and achieve normal adult height and sexual maturation. 
  • The presence of short stature, delayed puberty, small testes, and delayed bone age in this case strongly suggests a diagnosis of constitutional delay of growth and puberty.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Klinefelter syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic condition affecting males, characterized by the presence of an extra X chromosome (47,XXY). Patients typically have small testes, gynecomastia, and infertility. However, they are usually tall with long legs and have normal or low-pitched voices, making this diagnosis unlikely given the short stature and high-pitched voice observed in the patient.

 

Option B. Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism can lead to delayed growth and puberty due to reduced thyroid hormone levels, which are critical for growth and metabolism. It causes Jaundice, Poor tone, constipation. However, hypothyroidism is usually associated with additional symptoms such as weight gain, fatigue, dry skin, and constipation. The high-pitched voice described in the patient is not typical of hypothyroidism.

 

Option D. Turner syndrome: Turner syndrome is Female webbed neck. It is a genetic disorder that affects females and is characterized by short stature, delayed puberty, and infertility. It is caused by the absence of one X chromosome (45,X). Since Turner syndrome only affects females, it cannot be the diagnosis in this 12-year-old boy.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Constitutional delay of growth and puberty is a common cause of delayed puberty in boys and is characterized by temporary delays in growth and pubertal development. 
  • Boys with this condition often have delayed bone age and catch up with their peers later during adolescence, eventually achieving normal adult height and sexual maturation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with glucosuria despite having normal blood glucose levels. Which of the following is most likely to be defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) SGLT 2

 

  • Renal glucosuria is a condition where glucose is excreted in the urine despite normal blood glucose levels. 
  • In Intestine there is SGLTI. Kidneys have SGLTI and SGLTII 
  • If SGLTII is defective then kidney will not absorb the glucose and glucose will come in urine i.e renal glycosuria
  • This condition is typically caused by a defect in the SGLT2 (Sodium-Glucose Linked Transporter 2), which is responsible for reabsorbing glucose from the proximal convoluted tubule of the kidney into the bloodstream.
