Option B. Begin IV albumin only: Antibiotics are essential for infection control

 

Option C. Start meropenem and terlipressin: Not first-line unless HRS already develops

 

Option D. Give IV fluids and wait for culture: Dangerous delay; culture positivity not required

 

Educational Objective:

 

SBP with rising creatinine mandates immediate cefotaxime and albumin to prevent renal failure.

choices.text: Large goitre is an indication for thyroidectomy.
Radioiodine is recommended for management in pregnancy.
Agranulocytosis is a complication associated with carbimazole.

questions.text: With regards to the treatment of thyrotoxicosis of Grave's disease, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radioiodine is recommended for management in pregnancy

 

This statement is incorrect. Radioiodine is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its potential to cross the placenta and cause fetal thyroid destruction, leading to hypothyroidism in the developing fetus.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Propylthiouracil is suitable in breastfeeding patients: This statement is correct. Propylthiouracil (PTU) is often preferred in breastfeeding patients due to its lower excretion into breast milk compared to methimazole, making it safer for the infant.

 

Option B. Large goitre is an indication for thyroidectomy: This statement is correct. Large goitres, especially those causing compressive symptoms or cosmetic concerns, are an indication for thyroidectomy. Surgery is also considered when there is suspicion of malignancy or when medical management fails.

 

Option D. Agranulocytosis is a complication associated with carbimazole: This statement is correct. Agranulocytosis is a rare but serious side effect of antithyroid medications such as carbimazole and PTU. It is characterized by a dangerously low level of neutrophils, increasing the risk of severe infections.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Radioiodine therapy is contraindicated during pregnancy due to its risk of fetal thyroid destruction. 
  • Propylthiouracil is the preferred antithyroid drug in early pregnancy and is safe during breastfeeding. 
  • Agranulocytosis is a rare but serious adverse effect of antithyroid medications.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a high-speed road traffic collision. He is hemodynamically stable and fully conscious. As part of the trauma evaluation, a chest radiograph is taken and given below. Which of the following procedures is contraindicated in this clinical setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intercostal drainage tube

 

  • The chest X-ray reveals a classic appearance of left-sided diaphragmatic rupture, evidenced by:
    • A large air-fluid level within the left hemithorax,
    • Collapsed lung tissue medially,
    • Bowel loops visible in the chest cavity, and
    • A displaced mediastinum toward the right side.
  • In this setting, the stomach and possibly other abdominal organs have herniated through the ruptured diaphragm into the thoracic cavity, simulating a tension gastrothorax.
  • Why intercostal drainage (ICD) tube placement is contraindicated:
    • Placing an ICD (chest tube) into a space occupied by herniated bowel or stomach is extremely dangerous. 
    • The risk includes iatrogenic perforation of gastrointestinal structures, causing life-threatening contamination of the pleural space and rapid deterioration.
    • This is a surgical emergency, and definitive management involves operative reduction of herniated viscera and diaphragm repair — not tube thoracostomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous morphine administration: Pain control is appropriate for a hemodynamically stable and conscious trauma patient. Morphine helps alleviate pain and improves breathing mechanics by reducing splinting. This is not contraindicated and is a standard supportive measure.

 

Option B. Lateral decubitus positioning for imaging: This positioning can be safely used for better radiographic assessment of fluid levels or confirming bowel loop shifts in the thorax. It does not worsen the patient’s condition and is therefore not contraindicated.

 

Option D. Nasogastric tube insertion: Although it must be done carefully, NG tube insertion is not contraindicated and may even help decompress the herniated stomach, providing symptomatic relief and diagnostic confirmation on repeat imaging (e.g., if the NG tube is seen in the thoracic cavity). It is often part of the workup for tension gastrothorax prior to surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of diaphragmatic rupture with intrathoracic herniation of abdominal organs, intercostal drainage tube insertion is contraindicated due to risk of injuring herniated viscera.

questions.text: A patient presented with pulsatile swelling in the inguinal region. Which of the following is more appropriately done in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Doppler USG

 

  • The term "pulsatile" suggests that the swelling has a vascular origin, likely an aneurysm or other vascular abnormality. 
  • The primary goal in managing such a swelling is to correctly identify its nature, which necessitates imaging.
  • Why Doppler USG is the Best Initial Step:
    • Non-invasive and bedside-available
    • Can easily distinguish between Vascular vs non-vascular swelling
    • Pseudoaneurysm shows to-and-fro waveform in the neck and yin-yang sign
    • True aneurysm: dilated artery with pulsatile flow
    • Abscess or cystic mass: no vascular flow

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antibiotics and observation: This approach might be considered for a non-pulsatile infectious swelling, but given the vascular nature indicated by the pulsatile quality, antibiotics alone would not address the underlying vascular issue.

 

Option C. Incision and drainage: This procedure is appropriate for abscesses or other non-vascular swellings. Performing an incision and drainage on a vascular swelling can result in catastrophic bleeding.

 

Option D. Surgical Excision: While this might eventually be necessary, it should only be considered after confirming the diagnosis with appropriate imaging to plan the surgery safely. Blindly excising a vascular swelling without proper diagnosis can be very dangerous.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a pulsatile swelling in the inguinal region, indicative of a vascular abnormality, imaging such as arterial doppler or angiogram is essential to confirm the diagnosis before deciding on the appropriate intervention.

choices.text: Fomepizole inhibits the enzyme responsible for converting glycolic acid to oxalic acid, directly preventing renal toxicity
Fomepizole Non competitively inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH), preventing the formation of toxic metabolites like glycolic acid and oxalic acid
Fomepizole has Higher affinity for alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) as compared to ethylene glycol

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary mechanism by which fomepizole prevents the toxic effects of ethylene glycol poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fomepizole has Higher affinity for alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) as compared to ethylene glycol

 

  • Fomepizole has a higher affinity for ADH than ethylene glycol, which is why it prevents the metabolism of ethylene glycol into its toxic metabolites.
  • Fomepizole is the antidote for ethylene glycol and methanol poisoning. Its mechanism of action is through competitive inhibition of alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH), the enzyme that catalyzes the first step in the metabolism of ethylene glycol to toxic metabolites.
  • Ethylene glycol is converted by ADH to glycolaldehyde, then to glycolic acid, and ultimately to oxalic acid, which is nephrotoxic.
  • Fomepizole binds to ADH with higher affinity than ethylene glycol, thus preventing its metabolism to glycolic and oxalic acid.
  • This blockade allows ethylene glycol to be excreted unchanged by the kidneys, reducing toxicity.
  • Hence, the correct answer is C, as it most accurately explains the primary pharmacodynamic action of fomepizole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fomepizole inhibits the enzyme responsible for converting glycolic acid to oxalic acid, directly preventing renal toxicity: Fomepizole does not inhibit the enzyme that converts glycolic acid to oxalic acid. It inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH), which prevents the formation of glycolic acid in the first place.

 

Option B. Fomepizole Non competitively inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH), preventing the formation of toxic metabolites like glycolic acid and oxalic acid: Fomepizole competitively inhibits ADH, not non-competitively. So, while this statement describes the correct outcome, it inaccurately describes the type of inhibition.

 

Option D. Both B and C: As already pointed out, B is incorrect because it inaccurately describes the inhibition as non-competitive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fomepizole acts as a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH), with higher affinity than ethylene glycol or methanol, thereby preventing the formation of toxic metabolites such as glycolic acid and oxalic acid.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with fever, temporal headache, and jaw claudication. ESR is 110 mm/h. Fundoscopy shows pale swollen optic disc. What is the most important next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High-dose corticosteroids
 

  • Giant cell arteritis (GCA): elderly, temporal headache, jaw claudication, vision symptoms.
  • High ESR supports inflammatory vasculitis.
  • Start high-dose steroids immediately to prevent irreversible vision loss.
  • Biopsy confirms but should not delay treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Temporal artery biopsy: Biopsy must be done within 1–2 weeks but should not delay therapy.

 

Option C. MRI brain: MRI does not help diagnosis of GCA.

 

Option D. Aspirin 325 mg daily: Aspirin is adjunctive—not primary therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suspected GCA with visual symptoms mandates immediate high-dose steroids to prevent permanent blindness.

choices.text: Examine for vaginal and cervical tears

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) has just delivered via forceps. Following the delivery of the placenta, she experiences sudden severe bleeding. The uterus is well contracted. On examination, her pulse rate (PR) is 100, blood pressure (BP) is 90/60 mmHg, and the patient appears drowsy. Immediate resuscitation is done, and blood transfusion is started. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Examine for vaginal and cervical tears

 

  • This patient presents with postpartum hemorrhage following placental delivery, and the uterus is well contracted. 
  • In this scenario, the most likely cause of bleeding is vaginal or cervical tears, not uterine atony, as the uterus has already contracted. 
  • The next best step is to perform a thorough vaginal and cervical examination to identify and repair any tears.

  • In cases like this, where the uterus is well contracted, it's important to rule out trauma to the birth canal (e.g., tears) as a cause of bleeding before proceeding with other interventions like oxytocics.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine artery embolization: Uterine artery embolization is reserved for cases of severe and persistent bleeding when conservative measures fail. This patient's well-contracted uterus suggests that the bleeding is more likely due to vaginal or cervical tears rather than uterine atony, so embolization is not the initial step.

 

Option C. Administer oxytocics: Oxytocics (e.g., oxytocin) are the first-line treatment for uterine atony. However, in this case, the uterus is well contracted, indicating that uterine atony is not the issue. Therefore, administering oxytocics would not be appropriate before addressing potential vaginal or cervical tears.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is typically a last resort for uncontrollable bleeding when other treatments have failed, especially for uterine rupture or massive hemorrhage from placental issues. Since the uterus is well contracted and the bleeding is likely due to vaginal or cervical tears, hysterectomy is not indicated at this point.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the case of postpartum hemorrhage with a well-contracted uterus, the most likely cause of bleeding is vaginal or cervical tears. 
  • The first step in management is to examine the vagina and cervix for tears before proceeding with other interventions like oxytocics or more invasive treatments.

choices.text: Solifenacin is a long-acting vesicoselective M3 antagonist
Oxybutynin is very short acting antimuscarinic drug
Mirabegron is useful in management of overactive bladder without affecting muscarinic receptors
Trospium is antimuscarinic drug with high CNS penetration and should be avoided in Alzheimer’s disease

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with increased urinary urgency and frequency for the past 4 months, sometimes accompanied by urge incontinence. She has a known history of early-stage Alzheimer’s disease, for which she is on donepezil. The physician is planning pharmacologic management for overactive bladder (OAB) and is reviewing drug choices, especially keeping in mind her risk of cognitive side effects. Which of the following statements regarding the pharmacology of drugs used for overactive bladder is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trospium is antimuscarinic drug with high CNS penetration and should be avoided in Alzheimer’s disease

 

  • Trospium is antimuscarinic drug with high CNS penetration and should be avoided in Alzheimer’s disease
  • Trospium is a quaternary ammonium compound (hydrophilic).
  • Poor CNS penetration due to limited ability to cross the blood-brain barrier.
  • Minimal cognitive side effects, making it suitable in Alzheimer's or elderly patients.
  • This is in contrast to tertiary amines like oxybutynin, which easily cross into CNS.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement A. Solifenacin is a long-acting vesicoselective M3 antagonist: True.

 

  • Solifenacin selectively blocks M3 receptors in the bladder detrusor muscle.
  • Once-daily dosing with long duration of action.
  • Good bladder selectivity (vesicoselectivity) reduces systemic side effects.
  • Commonly used for chronic OAB.

 

Statement B. Oxybutynin is very short acting antimuscarinic drug: True.

 

  • Immediate-release (IR) oxybutynin has a short half-life (~2–3 hours).
  • Rapid onset but requires frequent dosing.
  • High incidence of anticholinergic side effects (dry mouth, blurred vision, CNS issues).
  • Extended-release and transdermal forms are available with improved profiles.

 

Statement C. Mirabegron is useful in management of overactive bladder without affecting muscarinic receptors: True.
 

  • Mirabegron is a β3-adrenergic receptor agonist.
  • Promotes bladder relaxation during filling phase.
  • No effect on muscarinic receptors, so no anticholinergic side effects.
  • Preferred in elderly and cognitively impaired patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trospium has low CNS penetration and is a safer antimuscarinic choice in elderly and Alzheimer's patients. 
  • The statement that it has high CNS penetration is incorrect.

choices.text: Multistage sampling uses only one level of random selection; cluster uses several.
Cluster sampling uses stratified selection at each level, whereas multistage uses fixed blocks.
Multistage sampling applies random selection at multiple levels; cluster typically selects only one level as the unit.
Both are identical in terms of error rates and sampling variability.

questions.text: How does cluster sampling differ from multistage sampling in large-scale field surveys?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multistage sampling applies random selection at multiple levels; cluster typically selects only one level as the unit.

 

  • Multistage sampling involves selecting units at two or more levels in a nested, hierarchical structure. In this example, the sampling progresses from states → districts → towns → households, with randomization at each level. 
  • It is especially useful in large, geographically spread-out populations and increases flexibility while maintaining representativeness.
  • Cluster sampling, in contrast, selects groups or “clusters” (e.g., entire villages) as the primary sampling unit and then includes all or a subset of members within the cluster.
  • It usually involves only one primary level of selection and is more feasible logistically but may introduce greater sampling error due to intra-cluster homogeneity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multistage sampling uses only one level of random selection; cluster uses several: Incorrect. Multistage by definition involves more than one level of sampling.

 

Option B. Cluster sampling uses stratified selection at each level, whereas multistage uses fixed blocks: Incorrect. Stratified sampling divides populations into strata; cluster sampling selects intact groups without stratification.

 

Option D. Both are identical in terms of error rates and sampling variability: Incorrect. Cluster sampling usually has higher sampling error compared to multistage due to greater intra-cluster similarity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multistage sampling involves random selection at multiple hierarchical levels, offering more flexibility and representativeness, whereas cluster sampling generally selects one level (e.g., villages, schools) and samples within that cluster.

questions.text:
Categorize the statements below regarding trauma patients as true (T) or false (F): 

 

  1. Arterial blood gas is a useful indicator of shock in patients of trauma, and trending these values can reflect improvements with resuscitation.
  2. In patients with suspected fracture of the cribriform plate, a Ryles tube is inserted nasally.
  3. It is essential to catheterize the patient transurethrally before you can proceed to examine the perineum and genitalia.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) T, F, F

 

  1. Arterial blood gas is a useful indicator of shock in patients of trauma, and trending these values can reflect improvements with resuscitation: True. Arterial blood gas (ABG) is indeed a useful indicator of shock in trauma patients and can reflect changes in response to resuscitation efforts.
  2. In patients with suspected fracture of the cribriform plate, a Ryles tube is inserted nasally: False. If a cribriform plate fracture is suspected, inserting a gastric tube nasally is contraindicated due to the risk of entering the cranial vault.
  3. It is essential to catheterize the patient transurethrally before you can proceed to examine the perineum and genitalia: False. Catheterization should not be done trans-urethrally before examining the perineum and genitalia, particularly if there is evidence of potential urethral injury.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Arterial blood gases are valuable for assessing shock and response to resuscitation. Gastric tubes should be inserted orally in the context of potential cribriform plate fractures to avoid intracranial passage. 
  • Lastly, a careful examination of the perineum and genitalia is necessary before catheterization to avoid exacerbating any potential urethral injuries.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with high-grade fever, malaise, and systemic signs of inflammation two days after returning from a camping trip. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum levels of interleukin-1β (IL-1β) and interleukin-18 (IL-18). The inflammatory response is linked to an intracellular bacterial infection triggering a specific form of programmed cell death. Which of the following best describes the mechanism involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyroptosis

 

  • Pyroptosis is a highly inflammatory form of programmed cell death most often associated with intracellular infections. It is characterized by the activation of caspase-1 and caspase-11, which in turn leads to the release of proinflammatory cytokines IL-1β and IL-18, both of which are mentioned in this case. 
  • This process helps eliminate infected cells and alert the immune system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apoptosis: A non-inflammatory, tightly regulated form of cell death involving caspase-3, -6, and -7. It does not involve IL-1β or IL-18 and is not typically associated with pathogen-triggered inflammatory responses.

 

Option B. Oncosis: A form of accidental cell death resulting from cellular injury (e.g., ischemia), leading to cell swelling and membrane rupture. It is not a programmed or cytokine-mediated pathway.

 

Option D. Necroptosis: A caspase-independent form of programmed cell death involving RIPK1, RIPK3, and MLKL. Though also inflammatory, it is not driven by IL-1β or IL-18 and does not use caspase-1 or -11.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyroptosis is a form of programmed cell death characterized by caspase-1 and caspase-11 activation and release of proinflammatory cytokines IL-1β and IL-18, especially in the setting of intracellular bacterial infections.

questions.text: A cost-effectiveness analysis is conducted to assess a new cancer treatment that prolongs life by 1.5 years but only 0.9 of that is in perfect health. Which of the following metrics best quantifies this outcome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) QALY

 

  • The Quality-Adjusted Life Year (QALY) is a measure that combines both the quantity and quality of life lived. It is widely used in health economics to assess the value of medical interventions. One QALY equates to one year in perfect health. If an individual lives for a year in a health state valued at 0.5 (on a scale where 0 represents death and 1 represents perfect health), they accrue 0.5 QALYs.
  • In the scenario provided, the new cancer treatment extends life by 1.5 years, but only 0.9 of that time is in perfect health. This suggests that the remaining 0.6 years are lived in a less-than-perfect health state. To quantify this:
    • Perfect health duration: 0.9 years × 1.0 (utility weight) = 0.9 QALYs
    • Imperfect health duration: 0.6 years × utility weight (assumed <1.0) = additional QALYs (value depends on specific utility weight)
  • However, since only 0.9 years are in perfect health, and the rest is not specified, the total QALYs gained would be less than 1.5, depending on the utility weights assigned to the less-than-perfect health states.
  • QALYs are instrumental in cost-effectiveness analyses, allowing for the comparison of the effectiveness of different interventions by considering both longevity and quality of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. YPLL (Years of Potential Life Lost): YPLL measures the total number of years not lived by individuals who die prematurely, typically before a predetermined age (e.g., 65 or 75). It focuses solely on mortality and does not account for the quality of life or morbidity. Therefore, it is not suitable for evaluating the benefits of a treatment that extends life or improves quality of life.

 

Option B. DALY (Disability-Adjusted Life Year): DALY quantifies the burden of disease by combining years of life lost due to premature death and years lived with disability. It is primarily used to assess the overall disease burden in populations rather than evaluating the benefits of specific medical interventions.

 

Option D. HALE (Health-Adjusted Life Expectancy): HALE represents the average number of years a person can expect to live in "full health" by adjusting for time spent in poor health due to disease and/or injury. It is a population-level measure and not typically used for assessing individual medical treatments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

QALY quantifies both the quantity and quality of life gained from an intervention, making it the key metric for evaluating cost-effectiveness in clinical decision-making.

choices.text: It is an ester local anesthetic that blocks calcium channels
It enhances bleeding at the site of application
It blocks sodium channels and also causes local vasoconstriction
It is primarily used for spinal anesthesia due to prolonged action

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding cocaine when used as a local anesthetic?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It blocks sodium channels and also causes local vasoconstriction

 

  • Cocaine is a unique ester local anesthetic that works by blocking sodium channels, thereby inhibiting nerve impulse conduction and producing anesthesia. 
  • A distinctive feature of cocaine is its vasoconstrictive effect due to norepinephrine reuptake inhibition—this property helps reduce bleeding, especially in surgeries involving highly vascular areas (like nasal mucosa). 
  • This contrasts with most local anesthetics that tend to cause vasodilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is an ester local anesthetic that blocks calcium channels: Incorrect. Cocaine blocks sodium channels—not calcium channels—and is classified as an ester anesthetic.

 

Option B. It enhances bleeding at the site of application: Incorrect. Cocaine causes vasoconstriction, not vasodilation.

 

Option D. It is primarily used for spinal anesthesia due to prolonged action: Incorrect. Cocaine is not used for spinal anesthesia due to its high abuse potential and shorter action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cocaine acts as a local anesthetic and vasoconstrictor, making it useful in procedures like nasal surgeries. 
  • It blocks sodium channels and reduces bleeding, but its clinical use is restricted due to its addictive potential.

questions.text: All of the following are selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitors except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amitriptyline

 

  • Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA), not an SSRI. 
  • It works by inhibiting the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine, and it also affects other neurotransmitter systems, which contributes to its broader side effect profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Escitalopram: Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) commonly used to treat depression and anxiety disorders. It works by increasing the levels of serotonin in the brain by inhibiting its reuptake into presynaptic cells.

 

Option C. Fluoxetine: Fluoxetine is one of the most well-known SSRIs. It is used to treat depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, bulimia nervosa, and panic disorder. It specifically inhibits the reuptake of serotonin, thereby increasing its availability in the synaptic cleft.

 

Option D. Sertraline: Sertraline is another SSRI used to treat depression, anxiety disorders, panic attacks, and other mood disorders. Like other SSRIs, it increases serotonin levels in the brain by inhibiting its reuptake into presynaptic cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) that inhibits both serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake, whereas SSRIs such as escitalopram, fluoxetine, and sertraline selectively inhibit serotonin reuptake only.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with proximal muscle weakness and rash. She has difficulty climbing stairs and rising from a chair. Examination reveals the finding below. What is the most useful investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Muscle biopsy

 

  • Classic dermatomyositis: Proximal weakness + heliotrope rash + Gottron’s papules.
  • Muscle biopsy confirms inflammation and helps rule out mimics (e.g., inclusion body myositis).
  • CK elevated but not specific.
  • EMG and autoantibodies support but biopsy is gold standard.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANA: ANA may be positive but nonspecific.

 

Option B. Serum CK levels: CK is helpful screening test but doesn’t confirm diagnosis.

 

Option D. Anti Mi-2: A specific autoantibody for dermatomyositis, but its testing is supportive

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscle biopsy is the definitive test for diagnosing dermatomyositis and differentiating from other myopathies.

choices.text: Botulinum toxin injection for Müller muscle overaction

questions.text: A patient with stable TAO and chronic proptosis presents with decreased color vision and a new relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD). Imaging reveals apical orbital crowding. Which intervention is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Orbital decompression surgery

 

  • RAPD will affect the Optic nerve. Optic nerve is getting affected with thyroid affected orbitopathy 
  • This patient has compressive optic neuropathy secondary to thyroid eye disease, as evidenced by:
    • RAPD (sign of optic nerve dysfunction)
    • Decreased color vision (early sign of optic nerve compromise)
    • Visual field defect
    • Apical orbital crowding on imaging
  • In such cases, orbital decompression is the most effective treatment. It relieves pressure on the optic nerve by removing portions of the orbital wall or fat to increase orbital volume.
  • In orbital decompression surgeries we will remove the orbital walls to create space for the expanded orbital muscles which will compress the optic nerve
    • We will do two wall decompression for the removal of floor and medial wall. Along the floor we have maxillary sinus and along the medial wall we have ethmoid sinus
    • 3 wall decompression in which there is addition of temporal wall
    • 4 wall decompression in which there is addition of roof 
  • Optic nerve cannot be replaced or regenerated. So if we don’t do orbital decompression surgery then the optic nerve will be lost forever. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic steroids and lubricating drops: Steroids are for the acute stage. They are first-line for active inflammatory TAO, but this patient is stable (chronic phase) and shows signs of optic nerve compression, where steroids are often ineffective alone. Lubricants manage surface disease but do not address neuropathy.

 

Option B. Botulinum toxin injection for Müller muscle overaction: Used for cosmetic management of lid retraction, not for vision-threatening complications. It does not alleviate optic nerve compression. They can be used for mild ptosis and for thyroid associated squint.

 

Option C. Orbital radiation to improve motility: Radiation is used in early, active disease to reduce inflammation of extraocular muscles but is too slow for optic neuropathy, and not effective in the chronic phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In thyroid-associated orbitopathy, compressive optic neuropathy is a vision-threatening complication. 
  • The most effective and urgent treatment in the chronic stable phase with apical crowding is orbital decompression surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme makes a transient single-stranded break in the supercoiled DNA double helix, which allows the DNA to unwind and relieve torsional strain during replication?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Topoisomerase Type I

 

  • Topoisomerase Type I creates a transient single-stranded break in supercoiled DNA. This allows the DNA to unwind, relieving torsional strain without the need for energy input (ATP). 
  • After relieving the strain, the enzyme re-ligates the DNA to restore the integrity of the DNA strand. 
  • This action is crucial during processes such as DNA replication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topoisomerase Type II: This enzyme creates transient double-stranded breaks in the DNA and requires ATP. It is involved in processes such as untangling DNA during chromosome segregation in mitosis.

 

Option B. Helicase: Helicase unwinds the DNA double helix ahead of the replication fork but does not make cuts in the DNA. It uses ATP for the unwinding process.

 

Option C. DNA polymerase: DNA polymerase synthesizes new strands of DNA but does not relieve DNA supercoiling or make breaks in the DNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topoisomerase Type I makes a transient single-stranded break in negatively supercoiled DNA, allowing it to unwind and relieve torsional strain during replication and transcription.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be adverse effect with long-term treatment of bipolar disorder with lithium carbonate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Weight loss

 

Weight loss is not a common adverse effect of lithium carbonate. In fact, weight gain is more frequently observed in patients on long-term lithium therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism is a well-documented side effect of long-term lithium therapy. Lithium interferes with thyroid hormone synthesis and release, leading to hypothyroidism in some patients.

 

Option C. Leucocytosis: Long-term lithium use can increase the levels of neutrophils in the blood, resulting in leucocytosis.

 

Option D. Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus: Lithium can impair the kidney's ability to concentrate urine, leading to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. This condition is characterized by excessive urination and thirst due to the kidney's inability to respond to antidiuretic hormone.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Long-term lithium therapy is associated with hypothyroidism, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, and leucocytosis. 
  • Weight loss is not a recognized side effect; instead, weight gain is more common.

choices.text: Minimizes Hawthorne effect in placebo arms
Avoids confirmation bias during data analysis

questions.text: A triple-blinded RCT evaluating a new lipid-lowering agent unexpectedly fails to replicate during meta-analysis. What is the primary reason triple blinding is used in original trials?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Avoids confirmation bias during data analysis

 

  • Triple blinding refers to when study participants, investigators, and the data analysts or outcome assessors are unaware of the treatment allocations. 
  • The key purpose of including the data analyst in the blinding process is to minimize confirmation bias—the subconscious (or conscious) tendency to favor or interpret data in a way that confirms preconceived expectations or the desired hypothesis.
  • In this case, the triple-blind design was intended to ensure that the analysis was conducted without any influence from knowledge of who received the active drug or placebo, maintaining internal validity. 
  • Though the trial results didn’t replicate in meta-analysis, the triple blinding still served its methodological role.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Minimizes Hawthorne effect in placebo arms: Incorrect. The Hawthorne effect refers to behavioral changes in participants simply due to awareness of being observed, not specifically due to blinding. While blinding participants (as in single or double blinding) may help reduce subject bias, it is not the primary purpose of triple blinding, which targets analyzer bias.

 

Option B. Prevents loss to follow-up: Incorrect. Loss to follow-up is an issue of attrition bias and is managed by retention strategies and ITT (intention-to-treat) analysis. It is unrelated to whether the analyst is blinded.

 

Option D. Prevents allocation concealment error: Incorrect. Allocation concealment refers to preventing selection bias at the time of randomization, ensuring group assignment is unknown prior to enrollment. It occurs before blinding is applied and is different from blinding, which occurs after allocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triple blinding minimizes subject bias, investigator bias, and most importantly, confirmation bias by the data analyst, which can otherwise distort interpretation and reporting of trial outcomes.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with cirrhosis due to chronic hepatitis C presents with confusion, disorientation, and asterixis. His serum ammonia level is elevated. He is diagnosed with hepatic encephalopathy. In addition to lactulose, the physician decides to add a poorly absorbed antibiotic to reduce ammonia-producing gut flora. Which of the following drug combinations is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neomycin or Rifaximin

 

  • Neomycin and rifaximin are poorly absorbed antibiotics used as adjunctive therapies in hepatic encephalopathy. 
  • Hepatic encephalopathy results from the accumulation of ammonia and other toxins in the bloodstream due to impaired liver function. 
  • These toxins are often produced by gut bacteria. 
  • Neomycin and rifaximin work by reducing the number of ammonia-producing bacteria in the intestines, thereby lowering blood ammonia levels and improving symptoms of hepatic encephalopathy.
  • Since they are poorly absorbed, they exert their effects primarily within the gastrointestinal tract, minimizing systemic side effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tenofovir or Telbivudine: Tenofovir and telbivudine are antiviral medications used in the treatment of hepatitis B infection. They are not antibiotics and are not typically used for hepatic encephalopathy. Therefore, this option is incorrect in the context of poorly absorbed antibiotics used for hepatic encephalopathy.

 

Option B. Sofosbuvir or Velpatasvir: Sofosbuvir and velpatasvir are antiviral drugs used in the treatment of hepatitis C infection. Similar to tenofovir and telbivudine, they are not antibiotics and are not used for hepatic encephalopathy. Hence, this option is also incorrect.

 

Option C. Levofloxacin or Clarithromycin: Levofloxacin and clarithromycin are antibiotics; however, they are well absorbed and used for treating bacterial infections such as respiratory and urinary tract infections. They are not used as poorly absorbed antibiotics for hepatic encephalopathy, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neomycin and rifaximin are poorly absorbed antibiotics used in hepatic encephalopathy to reduce ammonia-producing gut flora and lower systemic ammonia levels.

choices.text: Angelman syndrome is more common than this condition
The patient will have a happy demeanor with frequent laughter
Paternal gene is deleted or non-functional

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with hypotonia, increase appetite, developmental delay, almond-shaped eyes, and obesity. He exhibits temper tantrums and compulsive skin picking. Genetic analysis reveals imprinting on chromosome 15q11–q13. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Paternal gene is deleted or non-functional

 

  • Prader-Willi Syndrome is caused by loss of paternal 15q11–q13 gene due to deletion or maternal uniparental disomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It results from maternal deletion: Incorrect. Maternal deletion causes Angelman Syndrome, not Prader-Willi.

 

Option B. Angelman syndrome is more common than this condition: Incorrect. Prader-Willi is more common than Angelman.

 

Option C. The patient will have a happy demeanor with frequent laughter: Incorrect. That’s a hallmark of Angelman syndrome (also called “happy puppet syndrome”).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obesity, intellectual disability and micropenis are the features of prader willi syndrome

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with fever, watery diarrhea, and blood-streaked stool for the past two days. Stool culture is ordered to identify the causative bacterial pathogen. Which of the following enrichment media is most appropriate for isolating the likely organism from this stool sample?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Selenite F broth

 

  • Selenite F broth is a selective enrichment medium used for isolating Salmonella and Shigella from fecal specimens, especially when competing coliform bacteria are present. 
  • In a child presenting with bloody diarrhea and fever, invasive enteric pathogens such as Shigella is the likely culprit. 
  • Selenite F suppresses the growth of normal fecal flora while promoting the growth of these enteric pathogens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Robertson cooked meat broth: This is an anaerobic enrichment medium, typically used for culturing Clostridium species from clinical specimens, not enteric pathogens from stool.

 

Option B. Alkaline peptone water: This medium is used for enrichment of Vibrio species, particularly Vibrio cholerae, not Salmonella or Shigella.

 

Option D. Brain heart infusion broth: This is a general-purpose enrichment medium used to cultivate fastidious organisms like Streptococci, not selectively used for stool pathogens like Salmonella or Shigella.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selenite F broth is the enrichment medium used for isolating Salmonella and Shigella from stool specimens, especially in cases of diarrhea with blood in stools.

questions.text: A 28-year-old farmer presents with fever, jaundice, and hemoptysis after 7 days of illness. He is hypoxic (SpO2 88% on room air) and hypotensive (BP 90/60 mmHg). Labs show hemoglobin 9.8 g/dL, platelets 60,000/mm³, creatinine 3.2 mg/dL, bilirubin 8.5 mg/dL. Chest CT reveals diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. Despite fluid resuscitation, his condition deteriorates with worsening hemoptysis. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer IV ceftriaxone

 

  • The farmer’s presentation—fever, jaundice, hemoptysis, hypoxia, hypotension, renal failure, and diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH) on CT—suggests severe leptospirosis with pulmonary hemorrhage syndrome, likely from floodwater exposure.
  • IV ceftriaxone is an effective antibiotic for leptospirosis, targeting Leptospira, and is critical given the deterioration despite fluids, indicating ongoing infection.
  • Mechanical ventilation (not listed but implied in severe cases) would also be needed for hypoxemia, but the question focuses on the next pharmacological step.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start plasmapheresis: Used for thrombotic microangiopathy or autoimmune DAH (e.g., Goodpasture’s), not infectious leptospirosis.

 

Option B. Initiate high-dose corticosteroids: Contraindicated in bacterial sepsis; may worsen infection and is reserved for immune-mediated DAH.

 

Option D. Perform urgent renal biopsy: Risky in an unstable patient; renal failure is likely acute tubular necrosis from leptospirosis, not requiring biopsy now.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Severe leptospirosis with pulmonary hemorrhage requires urgent antibiotics (e.g., IV ceftriaxone) and ventilatory support for DAH and hypoxemia.
  • Clinical suspicion arises from occupational exposure and multiorgan involvement; avoid immunosuppression.
  • Rapid intervention is essential to prevent progression to ARDS or death.

questions.text: Which one of the following pressures is primarily regulated by the carotid sinus baroreceptors?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mean arterial pressure

 

  • Baroreceptors and chemoreceptors are going to maintain the BP. 
  • Carotid sinus baroreceptors are stretch-sensitive mechanoreceptors located in the wall of the internal carotid artery just above the bifurcation. 
  • They primarily respond to changes in mean arterial pressure (MAP) — the average pressure in a patient’s arteries during one cardiac cycle. 
  • Baroreceptors maintain the mean blood pressure in the range of 60 – 200 mmHg and chemoreceptors will maintain the mean blood pressure in between 40 – 60 mmHg
  • A drop in MAP (as in hypotension or hypovolemia) leads to decreased baroreceptor firing, which in turn reduces inhibition of the medullary cardiovascular center. 
  • This causes increased sympathetic outflow and reduced parasympathetic tone, leading to increased heart rate (HR), vasoconstriction, and restoration of blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diastolic blood pressure: Baroreceptors are sensitive to pressure changes throughout the cardiac cycle, but they do not specifically regulate diastolic pressure alone.

 

Option C. Systolic blood pressure: Although baroreceptors may transiently respond to peak systolic pressures, they are tuned to the average stretch over time — i.e., MAP.

 

Option D. Pulse pressure: Though baroreceptors are sensitive to the Pulse pressure (difference between systolic and diastolic pressure) but it is not the primary variable maintained or regulated by baroreceptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carotid sinus baroreceptors primarily regulate mean arterial pressure by modulating autonomic output to maintain hemodynamic stability in response to changes in blood volume or vascular tone.

choices.text: Reassure her that it's normal to have a delayed period

questions.text: A 27-year-old unmarried woman with a history of regular menstrual cycles presents with a complaint of a missed period. On pelvic examination, no abnormalities are found. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta hCG estimation

 

  • The next step in the management of a woman presenting with a missed period and no pelvic abnormalities is to check a beta hCG level. 
  • Beta hCG is the most reliable and cost-effective test to confirm pregnancy, which is the most common cause of a missed period. 
  • Given that the woman has no abnormalities on pelvic examination, pregnancy should be ruled out first before further diagnostic steps are taken.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum FSH and LH: Serum FSH and LH are typically useful in the evaluation of ovulatory disorders, such as polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) or premature ovarian failure. However, given the complaint of a missed period and the lack of other clinical findings, beta hCG estimation is the more appropriate next step for ruling out pregnancy first.

 

Option C. Reassure her that it's normal to have a delayed period: While delayed periods can occur from time to time, it is important to rule out pregnancy first, especially in a woman of reproductive age. Beta hCG testing will help confirm or exclude pregnancy, and if negative, reassurance can be provided later.

 

Option D. Transvaginal ultrasound: A transvaginal ultrasound is useful for evaluating structural causes of missed periods (e.g., fibroids, polycystic ovaries, ovarian cysts). However, it is not the first step in the evaluation of a missed period. Beta hCG testing should be done first to rule out pregnancy before considering other diagnostic imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of a missed period is to rule out pregnancy by performing a beta hCG test, as it is the most common cause of amenorrhea in women of reproductive age.

questions.text: Match the urea cycle disorder with its corresponding enzyme deficiency:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A–2, B–3, C–1, D–4

 

A → 2. Argininosuccinic aciduria: Caused by deficiency of argininosuccinate lyase, the enzyme that cleaves argininosuccinate into arginine and fumarate in the urea cycle.

 

B → 3. Hyperammonemia Type II: Due to deficiency of ornithine transcarbamoylase (OTC), the most common inherited urea cycle disorder. Leads to elevated carbamoyl phosphate and orotic acid.

 

C → 1. Citrullinemia Type I: Results from a deficiency of argininosuccinate synthetase, leading to accumulation of citrulline.

 

D → 4. Hyperammonemia Type I: Caused by deficiency of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS-I), preventing formation of carbamoyl phosphate, the first step in the urea cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Each urea cycle disorder is associated with a specific enzyme deficiency:
  • Hyperammonemia Type I → CPS-I,
  • Hyperammonemia Type II → OTC,
  • Citrullinemia Type I → Argininosuccinate synthetase,
  • Argininosuccinic aciduria → Argininosuccinate lyase.

choices.text: Dilated capillary loops in nail fold can be seen in this disease
Heliotrope rash seen in this disease is associated with anti-Mi-2 antibodies
Mechanic’s hands can be seen in this disease
Muscle tenderness is common in this condition

questions.text: A 30-year-old male software engineer presents to the outpatient department with complaints of reddish discoloration on his upper back and a purple hue around his eyes. He reports difficulty climbing stairs and lifting heavy objects. On examination, there is erythema over the upper back, violaceous rash over the upper eyelids, and cracked rough skin on the lateral digits. Nail fold examination shows periungual erythema with dilated capillary loops. Serum creatinine kinase is significantly elevated. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Muscle tenderness is common in this condition

 

  • This patient’s features are diagnostic of Dermatomyositis, an autoimmune inflammatory myopathy affecting skin and muscles.
    • Heliotrope rash (purple hue around eyes), shawl sign (as shown in the image above), and Gottron's papules are hallmark cutaneous signs.
    • Dilated periungual capillary loops and mechanic’s hands (cracked, rough skin on lateral digits) are also seen.

 


 

 

 

  • Muscle weakness (not tenderness) is typical — particularly of proximal muscles (e.g., climbing stairs, lifting).

 

  • Muscle tenderness is not common and hence makes Option D the false statement.

 

Note: Heliotrope rash seen in this disease is also associated with anti-Jo-1 antibodies 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dermatomyositis presents with proximal muscle weakness and characteristic skin changes. 
  • The disease is associated with elevated muscle enzymes and specific autoantibodies (anti-Mi-2, anti-Jo-1). Muscle tenderness is not a consistent finding.
